Penticton, B.C.,
June 5th, 1943.

Mr. R.A. Hey,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed is a list of books at present in Penticton Indian School Library.

I am sorry I overlooked your request to send the above at an earlier date; also, to send my two requisitions sooner.

I take this opportunity, likewise, to thank you for your subscription to the magazine "Canadian Nature." The children enjoy it, and it is a help to me.

I am,

Respectfully Yours,

Catherine Macdonald,
Teacher.

Dear Sir,

Herewith list of books in this school library. There is little use of going to the expense just now in adding to this number as they are of little use to the children who are not far enough advanced in their grades to make good use of them. The rough treatment the books receive and the fact that there is so much contagious skin diseases amongst the children makes the use of such books inadvisable just at present. The need is amply met with a constant and varied supply of Sunday School papers that contain good reading, and articles on crafts and what can be easily made from simple materials.

Should there be a revision in Text Books at some future date, it would be as well to change the name of the doll in "Two little Indians", for the authors have called it "May", and this has an unpleasant meaning in the Indian Language, in fact, no Indian would call their child "May". In the Highroads to Reading, Page 186, Book III, the story to illustrate "The Golden Rule" is not a nice one for Indian Children to read. I just mention these in case no one else has done so.

Yours very truly

Sam Waller.
The Pas Indian Day School.

Dear Sir,

You will notice that these two very popular books, with most children are worn out. I would be pleased to obtain three or four copies of each of these books: Treasure Island by R. L. Stevenson; Black Beauty by Anna Sewell; Blackie and Sons; Alice in Wonderland.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

John L. Lowe.

Fisher River School,
Kosstatah, Man.,
June 30, 1943.

P. A. Grey, Esq.,
Director of Indian Education,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed is a list of the books in the classroom libraries at Fisher River School. The pupils in Grades VII and VIII compiled the list as a closing exercise at school.

Many of the books were presented to the school by a departing missionary and are quite beyond the comprehension of even Grade VIII children. There is nothing that Grades III and IV, V, VI can get much enjoyment from except for the Alger books and the Pansy stories. Neither are of much educational value. Grades VII and VIII have read books like Trinkles, The Fairy Queen, Tales from Shakespeare, The Call of the Wild, the Ballantyne books and used the Dickie History readers as reference books. Little interest is shown in the other books.

The Junior Red Cross Magazine, and Nature Magazine are very popular. We use World Affairs for our
Current Events. All are helpful.

If books along the lines of those which Grades VII and VIII have already read, suitable books for Grades III - VI could be added to our present supply I am sure more reading would be done.

The books in the Junior Classroom library are very satisfactory. I hope we may be sent another set of supplementary readers like "Joe and Ruth Go to School." A dozen copies of primers such as "Friends"

"Mary, John and Peter" (Primers to Ontario Readers)

"Pat and Patty" Pre-primer

are good reading material for the younger children - and there would be books enough to go around.

The library can be a very helpful asset in a school as all our children need more vocabulary practice. A great number of them really like reading and would do more if there were more suitable books available.

Hoping that this list and few remarks may be of help to you in your survey,

Yours truly,
(Miss) Edythe Smith-Windsor.
(Principal)

This will acknowledge your letter of the 31st of December with reference to forming travelling libraries among the Schools in this Superintendency.

The matter was discussed at a recent meeting of the Teachers, and it was felt that such an arrangement could be worked out with excellent results, and enable the schools to have more varied reading material.

It was felt if the Department would supply a different variety of library books for each school, we would devise a group system - four groups of three schools each, who could exchange among themselves during the school year. This would keep the books moving a little more frequently than once a year, which was felt advisable; then with the advent of a new school year, No.1 group would exchange with No.2 and so on, so that each group finally had all the books received and thus maintain a quicker and more varied cycle of books.

If the Department would forward suitable books as variable as possible we can work out the details as outlined above, and it would more or less follow the lines of your suggestion.

Lt.-Col. E.P. Randle,

Indian Superintendent.

"Joan At Halfway" bears the mark of a distinguished story-telling gift. It is softened and delicate, and has a lovely simplicity. The character of the pastoral Nova Scotia section is portrayed, is represented with rare freshness and charm—a life half manorial, half frontier, and the people vivid with idiosyncrasies. An extraordinary thing is the quality of the speech in which the book is rendered, a plain rustic speech that yet is flavoured with the Old Testament and with Chaucer."

—New York Tribune.

"In the 400 odd pages there is not one that is dull or uninteresting. 'Halfway' and its people, become very real to the reader before many leaves are turned, and through the telling of the delightful story, seem no longer merely people in a book, but have been added to the list of friends in whose companionship one rejoices."

—St. John Globe.

"Joan At Halfway is a very charming novel, the action centering around Halfway, the old, old home of the Wisdom family, ruled over by Garret Wisdom, a crochety old autocrat. A delicious good humor permeates the book."

—Saturday Night.

"The story is scented with rich local color of character, manners, and customs, as well as landscape, and it is the author's ability to envisage and portray the very soul of the region, giving to her story a wholesome and a welcome humaneness."

—New York Times.
"A bewitching book, ripe with mystery and tradition, that receives you and makes you utterly at home with the wide Wisdom connection, sweet and homely folk, buoyed by pride and sheer-anchored by the high things of the earth. It is written out of a profound understanding of life, its beauty and its significance. Joan-of-the-singing-heart is a winsome creature. Deeply, wisely human is the story, radiated throughout by humor and quick wit."

—Milwaukee Sentinel.

"The author of Joan At Halfway paints her pictures with the sure strong hand of a lover of her country, paints as if she were the owner of its reputation, vivid word pictures of the characteristics of the Blue Nose people, and the matchless beauty of their land."

—Morning Chronicle.

"It is like the books I was brought up on—plain, good, sweet English—a comfortable cheerful story, yet brimming with life—and 'smells as a field that God hath blest.'"

—Rev. D. A. Steele, D.D.

"Stories of the Land of Evangeline" is the title of a series of short tales of surpassing interest, told with clearness and grace. The author with great artistic skill seizing upon the most romantic stories of her native land and weaving around them a spell all her own."

—Halifax Herald.

"No part of this wide Dominion is so rich in romantic interest as the 'Acadie' of the old French regime. Its beauties have been sung in verse and prose by many an ambitious writer, but Grace McLeod Rogers seems to have developed a peculiar gift of interpretation. She has gathered a group of delightful tales that recall all the drama and all the romance of those old days of heroism and romance. The book is well worth keeping in a handy place upon the library shelf you reserve for those volumes you hold in affectionate regard."

My dear Sirs:

I have often thought, down the long years of my writing, that I would at some time send some of my stories to the Indian schools, in token of my early and continued interest in the welfare of the Indian youth.

Today, I read, in the Ottawa Journal, the expression of your opinions concerning that long neglected race, and I took it for a sign "that now was the time for me to fulfil my desire." So I am forwarding to address given in the paper a box of my "Joan at Halfury" a purely and truly Nova Scotia story. I understand that the Government is to place a number of my Acadian folklore tales through the schools. Many references are in them to the Indian race.

When a child I lived in Queens County, Nova Scotia, my native heath-land of my sires - and in my home the Indians were frequent visitors. A household of five girls made it a favorite resort for them, it being an understood fact that in return for tales about the young papoose & singing of tribal songs "Any old skins, they give 'um me". Once they brought bunches of the flimsy swamp strips & dyes from roots and berries and wove before our wondering eyes a beautiful low oval basket for our lovely mother.

"How much is enough?" she asked them once, after repeated requests for "little salaratus", maybe little flour or cornmeal - some tea, perhaps, coupola eggs, and bunch candle wicking, etc.- etc. "How much is enough?"

"Oh, just leddle more, she says, answered the gentle voiced placid squaw!

They were pure-blood Micmacs there, of the high names - Peter & Nancy Glode, Franc. - Joe, Co etc.

I wish I had made a tour of the various schools.
Dr. Silas Ferkins Rand who gave his long life and his talents to the Nova Scotia race was a visitor to my childhood home.

The books go to you by freight, prepaid. And I hope you will like to distribute them.

May you both live long to labour in the work you have undertaken - "Life is sweeter when we give, and Love is dearer when we share".

Yours very truly,

Grace McLeod Rogers.

May 3rd, 1944.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

Both Colonel Asland and I have read this manuscript carefully. We agree that it is a charming book and that it would be useful as a library book for our Indian schools, providing the price were low enough. Unfortunately there is now available from the publishers a supply of similar books, most of them too expensive for school use (usually $1.50 and upwards).

I think the illustrations are good, but here again, if they are to be reproduced in colour, then it will add considerably to the cost of the book.

Colonel Asland has had considerable experience in writing children's books for publication. In his opinion the manuscript is better than the average of its kind submitted to publishers. However, he doubts if any publisher would accept it at this time. As you know, the shortage of materials is still such that we are experiencing difficulty in getting a sufficient supply of school texts.

The object of these Travelling Libraries is to supplement the available book stock of smaller public libraries as well as to serve the Women's Institutes, Farmers' Clubs, Study Clubs and schools in communities, rural and urban, where public library service is not accessible. TRAVELLING LIBRARIES

What they are

Small libraries consisting of 35 books may be borrowed by communities, clubs or groups for a three-month period. They are shipped in strong, hinged cases and are accompanied by display posters, book-ends and circulation records.

Three kinds

There are three kinds of travelling libraries:

Regular Libraries are already made up. They contain twenty-five novels and ten books of non-fiction on different subjects—biography, travel and current events predominating. The books are chosen for their variety and general interest.

Special Libraries are made from the Open Shelf Collection. The borrower indicates the kinds of books he wants or sends in a long list of titles (about 75) from the Open Shelf catalogue. Because of the long loan period, few of the very newest books from the Open Shelf can be included.

Children's Libraries. With information as to the age and interests of the readers we make up libraries from our collection of children's books. No books on the Free Reading course for the schools can be included in the libraries because of the long loan period and the great demand for the books.

How libraries are borrowed

Application cards for Travelling Libraries are signed by three responsible citizens of the community and the name of the person to be in charge of the library is given.

The only cost is for transportation.

When the libraries arrive

They can give the best service if they are kept in a prominent place, e.g., post office, and are accessible at frequent and regular intervals. An enthusiastic librarian is a great help in introducing the books to the people who want them. Librarians are asked to keep circulation records on the cards provided.

Although the books should be lent free of charge, small contributions may be accepted from the borrowers to defray the cost of transportation.

The Extension Library reserves the right to discontinue its services to anyone failing to obey the regulations.

OPEN SHELF

This is a collection of about 20,000 books in many fields, including fiction, biography, travel, history, literature, fine arts, science, useful arts, religion and philosophy.

The complete catalogue to November, 1945 is available for 50 cents. Supplementary lists are issued periodically, and may be obtained free on request.

How books are borrowed

Borrowers pay the postage which is the only charge, and are able to take advantage of the reduced postal rates on books. One dollar may be deposited with the library, or readers may send postage each time as they are notified.

Money sent in for postage should not be put in the books or loose in an envelope. The library cannot be responsible for loss of money sent in this way.

The loan period is one month. There is no limit to the number of books that may be borrowed but readers are asked not to borrow more than they can read within the month. There is a fine of five cents a week for overdue books.

TRAVELLING LIBRARY DIVISION.

FOR WHOM ORGANIZED.

The main purpose of the Travelling Libraries is to provide good reading in outlying communities and schools which would otherwise lack library facilities. They have long proved a great boon to adults and school children in such localities.

SCHOOL LIBRARIES.

Travelling Libraries for schools consist of 60 volumes, representative of the full range of the best juvenile literature. They are normally supplied only to one-room schools at a flat charge of $2 to cover transportation costs. Teachers, school trustees, or other people interested in this service should write the Commission for full particulars.

COMMUNITY LIBRARIES.

These are small collections of from 50 to 150 books, depending on the size and reading interests of the individual community. They include a full range of literature: Modern fiction, both serious and light (mystery, romance, western); all classes of non-fiction; and juvenile books, if desired. Selection of books is made by the librarian in relation to the needs and expressed wishes of the readers in the respective communities.

LOAN CONDITIONS.

All that is required of the local community is that a Library Committee be formed to take proper care of the collection according to a few simple rules. The only cost is that of return freight. Libraries may be exchanged two or three times a year as the Committee may choose. Use of the library must be free.

OPEN SHELF.

Mention should be made here of the Open Shelf Division, from which books are loaned free to individual borrowers by mail. This service is available, in addition to Travelling Library service, to any one in the Province who does not have the advantages of a local public library. Interested readers should apply direct to the Public Library Commission for full particulars. Use of one service does not in any way affect use of the other. The Open Shelf is mentioned here because the serious reader may require a wider range of literature than that offered by the Travelling Library.

Dear Sir,

We have received your letter of 3 March asking about membership in the Legislative Library of New Brunswick. Membership is individual, any resident of this province, upon completion of an application for membership card and the payment of one dollar, is entitled to books, one dollar being the annual membership fee. The reference required is a responsible person such as a member of the legislature, a judge or a clergyman. Many school teachers write up for books, and at present very few children from out of town, although the local school-age membership is considerable.

Two books and a magazine may be taken out at one time. It is necessary that we receive a request, by letter or post card, each time books are wanted. If the books asked for are not in the library or are on loan, we substitute. Usually we have only one copy of a book. To ensure receiving books that are wanted, members send us a list of what they want, from which we choose. We have books of all kinds in the library, biography, travel, history, fiction, handicrafts, mythology, science, etc. Two weeks is the time allowed for Books to out-of-town members, and one week to local members. The date when books are due to be returned to the library is stamped on the slip, inside the cover of each. A post-free address label for the return parcel is sent with the books, so there is no cost to members for postage on books. Our wrapper may be used inside out when returning. A fine of two cents a day (excluding Saturdays and Sundays) is charged on any book returned to the library beyond the due date.

This library is not advertised, but there was an interesting article about it in the Family Herald (February 26 1947) which will doubtless bring it to the attention of more rural residents.

Yours truly,

available book stock of smaller public libraries as well as to serve the

rural and urban, where public library service is not accessible. Requests

far as possible; for example, agriculture, household science, travel,
biography, economics, boys' and girls' books. A case holds from forty to
fifty volumes.

Occasionally requests are made for cases entirely of fiction.

educational purposes.

are being purchased every month, worn-out volumes are being withdrawn,
and much of the collection is always in circulation throughout the
Province.

Cost -- None, except carriage charges. The borrowing community
is asked to pay the charges on arrival; the Department will pay for the
return. A case of books weighs approximately seventy-five pounds. The

though cases may be returned as soon as the books are read, and another
case procured but only one case may be procured at a time.

The Department prefers to lend through an organized association
of some kind. The books must be available without charge to the entire
community and not only to the members of an association, club or church.
Arrangements must be made for a suitable custodian."

The Indian Affairs Branch has very limited funds available to
defray the cost of transportation or loss of such travelling libraries.
Several schools are already using this service and are meeting the small
expenses involved by raising funds by community efforts such as concerts,
bazaars, etc. If such community contributions are not readily available,
then application can be made through the Indian Agent for necessary funds.

After reading the request for contributions I'd like to share with other teachers a few of the practical and original devices I've developed to make my classroom attractive. There is no need to work in a dark, drab schoolroom when a few deft touches will transform it into a cheerful workshop for happy boys and girls.

Window Pictures
One of the cheapest and most beautiful ways of decorating the windows is this: Mixten a bar of Ben Ami with water and rub it gently on the lower pane of a window. After the Ben Ami is dry any pattern you wish may be drawn, such as an Indian village, an Eskimo house, sled and dogs, Easter rabbit, Christmas scene, spring flowers.

Paper Flowers
Speaking of flowers reminds me of the many pots of tulips we made for our window-sills. The children excel in the manufacture of paper flowers, so it was a simple matter to fill some pots with sanddust, plant the tulips and cover the flower pots with tin-foil.

Art Display Forms
The glass doors in my classroom have become display frames for pupils' art work. Construction paper makes a suitable background, for cutting, crayon drawing, or water color illustration of seasonal subjects. The pupils derive satisfaction from their artistic efforts, and the room reflects the gaiety and color behind the familiar glass doors.

Blackboard Stencils and Designs
Blackboards besides affording excellent visual instruction can add warmth and cheer when decorated. The centre blackboard in the front of the room has a stencilled motto done with white show card paint. The class flower, a lily, painted in conventional design completes the picture.

What child doesn't love a circus with its funny-faced clowns? Paint some on the other boards around the room. Put in your clown's hand a square, rhombus, circle, trapezoid etc., and you have a visual aid for mensuration. You've a reminder too of a happy day spent in the big tent the last time the circus came to town.

There are two front boards planned to stimulate interest in the basic skills of reading and arithmetic among the younger pupils. A broad highway of white chalk is drawn across the blackboard. Motor cars and the school bus speed along the road bearing the reading class (children are cut-outs from a catalogue). On the lower part of the blackboard are several cradles ready to receive boys and girls who miss their reading. Nobody wants to leave the jolly crowd in the care to be a baby in a cradle! Then there's the board with the fishing pond. Large yellow cardboard fish swim in blue chalk water. Each fish has a combination of numbers to be added or subtracted. A sign invites all to try their luck.

Magazine Rack
My latest fabrication is what I call a homemade mega size rack and current events chart. Both of these were made out of two yards of blue denim and decorated with the class flower in show card paint. With the help of these new additions I hope to teach the children how to acquire useful information from varied sources.

Some day, I hope, we shall own a small radio and widen our source of information as we listen to the splendid school broadcasts. We shall then be better equipped to instil an appreciation of the finer things of life such as art, music, literature, and good citizenship. These valuable factors in educational growth are frequently not well developed outside the school in this day and age.

Delphine Gertrude Murphy
El Round Indian Bay School,
Newcastle, New Brunswick.
Teaching Techniques

(1) Primary Reading
   I draw a house on the blackboard
   the slinger and bricks consist of
   words already taken in class. The
   pupil that names all
   the words correctly is
   allowed to enter the house
   and he is represented
   by a drawn stick figure.

(2) Another device somewhat
    similar consists of the
    word ladder placed against
    the apple tree. The pupils who
    say words correctly and reach
    the top of the ladder are able to
    take their place on a branch.

(3) Another device is using
    the spiral form drawn
    on the floor with words
    printed in the spaces. The
    pupils hop or step as they
    can say the words. Those not
    able to reach the center, step
    off and let the next pupil
    try. The ones missing words
    start from the beginning
    until they successfully reach
    the center. This may be varied
    by simply counting the errors
    and drilling on them later.

(4) Another drill device for action
    words such as run, hop, walk
clap, bend, sing, write, is to show flash cards and have pupils do actions accordingly.

It may be varied by the teacher doing the action and the pupils pointing out the correct name word from a list on the blackboard.

(5) "A bag of tricks." The teacher has a bag in which have been placed a number of tickets containing a word on each. The pupils each draw out a word and say it in a whisper to the teacher. Those not known by the pupils are put back in the bag. Those pupils having the most tickets are the winners of the game.

(6) "Fishing." The pupil saying the (correct) words correctly takes his place on the bank.

(b) Number work drill

(i) For beginners I like them to sing "One little, two little, three little Indians etc," raising the fingers consecutively as named and vice versa.

(ii) I tap "two" lightly and "four" loudly. They say two and four make six. This can be used extensively for all the fun.
(3) Climbing ladders to tree tops and house tops may be used to drill number facts. The figure representing the pupils usually causes much delightful amusement.

(4) "Fording the river" A number of stepping stones are drawn in a river, on the floor. The pupils cross the river and then return to the original bank by stepping on the stones. When an error is made they have fallen into the water and must "swim" to the bank and try again.

Games

Ross - Grade II

The players have two men each off the man goes into the bowl it counts 9 if it remains near any card it counts the number of points accordingly. The scores are added to see who has highest.
"Guess"

This is very useful in teaching the word "guess." A child sits on a small chair at the front of the room with his back to the class. I point to a child, he comes up and taps the back of the chair. I tell child seated to guess who tapped his chair. He says "I guess Harry." If it were Harry, he says "Your guess is right." This game may be used to teach the expression "It was I," and "It was not I." The child who is seated says "Was it you who knocked on my chair Gloria?" The answer may be "It was I," or "It was not I." This may be used in all grades.
W.T. How I Teach My Pupils

Dr. Glenn Macomber was quoted in the New York Times as saying that the chief purpose of the school was the development of individuals capable of effective participation in our society with benefit to both individual and society. I hope and trust that in my music period each day, I shall be doing that very thing.

Indian children are very musical and can be brought out in many ways by means of this love for, and interest in music. I have found these children shy and backward when asked to speak or read alone. But when asked to sing with their class, these same children give forth with great gusto, enjoying the full few minutes break from other classes.

Our songs are usually simple but with very musical tunes and if we can put in a few actions, so much the better.

It has been said that no great singer ever developed tuberculosis and so we are guarding our health as we unconsciously do deep breathing exercises, and practice breath-control. Pupils also improve their speaking voice - enunciation, and pronunciation and volume. They gain confidence in standing up before an audience and making a real contribution to the enjoyment they derive from the benefits derived.

When I taught that beautiful old favorite Brother James Air (Bask School Song Book) I sang it over first and let my class hum with me. Then they said the first verse "The Lord's my shepherd, I'll not want." In a few minutes they could sing it alone. Then I could let different groups stand up at the front and sing it while the rest listened and learned. Listening is the most important and the children soon can judge the best tone and clearest words. This helps them to sing with greater care when they come up to sing. Next we ask for a volunteer choir who come up and lead the others. These pupils are praised for their posture, appearance, opening mouths, etc., and the others imitate these good examples more readily than they do me. They learn to sing with the mind as well as the voice. They
must use every faculty, if they are to sing with real feeling and beauty. One phrase must be softer another louder. One line is the climax. One word must be expressive or retarded! And so on right to the very last note. And every pupil must give his fullest cooperation, if the song is to be a thing of beauty and a joy forever.

Today I started to teach a song for the musical festival. Even though we may never get to the big city, we can strive for that high standard required and reap the benefits gained thereby. Everybody will be thrilled with the joy of having accomplished such an artistic rendition by the united effort of each individual. This is cooperation in the highest sense.

First, the teacher must know her song perfectly—and understand how the composer wanted it sung. Then when she sings it for her class, they will imitate her and thus learn to sing it as it should be sung, right from the first. The children must listen intently in order to reproduce it in a similar manner. Next they hum the tune to familiarize themselves with it. We then spend a few minutes learning the words of the first verse and then try to fit them in, singing very softly and listening to me. And so, in fifteen minutes, we have completed our first lesson, and have a fair idea of the tune and first verse. We will write out the words during writing period, and repeat the words for choral reading lesson, thus correlating it with other lessons if and when possible. Expression and beauty of tone will come gradually but surely. Every word must be clear and distinct.

If we are fortunate enough to obtain transportation, etc., we shall travel to a big city and see many new sights—visit places of interest (e.g., radio station, flour mill, or Parliament Bldgs) and also enjoy the excitement of a competition with their white friends. They have done something for society and themselves! Who knows but what it might lead to the production of a Marion Anderson or a Paul Robeson here at Cote!
Ottawa, February 27, 1948.

The enclosed photographs may interest you as an unusual study of eager anticipation of the daily ration of cod liver oil.

The Rev. H. F. Dunlop, principal of the Sechelt Indian Residential School conceived the idea of using a plunger oil-can. By placing the long spout well into the recipient's mouth, the cod liver oil is projected back of the tongue where the taste buds do not function.

Judging from the facial expressions of the pupils, the daily dose holds no dread. Two depressions of the plunger give the required amount, eliminating greasy spoons, unsavoury taste, and dribbling.

The uniforms worn by the girl pupils were made by them at school. As they are attractively modern they proved very acceptable, and remedied a contentious situation caused by some girls wearing better and more stylish clothes than their less fortunate companions.

Dear Sir,

We teachers are all aware of the simple art of telling others what to do, but we need each other's ideas. It is only through genuine effort that the bond of sympathy and understanding may be tightened. When in our lonely Indian reserves we like to feel that we are not alone fighting out a great variety of school problems.

Therefore in response to the invitation that was sent in the January Indian School Bulletin for contributions to be published in the same bulletin, I have tried to give a few suggestions, that I hope may be of help to others, on "How I teach my Pupils Art."

At the same time let me express my sincere appreciation and thanks for the help given us in your always so interesting magazine.

Sincerely yours,

Sr. Bernadette Marie.
How I teach Art.

Can and should a teacher in an Indian Day School teach art? When I said that I stepped in the midst of trouble for can art be taught? Art is expressing in a visible form one's own ideas and visions. Can one teach that?

We must first remember that the fundamental purpose of art in the primary and elementary grades is to train the child to see and appreciate the beauty in his environment, to teach him the use of materials to make beautiful things and to enable him to apply art to his daily life as an individual and as a member of the social group.

In any discussion of methods in teaching art, it must be remembered, that there is no pedagogical substitute for clear thinking and imagination on the part of the pupil. Moreover there is nothing to take the place of observation as a background for art. The problem of how these faculties can best be developed and directed is outside the scope of this paper.
It would be using a platitude to say that a child who has been taught to observe well, and to enjoy observation can be taught to draw well, and to enjoy painting his drawings if he is given the proper directions as to the use of the media he wants to work with, and given of course the proper stimulus. One of the major problems of the teacher of art therefore, is concerned firstly with getting the pupils to observe well, and secondly finding the medium which will at once be adequate, adaptable and pleasant in transmitting the pictures in the imagination of the child.

I find that chalk even though it is "messy" does fine work in a very short time, and you know as well as I do that the pupils are always anxious to see the results.

Since most children have a natural desire to express themselves in drawing and making things I never introduce art to my pupils as a school subject nor do I attempt any formal teaching of color, design, perspective, lettering etc., before I get them
Here was the motivation; they all wanted to color. All this encouraged my little artists who thought they had achieved master pieces, although I had done most of the work. Now I hear you exclaim, "What about the so much talked about 'more pupil activity and less teacher activity'?" Yes, I know that, but don't you think it is permitted and I might say necessary that the teacher use much energy and activity in motivating her lessons? Definitely, I hear you say. I'm sure you'll agree with me also when I say that teaching must be a duty to the teacher in order to be a pleasure for her class. She must throw herself wholeheartedly into the task of teaching, you see, be ever on the alert for simpler and more effective methods and be a detective for novel ideas.

Now let us come back to the group in admiration before the scenes on which the girls are still working. Everyone by now wanted a paper and colored chalk, as we were working with chalk.
to like art. The required knowledge of colour facts must be acquired by experimenting on the part of the pupils and not under any circumstances by merely memorizing colour theory. That is why I always try to introduce art as play at recess time! You may find this strange, but try it, when the children cannot go out, and you will see how easy the motivation becomes!

This year I started with a few girls before school time. I simply asked them if they would help me. Think then what pride they took in their work since they really thought that they were "helping". We made a few simple scenes showing sky, horizon line and one point of interest in each picture such as a tree, road, lake or else a little log cabin. One by one as the other pupils arrived at school they crowded around the desk to see!! You should have heard and understood all the cries of admiration!! I myself could not enjoy all the exclamations as most were expressed in their native tongue....."Ah... Dupwe metose moyosin"
since we had no pastels or tempera. Everyone was over enthusiastic about trying his skill. They wanted to draw and color. It was not imposed on them. Remember interest is the keystone! And there I had it! They were all busy even before the school bell chimed, yes, the forty of them. Did the bell need to chime in such circumstances?... All the while I had not said "Art," at all, I simply let the children make things well according to their ability and so! and behold!!! Try it yourself and you'll be surprised to see that you will have your pupils well started toward the place an artist properly should have in a healthy civilization—a member of a building gang.

It follows that projects are desirable but the time element is a real problem, for that reason the children might work in relays, and it might be best to take time for it in lumps rather than to have many short periods... or what do you think?... In these days of hustle and bustle, I
think each teacher must work that out according to her own resources.

One of the most animated projects that grew out of the art class was the drawing of different scenes from our reserve. We cut out a hole 2½ in. by 3½ in. in a postcard, and with that in hand we viewed from the window and the yard scenes that we wished to reproduce. A few pencil strokes on the white sheet indicated the most important lines, then each composition was colorfully illustrated in pastel tints, with the least possible details. We stressed especially the bright colours of the rising and setting sun, since bright colors are of greatest appeal to these children. One little word of advice concerning the use of chalk, if you have no pastels: do not be afraid of making a "mess." It is better to experiment, fail, and from your failure learn, than to set yourself into a safe groove and thereby cease to grow. Whatever you do, do not worry a chalk or pastel painting, do not try to put in
too much too carefully. Chalk, of all mediums is impressionistic. Draw boldly, thoughtfully and simply, and you will produce very satisfying work.

In the project on the reserve, the pupils worked in relays, each had a different scenery to accomplish. Then all the drawings were sized with fixative and assembled in a booklet with the title "Visit our Reserve." The whole was very attractive when finished. Enthusiasm ran high over this project, so much so that most of the pupils came to school much earlier than usual to work on their art, and that I think is marvelous for Indians, who a couple of years ago had to be fetched with a stick every morning. Each one was quite proud of his finished work. This proved to be a very attractive display for the Christmas Concert Exhibition.

The reason why I have started with this project, you may have guessed it! You know just as well as I do that most of the pupils who frequent the Indian Day Schools have not had the chance to
so much outside of nature. Our aim therefore must be to develop their ability to recognize and appreciate beauty wherever it is found for e.g. in the glory of the evening sunset, in the autumn leaves, in the flashing colours of birds or butterflies, in lakes and rivers, in the remote nooks and corners of the woods, and whenever a trip is possible in well-kept parks, streets, and other community enterprises. Last year I was able to take my pupils out for a three day excursion to the city and to a fifteenth anniversary celebration. You have no idea how much good this outing has done towards fostering better social habits and developing the right attitudes and comprehension of the principles which are the basis of good taste and discrimination. A new world was opening up to these pupils and therefore more visions and ideas to be expressed in various media.

These preliminary remarks though should dispel any notion that the method
suggested here attempts to solve all the problems encountered in teaching the subject, nor does it offer a panacea for the many ills which the harassed teacher must endure in her noble work. The simple plan described here has been put to a practical test in the classroom, however, and has been found helpful in teaching the pupils a certain skill in manipulating the various elements that go to make up a picture and in clothing ideas with fitting garb of colour, especially in the elementary grades when the children become more self-critical. At this stage their ability to perform usually has not kept pace with their power of observation; their standard is too high, consequently they are easily discouraged. To overcome this, care should be taken to ensure that the activities selected are kept well within their capacities and interests, and that they have a practical appeal.

There will be many discouraging
days, especially when you have great hopes,
but we must keep our courage shining.
Think for example the shock I had when,
going around the desks giving individual
suggestions, I came upon a purple horse
right in the middle of what had been
a few minutes before a beautiful winter
sunset. You can never tell what is
going to pop out next in those lively
little imaginations!! I wasn't going
to scold Joe, as this might have given
him an inferiority complex attitude
towards art, but to point out his mistake
I simply showed the beautiful sunset to
the class giving a few words of praise,
then asked, "Did you see a purple horse?"
"No" was chorused even from Joe. He
laughed over it and so did we!

Even though Indian children have
great artistic talents, relatively few of them
will become art specialists, because
they will not persevere long enough,
therefore technical excellence should
not be unduly emphasized. The aim
should be to develop, in addition to
creative ability, standards of good taste and appreciation. It should be possible to develop in our Indian pupils an art consciousness which will establish a dislike for carelessness and disorder and a demand for beauty in the environment in which they live from day to day. To this end I think, the fostering of pride in orderly, well-kept school and grounds should be as much a part of school art activities as the development of creative ability and appreciation in the recognized fields of art as painting and sculpture. When such is the case there is greater prospect of carry-over into individual and community life, and those who have visited the reserve know how great is the need of doing something to make the little log shacks and surroundings more attractive in appearance.

Pages and pages could be devoted to enumerating attractive and clever ways of teaching art, but each teacher should be careful to select the one best suited to her class, otherwise the methods will fail to serve their purpose.

An Experience

Of the many problems that teachers have to face, a most important one is possibly how to avoid the MONCTONY which results from a very conscientiously followed-well-planned time table. Day after day, week after week, month after month comes the absolutely same routine. Did not an inspector once remark to the teacher, "Your time-table says—'Arithmetic', how is it that you are teaching 'Health'? Does the breaking of the law set by the time-table bear the same consequence as the breaking of the Divine decalogue? Certainly not. Any plausible excuse will be readily accepted by our worthy visitor; and what a relief for the pupil when an unlooked for subject is offered!

It was the privilege of our students, last fall, to forget for a few days—all about the prescribed programme and to experiment in an unknown field of some really educational value. Our new centre of interest was: "flax growing".

Words came one day, that flax fields, three miles from the Reserve, were to be combined. On October 13th, pupils of Grades 5 to 8 accompanied by their teachers left for the flax fields. The thrill brought by the unusual, the enthusiasm awakened by the prospect of a day spent in the open air, the packing of a lunch which included salted peanuts, sweets, fruits etc., put a new radiance in everyone's face.

The three-mile walk did not weary our young Indian pedestrians. An hour after our departure we had reached the field and discovered the combine near which was a truck. Two men standing in the box held a large canvas which received the precious flaxseed from the powerful machine.

Reading curiosity and eagerness in our demeanour, the kind farmer carefully and patiently explained the ways of cultivating such a valuable crop and what profitable returns he expected from his three fields. He generously distributed handfuls of seeds which we carefully packed. Some pupils examined and gathered stalks, a few small boys jubilantly accepted a ride on the new combine; and after the disposal of our appetizing lunch, off we were, bringing back to school material and new ideas for many days of classwork.

The next morning, a discussion on the precious day's excursion came first on the programme. Looking at the stalks, pods and seeds on every desk, one pupil exclaimed, "What are we going to do with these?" Suggestions poured! "A Booklet about flax!" was nearly the unanimous decision.

The planning of the booklet followed:

1. Research work was proposed in order to discover:
   a) What other countries grew flax.
   b) Of what use were the stalk fibres and the seeds?
   c) Why some countries grew flax for seeds and others for fibres.
   d) What the flower is like.

2. A vocabulary containing a list of all new words for our spelling lessons.

3. Maps indicating the countries and places where flax is grown. (Our fields were to be marked in colour).

4. Climatic conditions favoring the use of fibres for textiles.

5. Reports for the composition class. (A good opportunity was afforded here for the teaching of paragraphing). Having read about the flowering of the flax, one pupil's composition was about an imaginary trip to the same fields in the spring. A drawing of the beautiful blue flower artistically illumined the booklet.

6. Art. The use of the flax flower as a motif in a border design. A boy more interested in machinery than in the flower drew a combine, truck and all.

7. Home Economics and Home Medicine. Difference between cotton and linen as to texture, durability and laundering qualities. Different uses of both cotton and linen.

Linseed cough medicine.
Grandmother's linseed poultice.
VI. Bibliographies:
The Book of Knowledge
The clothes We Wear—Carpenter.
Our Little Neighbors at Work—Carpenter.
The Standard Reference Books
Fundamentals of Home Economics—Jensen, Jensen, Ziller.
Elementary Home Economics—M.Lockwood's Mathews, B.S.

IX. Arithmetic: Here are some of our problems, many of them suggested by the pupils:

1. If we walked \( \frac{1}{2} \) mile in 10 minutes, how long did it take us to walk 2 miles? 3 miles? 6 miles?

2. We left at 1.10 P.M. and were back at 4.45 P.M. How long were we away?

3. Mr. H.... has three fields of flax, in all 60 acres. One field contains 25 acres, another 7 acres. How many acres are there in the third field.

4. How many square rods in a field of 7 acres?

5. Mr. H....'s crop was of 1,200 bushels. How many bushels an acre did his fields yield?

6. If flaxseed sells at $5.00 a bushel, how much will Mr. H... receive for his full crop? For \( \frac{1}{2} \) of it? For \( \frac{3}{4} \) of it?

7. If Mr. H... pays $6.00 an acre for the use of the combine. How much will he have to pay?

8. How much will he have left after paying for the use of the combine?

9. He gave his son 10% of his money. How much did Harold receive?

10. He put 25% of his money in the bank. How much was this? What percent did he have left for his winter expenses? How much money was this?

N.B. The difficulties in solving the problems were few; pupils knew what they were doing. What an improvement on the problems in our Arithmetics texts dealing with so many subjects outside of the Indian sphere of knowledge.

I might say here that a group of teachers from three different schools met for a few weeks last summer to discuss problems pertaining to our particular field of work. We agreed that special efforts should be made this year to give our pupils practical arithmetic problems dealing mostly with their known world and possible experiences. Next summer, the same teachers will review these, a judicious choice will be made and a compilation of the result given to each teacher. We hope that in a near future some other experienced teachers will be inspired to prepare some branch of work that will especially appeal to the Indian children.

I end the digression here to give a general outlook of the result of our project on flax: Happiness in work, sustained interest, stimulation in neatness, first hand acquaintance with some practical knowledge, and subjects of clean conversation afforded during recreations.

The real test of this pleasurable achievement is best exemplified when visitors come to our classrooms. No shyness on the part of the children; with full confidence they explain the different steps of their project; it is theirs and they know it.

A young school teacher.

(My name— not for publicity—is —Sister Rose Helen,...)

Adult education is desirable on Reserves and in Residential Schools for both Indian and white.

On the reservations, it is desirable that new methods of farming be illustrated and demonstrated by capable instructors. How to use bulletins and how to interpret illustrations therein, would help the adult on to self-education.

A study of the soil, qualities, contents and fertilizers needed, would be helpful and encouraging.

Part of the residential school building should be made available for the instruction of parents in the study of child care, diets, sewing and agriculture. The parents should be permitted to enjoy the facilities of the school that might enable them to improve their reading abilities to comprehend.
Films and slides should be used frequently to develop discriminating taste and to improve knowledge of skills and interests.

Cooperation with provincial boards - education, agriculture, health and highways would be a step in the right direction towards educating the Indian to fit into the Canadian economy as a contributing member with a great purpose.

Our course of study highly recommends enterprises as an incentive to child education.

In our room we selected "The Red River Settlement" for one of our enterprises. It was originally planned for grade six but may be used also for grade five as the two grades are correlated.

At the time that we were studying about the Fur Traders at the Hudson's Bay Posts, the pupils were keenly interested in the problems of the early settlers. The class received with enthusiasm the proposal that we build our enterprise around the Red River Settlement.

In a social study period we listed the names of the various things we ought to construct and find out about. Groups for getting on with the work were selected.

The class chose the best artists to draw such pictures as Lord Selkirk, the Highlanders arriving at York Factory, Beat building during the winter and buffalo round-up of Indians and Metis (people of Red River at the time). Others made maps, while still others helped with the printing, cutting and oil painting.

Library periods were spent on reading books about Lord Selkirk and his settlements. Some of the following books proved very helpful: Pages From Canada's Story by D.J.Dickie; The Story Of Our People by Patterson; Social Studies For Canadians by Gernish & Dewdney; Silver Chief in Highroads To Reading, Book VI; and the Encyclopedia and World Books were also referred to quite frequently.

Our enterprise then culminated in a movie film. For this we got a good-size cardboard box about 20" by 12". Holes were made on the two sides of the box, about ten inches apart in which the rollers were inserted. The inside of
the box and the rollers were then painted nile green (oil paint) and the outside was painted red, trimmed with green.

By this time our pictures, maps, printing, etc., were completed, so they were arranged in their proper sequence on a long strip of white wrapping paper, eleven inches wide. This served as a film which was securely glued to the rollers.

For the production of the film, two pupils operated the machine, while a third girl, hidden in the audience, narrated the story of the event represented by the pictures.

I consider the class received several educational benefits (1) A practical training in obtaining information regarding a specific subject. (2) Pupils learned to work with others and shoulder responsibility until the project was completed. (3) Pupils learned to look up information and to use material at hand, to make reasonable decisions. (4) In fine, it made school and learning seem more worthwhile to them.

Sister Elizabeth Herauf, S.C.M.

THE BASIC PROBLEMS OF MODERN CLASSROOM MANAGEMENT
ARE CONCERNED WITH THE DIFFERING
NEEDS, INTERESTS, AND CAPACITIES
OF PUPILS AS INDIVIDUALS

"Like a Military Campaign, an effective teaching program
is, to a large extent, a matter of good classroom management.
Given the same men and material, one general might gain a
given objective with minimum losses, where another general
would fail simply because the first was a good tactician and
the second was not." (1) Similarly, "the ideal teacher
adapts herself to each pupil, studies his individuality, learns
his strong and his weak points; thus, like a successful general,
she gains entrance into the fortress of the pupil's inner-self--
not that she may take possession of that fortress, but rather
carefully guard it against the raging assaults of ignorance
and vice." (2)

However, the teacher who would gain great victories as
those of a world wide known Eisenhower or of a far-seeing
McArthur, must not "regiment" her pupils by enforcing military
discipline. The teacher's field of action does not call for
martial law. "If there is to be real pupil growth in the
ability to act in a responsible manner, the type of order
dictated by a particular social situation must grow out of a
desire within the pupil, not be continually imposed from above."(3)

(1) Ruch, Floyd L., "New Edition Psychology and Life" p.336
Schott Foresman and Co., Chicago, 1941
(2) Catholic School Journal, 1923 p.183
(3) Macomber, F. G., "Guiding Child Development in the
Elementary School", American Book Co., 1941 p.237

The classroom is the stage where the pupil's individual character is brought out by the aid of the teacher's leading qualities, and the school time makes the daily performance of classwork activities a dress rehearsal. According to the teacher's skill to explore the hidden talents of each pupil through a careful study of his likes and dislikes, his moods, his temperament, his natural abilities, his interest, his whole personality, will she be better fitted to choose her cast and assign the various parts best suited to the pupils for the enactment of the real play on the screen of after-school life. There, "the basic problems of modern classroom management are concerned with the differing need, interests, and capacities of pupils as individuals".

BOTANY IN THE CLASSROOM

The classroom may be compared to a beautiful garden where a rich and colorful assortment of flowers are found. The teacher who is the gardener studies the needs of every species of flowers therein. These needs are made manifest according to the nature of each. The boisterous "Jack-in-the-Pulpit" shouts his need for activity; the shy "Violet" confidently whispers her need of sympathetic understanding; the overgrown "Hollyhock" longs for a kind encouraging word; the backward "Brown-eyed Susan" feels the need of a lifting hand; the snow-white "Lily" thirsts for a bit of kindness and affection; the talkative "Tulips" may tell their needs for a better home environment, while the laughing "Daffodil" just bubbling over with
energy needs her world of fanciful, creative imagination. While these and many more present a variety of individual needs which constantly call for patience and untiring zeal on the part of the wide-awake teacher, yet it remains true that love and devotedness should fill the needs of all. If these flowers are to grow and sway happily they must be exposed to the rays of cheerfulness and to the light of sunny dispositions. Such a garden of smiling faces will not fail to attract the all-loving and divine eyes of Him Who is ever mindful of their intellectual, moral and physical needs and whose delight it is to swell with the children of men.

FAIRYLAND ADVENTURES

Interest is the magic wand that changes "work" into pleasure. The teacher who is skillful in arousing the interest of her pupils possesses the fairy-like gift of changing the monotonous minutes of daily routine into as many little busy-bees that will gather the sweet nectar of contentment from each of her frolicking "Flowers". In this busy atmosphere of awakened interest, the "tic toc" of the clock is hushed by the humming of the bees and the hours at school quickly tip-toe away leaving no time for troublesome "idleness" to interfere with Time's hurried pace.

When the fire of interest kindles the child's enthusiasm the various subjects of the curriculum are viewed with greater anticipation and the hard lessons are learnt the easier way. "The teacher uses the pupil's instinctive interests as a basis to build ideal interests of life-time value upon them; effort will naturally be required to span the intervening space
but herein lies its importance in the formation of character which will enable them to meet the challenging situations as they come." (4) Christ, the divine Model of Teachers seized every opportunity to link the earthly interests of His listeners to those of His Heavenly Father. The Church also throughout the liturgical year continues her divinely-appointed missions to teach. This she does by the use of symbolical colors and vestments, by the interpretation of religious feelings through her sacred chant, by her various rites and ceremonies and above all by the dramatization of her mysteries, thus making her teaching more effective by rendering it more interesting to the faithful. Again Saint Paul used athletic terms in his preaching and his words created new interests towards the championship of a "marathon" on the racetrack to Eternity. Happy is the teacher blessed with a sense of humor who can make use of a mischievous boy's collection of prize-winning trouble makers: a sling shot, a horse-shoe magnet, an old alarm clock just aching to creat "alarm" a few yards of snaring wire, or even perhaps a live lizard especially valuable because it is "alive", all these may give rise to an impromptu lesson on nature study or science that will change their owner's intended nature of fun-making into a practical demonstration of newly discovered interests. A boy's pocketful of trinkets is the shortest path that the teacher may take to arrive at his heart.

(4) Catholic School Journal Nov. 1927 p. 256
KNOWLEDGE IN A TEST TUBE

A chemist must have a knowledge of the potential energies stored in each constituent element before he can do any experiments. Otherwise, he is likely to see his analysis, if not his life, blow up in a test tube. In the classroom "laboratory", the teacher too must be well aware of the child's potential or manifest capacities as an individual before she can decide what special apparatus or device is best suited for the expected reaction. In the case of the mentally slow pupil, the teacher will carefully choose an active compound that will bring out the child's capacities for manual work or any other type of work in which he naturally excels. The bright, dynamic personality may need a chemical agent to prevent or retard an overactive reaction, but at the same time his atomic nature must not be so checked as to destroy his capacities for effective progress in learning. The teacher cannot test the capacities of each pupil through the process of electrolysis, nor can she measure them by the yardstick. Talents, aptitudes, and abilities vary too greatly to be detected on a common barometer system. The art of teaching demands more than generalized formulas in which children are expected to react in the same manner, but rather does it call for a close observation of the child's natural resourcefulness and individual capacity to adjust himself to his work. The humble teacher bent lovingly over the child's desk is not always conscious of the importance of her task, yet it
may be that through her watchful care to develop his potential capacities, she may be the unknown but non the less great generator of noble deeds. Here is the delicate task of testing the child's mind, not with the "acid" of sour dispositions nor with a "temper" at a boiling point, but rather with a mixture of love and devotedness. The whole experiment must be based upon the knowledge of the pupil's capabilities and upon her ardent desires to lend him a helping hand in the hard climb towards the heights to success. In the analysis of the children's differing capacities, successful classroom management can best be worked on the "electron theory" where the teacher's heart becomes a powerful battery that can bring to action both the "negatively" and "positively charged" natures, thus making their mind shine with a new glow in the "light" of their own personal efforts.

BEAUTY ON CANVAS

When the artist has given the last stroke of the brush, and has added the final touch to his masterpiece, he steps back at a distance to catch a glimpse of the restful harmony in the choice of his colors, then he stares at the beautiful image enshrined in his own thought-conceiving, he admires and smiles, but the figure refuses to nod any approval of satisfaction. Then, in a deep sigh, he fully realizes the limits of his creative ability. The teacher too blends colors. With great care, she detects every shade of difference in the character of her pupils. Day after day she strives to repro-
duce in beauty, the traits of each individual. It may be, that while she is toiling in the classroom, she fails to notice the effects of her work. Perhaps the strokes of her strong determination to bring out the child's individuality, are greatly apparent. Yet when years have slipped by and she looks back into the past, does she appreciate her artistic and lasting work. Before her stands the masterpieces of her high ideals and, as she smiles with admiration, thousands of other smiles come to greet her, for hers is the privilege of working on hearts and minds which renders her life sublime and her task immortal.

I tap with fingers 4 times while pupils count the taps. I ask a pupil to come to the front of the room and pick up 4 pieces of chalk. I give the pupils 16 shoe pegs each. I demonstrate on the blackboard how they are to arrange the pegs. Firstly, the 16 pegs are arranged in groups of four thus:

Next, I have them arranged thus:

Next time thus, and lastly

The next time the pupils show all the arrangements with the 16 pegs.

I next show this arrangement on the blackboard and place the number 4 underneath.

The pupils draw these arrangements on their papers.
They also use blocks, plasticine, boxes, lids and any other suitable objects to make these formations. They make the figure 4 with sticks and plasticine.

Finger Painting.

The paper is soaked in warm water about one minute, then placed on an oilcloth covered table. The child, using one hand with sleeve above the elbow spreads over the surface about one tablespoonful of paste, thinned out till it pours like cream. Cold water paste powder and water can be used instead of the more expensive paste. About one tablespoonful of show card colour is added and worked in till the paper has an even colour. More or less show card colour can be used, depending on the colour desired. If orange is required, red and yellow may be used to make it. Now it is ready for drawing. Children love to make their own picture and tell what it means. Let drawings dry over night on flat newspaper. Those who like it best will want to use both hands to make a more intricate design.

This exercise lends itself well to a Composition Lesson—in describing the pictures.

Murals.

This is a project in Art which I have used throughout my teaching career with much success and am finding it particularly useful with the Indian children.

I have large sheets 3' x 2' of kraft paper tacked on each wall at a height the children can all reach with ease. I try to keep four at different stages of completion at all times. The children choose the topics for these and do all the work on them.

We make one for each topic in Social Studies, Health and Science and correlate it with sand table work. A few of the Murals we have completed in the two month period I have been teaching Indian children are China, Eskimo Land, Lumbering in Ontario, Farming in Ontario, Healthful Foods, Winter, Holland, Our Health House and Stores. The new ones on which we are now working are Mail, Animals and Travel.

The Murals are done in different mediums -- again the children's choice. We have used only chalk, crayon and pastels so far but intend to use charcoal and show-card paints later on. These enhance the appearance of our classroom considerably, for as each new one is completed it is hung above the blackboard and is a constant reminder to the children of the work they have taken. This is much more interesting than reviewing notes.

I find this enterprise particularly useful, in that it is a continual stimulant to the child who might grow a little weary of the daily routine of school as there is always a new Mural he may enjoy. The children do all of the research work for these pictures. I find the dullest child delving through the library looking for pictures suitable to the topic at hand, for suggestions or ideas. This, in itself, shows the interest aroused.

This project is excellent in training the children to cooperate. They have found out the results they get by cooperation. Also it is a splendid review for the subject taught.

An amusing incident the other day - the children had just put up a new sheet of kraft paper and they were deciding on a topic. Finally one boy came to me, quite reluctantly, and said "Mrs. McCracken, Preston wants to know if we may do one on Cowboys but I don't think we can, can we?" I smiled but of course assured him that the Cowboy topic was not Exactly pertaining to our school work. However, I promised as a reward for their good work, that later on in the year - only to show their artistic ability - I should let them do one on Cowboys and Ranching if they wished.

This project...........
This project is wonderful for improving the artistic ability of the children. I find some are better in scenery; others are better in drawing figures and so on. In this project they learn all of these things by observing others at work and helping in the operation. Mural work discourages minute drawing. It teaches the children to take full swinging strokes, avoiding unnecessary details. By working together the poorest artists in the class do not become discouraged with their efforts for a better 'artist' is always at hand to assist. In this way all the children acquire more self-confidence with a minimum of direction.

Mrs. T. H. McCracken,
