MR. BOY

Proposals for grades of Civil Servants to be employed in the Welfare and Training Service of the Indian Affairs Branch.

Herewith additional facts as required by the Minister's office regarding the above mentioned subject.

My recommendations fall under two main headings:

1. That teachers of Indian day schools be given the right to become permanent civil servants, contributors to the Consolidated Revenue Fund and entitled to annual superannuation allowances under the "Civil Service Superannuation Act".

2. That grades of teachers and salary scales for these grades be established.

My reasons for making these proposals have been set out in my memorandum of November 25, 1946.

Insofar as my recommendation re. superannuation is concerned, I present further information herewith.

Appendix A - Permanent and Temporary Teachers.

Insofar as my recommendation re. salary scales is concerned, I present further facts herewith.

......... Appendix B
Appendix B - Payment of Teachers on a 12 Month Basis

Appendix C - Classification of Teachers of 8 Provinces according to Annual Salary.

Appendix D - Basic Salary Schedules for the Province of British Columbia.

Key Salary is that of Grade II Day Teacher.

By far the largest number of our teachers will fall into the category "Teacher, Day School, Grade II", or teachers holding Second Class Teacher's Certificates. Therefore, I have made this the key salary for the purpose of establishing a scale. I have tried to make the difference in salary between Grade II and Grade III teachers such that those in the lower category will endeavour to improve their certificates to "First Class" by attending summer courses.

We will have very few teachers in the Grade IV category. (There are only two such teachers at the present time).

For the Welfare Teachers, I have included an additional amount to provide an inducement for them to remain on these isolated Indian reservations for twelve months in the year, rather than the usual ten months.

How Amount of Key Salary Was Selected

I would point out the following considerations which led me to adopt the sum of $1,200 as the key salary for Grade II teachers:

(a) It will enable us to compete satisfactorily with the teacher's salaries in provincial schools, (see Appendices C and D).

In Saskatchewan, the minimum teacher's salary required by legislation is $1,200; in B.C. it is $1,150. In other provinces it is being similarly increased. Therefore, if the proposed scale is adopted, I feel that we will be...
able to offer teachers salaries comparable to those received in provincial schools.

(b) It is in accord with the recommendations of the Survey Committee of the Canadian and Newfoundland Education Association.

Miscellaneous

I would further recommend that:

Any person holding a teachers license from the Council of Public Instruction is eligible to teach in any public school and the individual school boards have the decision as to whether a lay or a member of a religious order is to be engaged.

I regret that I cannot send you a copy of the Nova Scotia Teachers Pension Act as the Act is at present out of print. Briefly, our teachers pensions are based on the teachers salaries, but on their provincial aid, which is paid to them direct by the Department of Education. Sixteen per cent of the provincial aid is deducted each year and placed in the Pension Fund, and on retirement each teacher is entitled to pension equal to three times the provincial aid they received at the time of retirement. Pensions for fully qualified teachers vary from $600 to $1020 per year according to the class of license held.

Very truly yours,

H.P. Moffatt,
Asst. Supt. of Education.

Teacher, Indian School

Teacher, Indian School, Grade I $1000-1120.

Teacher, Indian School, Grade III $1260-1980.
Teacher, Indian School, Grade IV $1500-2220.

Classification Regulations.

1. Teacher, Indian School, Grade I.

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold certificates from a recognized Normal or Teachers' Training School. (b) Salary raises to $1060. and $1120. will be given for satisfactory service in the first three years only as shown on the salary scale.

2. Teacher, Indian School, Grade II.

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold a Second Class Teachers Certificate (or equivalent requiring High School Junior Matriculation plus teacher training at a recognized school).

(b) Salary raises for satisfactory service will be given annually for the first seven years only as shown on the salary scale.

(c) No teacher shall be eligible for the increments provided in the fourth or seventh years of service according to the scale attached hereto, unless such teacher has at some time in the preceding three year period respectively, completed one professional or academic session at a Provincial or University Summer School for teachers, or an equivalent course recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch.

3. Teacher, Indian School, Grade III.

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold a First Class Teachers Certificate (or equivalent requiring High School Senior Matriculation/First Year University) plus teacher training at a recognized school. Specialist teachers with First Class Certificates in Industrial Arts, Household Science, Agriculture or other specialist field will also be classified in this category.
(b) Salary raises for satisfactory services will be given annually for the first ten years; thereafter at the end of the 15th and 20th years of experience.

(c) No teacher shall be eligible for the increments provided in the 4th, 7th, 10th, 14th and 19th years of service according to the scale attached hereto, unless such teacher has at some time in the preceding three or five year period respectively, completed one professional or academic session at a Provincial or University Summer School for teachers, or an equivalent course recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch.

4. Teacher, Indian School, Grade IV.

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold a High School Teacher's Certificate (or equivalent requiring a University degree plus teacher training). Specialist teachers with High School Certificates in Industrial Arts, Household Science, Agriculture, or other specialist field will also be classified in this category. It will be further required that 50% of such teacher's teaching time be spent in Grade IX and upwards.

(b) Same as for Teacher, Grade III.

(c) Same as for Teacher, Grade III.

TEACHER, WELFARE.

1. Teacher, Welfare, Grade 1 $1200-1320.
2. Teacher, Welfare, Grade 2 $1260-1740.
3. Teacher, Welfare, Grade 3 $1500-2220.
4. Teacher, Welfare, Grade 4 $1740-2460.

CLASSIFICATION REGULATIONS.

(a) These regulations shall be the same as for Teacher, Indian School. Normally these will be teachers of day schools situated on isolated reservations.

(b) These teachers can qualify for the salary increments requiring summer school courses by taking correspondence courses from Provincial Departments of Education, Universities or other schools recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch.

(c) These teachers will remain on the reservations during the usual summer holiday period. They will be given the normal Civil Service holidays totalling eighteen days throughout the school year.

Dear Mr. Smith:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of file T. 322076 B., dated January 25, addressed to the Deputy Minister.

The points which you have raised concerning the recommendation from the Honorable the Minister of Mines and Resources, requesting approval of new classes and salary scales for Teachers, Indian schools, are dealt with below.

(a) Proposed Salary Scales

At the present time there is no salary scale for teachers employed as temporary civil servants in the Indian day schools conducted by the Indian Affairs Branch of this Department. An attempt has been made to pay the salary rates of the province in which the school is located. This has not always been possible, due to the limited funds available. Hence the quality of the teaching in our Indian day schools has been steadily deteriorating as we have not been attracting the better type of teachers with the salaries offered.

(b) Number of Employees Affected

At the present time there are 139 teachers employed in our Indian day schools.

(c) As the proposed salary scale provides for pay increases based upon qualifications and experience, it is
very difficult to gauge the cost of this plan, so much
depends on the type of teacher that we will be able to
attract by it. However, a rough estimate of the
anticipated increase in annual expenditure would be
$150,000. This might rise eventually to $200,000 as
teachers qualify for increases.

Yours sincerely,

G. W. Jackson,
For Deputy Minister.

S. Amalie, Esq.,
For Secretary,
Treasury Board,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
AIRMAL

Ottawa, December 30, 1946.

Dear Doctor Moore:

This request is a little out of the usual letter which I write to you. However, we have run into a small problem concerning the admission of religious Orders into the Civil Service as would be necessary if our day school teachers are to be eligible for superannuation.

I would very much like to know how this problem is met in the province of Manitoba. Are the Sisters at St. Boniface eligible for superannuation under your Teachers' Retirement Fund Act (or whatever the title given to the Act in your province is)?

I would appreciate it if you could send to me copies of the following:

(1) your Teachers' Superannuation Act,

(2) your School Attendance Act.

I know you will understand why I have written to you rather than to the Deputy Minister, as I feel that you are fully aware of my proposals for providing superannuation for our Indian day school teachers.

Very sincerely yours,

Bernard J. Henry,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dr. Andrew Moore, Ph.D.,
Inspector of Secondary Schools,
187 Queenston Street,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

PROPOSALS FOR GRADES OF CIVIL SERVANTS TO BE EMPLOYED IN THE WELFARE AND TRAINING SERVICE OF THE INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES

Teacher, Indian School

Teacher, Indian School, Grade I $1000-1120.
Teacher, Indian School, Grade II 1200-1360.
Teacher, Indian School, Grade III 1260-1380.

Classification Regulations.

1. Teacher, Indian School, Grade I.

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold certificates from a recognized Normal or Teachers' Training School. After 1 September, 1947, it will be the policy of the Department to employ only teachers who hold recognized teaching certificates. Any non-certificated teachers employed prior to that date can be retained in the service but no further non-certificated teachers will be employed except in the event of an emergency. If this is necessary such teachers will fall into this category.

(b) Salary raises to $1060 and $1120 will be given for satisfactory service in the first three years only as shown on the salary scale.

2. Teacher, Indian School, Grade II.

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold a Second Class Teacher's Certificate (or equivalent requiring High School Junior Matriculation plus teacher training at a recognized school).

(b) Salary raises for satisfactory service will be given annually for the first seven years only as shown on the salary scale.

(c) No teacher shall be eligible for the increments provided in the fourth or seventh years of service according to the scale attached hereto, unless such teacher has at some time in the preceding three year period respectively, completed one professional or academic session at a Provincial or University Summer School for teachers, or an equivalent course recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch.

3. Teacher, Indian School, Grade III.

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold a First Class Teacher's Certificate (or equivalent requiring High School Senior Matriculation or First Year University) plus teacher training at a recognized school. Specialist teachers with First Class Certificates in Industrial Arts, Household Science, Agriculture or other specialist field will also be classified in this category.
(b) Salary raises for satisfactory services will be given annually for the first ten years; thereafter at the end of the 14th and 19th years of experience.

(c) No teacher shall be eligible for the increments provided in the 4th, 7th, 10th, 14th and 19th years of service according to the scale attached hereto, unless such teacher has at some time in the preceding three or five year period respectively, completed one professional or academic session at a Provincial or University Summer School for teachers, or an equivalent course recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch.

4. Teacher, Indian School, Grade IV

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold a High School Teacher's Certificate (or equivalent requiring a University degree plus teacher training). Specialist teachers with High School Certificates in Industrial Arts, Household Science, Agriculture, or other specialist fields will also be classified in this category. It will be further required that 50% of such teacher's teaching time be spent in Grade IX and upwards.

(b) Same as for Teacher, Grade III.

(c) Same as for Teacher, Grade III.

TEACHER, INDIAN WELFARE

1. Teacher, Indian welfare, Grade 1 $1200-1320.
2. Teacher, Indian welfare, Grade 2 $1380-1470.
3. Teacher, Indian welfare, Grade 3 $1500-2250.
4. Teacher, Indian welfare, Grade 4 $1740-2460.

CLASSIFICATION REGULATIONS

(a) These regulations shall be the same as for Teacher, Indian School. Normally these will be teachers of day schools situated on isolated reservations.

(b) These teachers can qualify for the salary increases requiring summer school courses by taking correspondence courses from Provincial Departments of Education, Universities or other schools recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch.

(c) These teachers will remain on the reservations during the usual summer holiday period. They will be given the normal Civil Service holidays totaling eighteen days throughout the school year.

(d) These teachers will, in addition to their normal teaching duties, carry out social and welfare work; assist in the administration of family allowances, the dispensing of medicines and work towards the general welfare and advancement of the Indian people as required by the Indian Affairs Branch.
(c) These teachers may be granted a leave of seven weeks once every three years to enable them to attend a course in social welfare, sociology, child psychology or allied professional field at a Canadian or American University or school recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch.

Interview with Personnel Official,
Department of National Health and Welfare.

Re: Teachers' Superannuation

Order-in-Council No. P.C. 2/2582 of December 16, 1922, grants power to the Superintendent of Indian Affairs to appoint nurses to hospitals and nursing stations located on Indian reservations. In 1924, this privilege was extended to the appointment of ward aids and hospital attendants of various types. In 1946 this privilege was extended to the Department of National Health and Welfare and it was specified that these positions would be totally exempt from the Civil Service Commission. The reason advanced for this exemption was that rotational service was required of their hospital personnel; they were often moved from one hospital to another and also from one province to another and it was desired that this should be done with great flexibility. It was felt therefore that they should be exempt from the Civil Service Commission.

Special reference should be made to P.C. 38/1731 of March 14, 1945, which specifically states that five years' temporary service when excluded from Civil Service Commission regulations, entitles application to Treasury Board for superannuation. (This was amended by P.C. 221/3183 of July 27, 1946.

Mr. Hazelton also described the following method of detailing specific numbers for teaching positions:
(a) HW denoting Health and Welfare,

(b) IM denoting Indian Medical,

(c) starting with P.E.I. and working towards B.C.
by denoting the province numbers 1 to 9.
No. 10 denotes Northwest Territories.

(d) Numbers start at 6,000 and go upwards.

Therefore a nurse at a hospital in the Northwest Territories would have her position denoted as follows:

HW - IM 10-6000

Certificates:

The Normal School Course of Study for women is divided into three sections: Elementary, Complimentary and Superior.

The Course is arranged in such a manner so that the pupils generally may obtain an elementary certificate, (that is a primary elementary school) at the termination of the second year and the complimentary certificate (for primary elementary schools) at the termination of the third year. The superior certificate is awarded as a result of studies for four years in the normal schools for girls with mention (general course) or (domestic science course) as the case may be.

Elementary Certificate Course:

The preliminary subjects of the course of study:
Practical Pedagogy, History of Pedagogy, Liturgy, Elements of Philosophy, Bible Study and Church History, General History, French Grammar, French Dictation, French Reading, Literature, Study of French Authors, Memory, History of Literature (French and Canadian), Arithmetic, Algebra, Politeness, Hygiene, Singing, Writing, Agriculture, Natural Science, Domestic Science, English Reading, English Translation, English Grammar, Spelling, History of Art, Physical Training, Mental Arithmetic.

Complimentary Certificate Course:

Practical Pedagogy, History of Pedagogy,
Philosophy, French Grammar, French Dictation, Literature, French Authors, Memory, History of Literature, Geography, General History, History of Canada, Singing, Physics, Domestic Science, Agriculture, English Grammar, Spelling, Translation, Physical Training, Art.

Superior Certificate Course:

Practical Pedagogy, Pedagogy Theoretical, History of Pedagogy, Liturgy, History of Canada, General History, French Dictation, Vocabulary, Literature, History of Literature, Study of French Authors, Algebra, Elements of Public and Private Rights, Geology and Cosmology, Chemistry, Hygiene and Agriculture, Domestic Science, English Grammar, Spelling, English Composition, English Conversation, English Authors, History of Art.

Final Examinations:

The final examination takes place in two annual sections determined by the Superintendent of Public Instruction: The first at the end of the scholastic year, in June, constitutes the regular session. The students who were successful at this test may present themselves for the Departmental examination, usually in June.

The subjects of the final examinations are:

Elementary Certificates:

Pedagogy (Theory) Liturgy, French Composition, Grammatical Analysis, History of Canada, Geography, English Composition, Arithmetic, Drawing.

Complimentary Certificates:

Physical Pedagogy, Liturgy, French Composition, English Composition, English Conversation, Algebra, Drawing.

Superior Certificates:

Psychology applied to Education, Apologetics, French Composition, English Composition, Philosophy, Geometry.
Note: To be admitted to the first year of the Normal School, a pupil must have a certificate of study for the ninth grade of the primary elementary school. To be admitted to the second year a pupil should have completed his tenth year. To be admitted to the third year (complimentary course) a pupil should have a certificate for the eleventh year of the primary superior school. To be admitted to the superior certificate a pupil must possess the complimentary certificate from the normal school.

CLASS FOR MEN:

To be admitted to the Normal School for men a student must have his eleventh year of the primary school. The complimentary certificate is obtained with two years of normal training. The student who has obtained his complimentary certificate is allowed to teach up to the ninth year inclusive of the primary course.

These pupils who have obtained their complimentary certificate may be admitted for examination and finally to the class for the superior certificate. One year course is required.

Pupils who have obtained a Bachelor's Degree are admitted directly to the second year normal training. They may obtain the complimentary certificate with one year's study and a superior certificate at the termination of two year's study.

Students who have obtained the superior certificate are eligible to teach in the superior primary course.

With the exception of a few subjects the courses prescribed are very similar to those prescribed for women.

I have to refer to Mr. Neary's letter of May 21st in connection with the new salary schedule for teachers in Indian day schools and in particular the question of an adjustment in the salaries of teachers for whom the Department provides fuel and accommodation, or otherwise an allowance to teachers for whom the Department does not provide such facilities.

Mr. Coleman's letter of May 10th was prepared by School Inspector Davey and was perhaps not sufficiently detailed. The extent of accommodation provided for Indian day school teachers in this Province varies from nothing as in the case of the Nanaimo Indian day school to comfortably furnished quarters as provided at the Bella Bella Indian day school and elsewhere. It is my view that should the Department not take into consideration these facilities in establishing teachers' salaries the schools where such facilities are provided will most certainly secure the best teachers whereas the others will very likely remain closed at least until such time as teachers become more plentiful. I am of the opinion that all the Indian day schools in this Province should be reviewed with the object of placing a valuation on the accommodation and fuel provided for the teachers and with this in mind I have given careful consideration to the matter and placed an approximate valuation on the facilities provided for the teachers at each school, taking into consideration the location of the school, the actual accommodation and furnishings provided and the cost of fuel purchased each year by the Department specifically for the teacher's residence, on the basis of which it would appear that the average value of these facilities would be $25.00 per month.
It is felt that the importance of this matter warrants careful consideration by the Department with a view to arriving at a reasonable average value of the facilities provided, the teachers at schools where no accommodation, fuel, etc., is provided at the Department's expense to be given a cash allowance in lieu thereof.

If necessary additional information can be provided if the Department concurs in my views.

Teachers' Salary Schedule

Reference your C-11-2 of June 15 -

At the time the salary schedule was being prepared, several proposals were made as to the way in which the salaries of teachers could be adjusted so as to equalize the varying standards of accommodation provided in our day schools. Suggestions were also made that the relative isolation of the schools should be shown in varying salaries.

However, upon advice from senior Treasury officials, it was decided to prepare the salary schedule in its initial stage in a very simple form. Therefore, only two items were taken into effect in establishing the salaries.

As you know by now, these two factors are:

(a) Teaching certificate held,
(b) Teaching experience.

We were also able to work in the factor of continued professional improvement by allowing for salary increases at certain periods only upon completion of summer school courses.

The point made by Treasury officials was that a simple schedule would have a much better opportunity of passing the Treasury Board than a complicated and involved one. It was recommended that we establish a simple schedule and then
amend it as conditions demanded. It is our intention in future to make provision for amendments to our schedule to provide for such factors as mentioned in your letter of above date. In the meantime you will be very interested in the attached isolation bonus score sheet which is used by the Provincial Department of Education in the Province of Alberta. The various schools are scored as objectively as possible in accordance with the scale attached and then rated as follows:

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of June 23rd in connection with the Teachers' Salary Schedule, although "an isolation bonus" is desirable in British Columbia, I consider it equally important that a bonus be provided for teachers for whom no accommodation or inferior accommodation is provided. I have discussed this matter at some length with District School Inspector Davey who has prepared the attached memorandum. You will note his suggestion that the bonus be divided into two sections, one for isolation and one based on accommodation, with a maximum grant of $150.00 for each section with ratings for the various factors involved as set out by him. The Koksilah School, which is close to the town of Duncan, in which the teacher lives, shows no isolation bonus but an allowance in lieu of accommodation of $150.00. The Skwah School, which is less than 3/4 mile from the centre of the city of Chilliwack, and has a very good teacherage, shows no bonus.

Major D.M. McKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

On the grounds that allowances should be based on the actual cost of living, including transportation and that salary be based on qualifications, it is recommended that appointments of all teachers in this Agency be made as at Prince Rupert, B.C.

For your information, the following costs are applicable. The fare from Vancouver to Prince Rupert is now $60.70 return.

(1) Gitlakdamix - fare from Prince Rupert to Naas River is $11.40 return. From there the teachers go up river either in the mail boat (an ordinary gillnet boat) and spend anything from twenty-four hours to three days sitting on a pile of mail sacks and freight; at a cost of $10.00 each way plus 1¢ to 2¢ a pound for all their belongings and freight; or a flat rate of $60.00 for a direct trip, which would include all their freight and baggage. In this village they have to take in with them at least five months supply of basic groceries and foods.

(2) Gwinaha (Canyon City) - The same costs apply as to Gitlakdamix with the exception that the charter rate is $50.00 instead of $60.00. There is no store in this village and the teachers have to either bring in their supplies from outside or from Alyansh at Indian village store prices.

(3) Lakalsap (Greenville) - Similar costs as for Gitlakdamix and Gwinaha, but that charter rate is $20.00. This village freezes up sooner than any village on the Naas River and consequently the teachers must make more careful provision for ensuring supplies than to other places in the Agency.

(4) Kincolith - The teachers for this village can land at the Government Dock, but all their goods have to be
Major D.M. McKay,

Page 2.

(4) Cont'd. Kincolith -- transported to the village at high water by Indian gas boat, for which a charge of $5.00 per trip is made.

(5) Port Simpson - no adjustment is required here as teachers embark within 250 yards of the School.

(6) Metlakatla - Teachers embark at Prince Rupert and proceed by gasboat at a cost of $7.00 to this village.

(7) Kitkatla - Teachers embark at Prince Rupert on Indian gas boats at a charge of $12.00 per trip to Kitkatla.

(8) Hartley Bay - Teachers for this village have usually disembarked at Butedale and have been taken in by the United Church Mission boat. Cost of Indian gas boat is about $10.00 from Butedale and $15.00 from Prince Rupert, B.C.

(9) Port Edward and Sunnyside and Kitselas - No adjustments need be made for these schools as both are adjacent to the C.N. Railroad tracks.

GENERAL:

Teachers for Kitkatla, Hartley Bay, Metlakatla and Kincolith can all be taken in by the Agency Launch and this action is recommended wherever possible.

It should be noted that generally speaking the poorest teachers pedagogically are located in the most isolated villages. We have cases of untrained teachers earning $1000.00 a year who are further penalized by having to pay as much as $300.00 a year for transportation and then having to meet Indian store prices. Even if they were highly qualified and in receipt of high salaries, it is not just to penalize the work they have done to obtain their status by excessive transportation costs.

It should also be recommended that in these very isolated villages it is essential that married couples or a teacher and companion be together. This of course doubles the cost of getting in, often a charge on one salary of $1000.00 a year, as in the case of Lakalsap, Gwinaha and Gitlakdamix in the present school year. Under no circumstances should a single girl be allowed to remain in any Indian village when she is the only white person there.
This matter is I know under advisement by the Department and it is hoped that the information given herein will assist in bringing a favorable decision to the recommendation that appointments be based for this Agency, on Prince Rupert, B.C.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

The Daily Edition is issued on the morning following each day's sitting, the speeches being reported in the language in which they were delivered. Speeches in French are translated into English and appear in that form as an appendix to the daily issue. Speeches in English are translated and appear in the French edition on the day following delivery.

Extra copies of the Daily Edition will be supplied at five cents each or $3.75 a hundred, if the order is given on the day of sitting. Order through the Debates Office.

Reprints of speeches are furnished if the order is given within ten days of first publication. Order through the Debates Office.

Hansard is available to the public by subscription. The rate for the session is three dollars. Remittance must accompany the order, and should be sent to the King's Printer, Ottawa.

Following publication of the Daily Edition, proofs are sent to members for revision. These should be returned within twenty-four hours.

Two indexes are issued, one to the Daily Edition, at the close of the session, and the other to the bound edition, printed about four months later. The current index is compiled as the session proceeds and may be consulted in the Debates Office. For index inquiries and information as to mailing lists, telephone 2-3211, local 2346.

Dear Bob:

I attach a draft isolation score sheet for Indian schools, which we have developed. I would like very much to have your comments as to whether it will fit most of the B.C. schools which you feel should benefit from increased teachers' salaries.

The present proposal is to change the regulations for Grade 4 teachers so that they will include teachers of isolated schools. You will find attached also a draft proposal for changing the classification regulations of a Grade 4 teacher. Teachers of schools in the Northwest Territories and the Yukon will automatically come under these regulations. The isolated schools will be decided by the Indian Affairs Branch by having each Indian agent concerned complete the isolation score sheet. This score sheet will be submitted to the Department through the Regional Supervisor and we can then decide whether the teacher can be classified as Grade 4.

The proposed salary range for Grade 4 teachers will be from $1,800.00 up to $2,500.00. I think this should attract the type of teacher that we want. In addition, of course, we will provide, as usual, free house, fuel and light. I hope that I have made the above fairly clear and would appreciate your comments as to its suitability for the B.C. schools. We have a lot of other irons in the fire. We hope the new monthly day school report will be out within the next few days. It is at the printer's now and as soon as we receive a supply we will send them directly to the teachers. Clark is also hard at work revising the cumulative record card. Our aim will be
to make it as simple as possible and to apply to as many schools as possible.

I hope you had a pleasant Christmas and that you will get all the breaks you richly deserve in the New Year.

As ever,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major R. F. Davey,
District Inspector of Indian Schools,
Vancouver, British Columbia.
Ottawa, January 13, 1948.

Dear Benny:

Regarding the draft isolation score sheet which you sent me there are a few observations I should like to make concerning it. Probably the chief difficulty that we are having in B.C. at the present time is that of accommodation, although isolation does present a problem in a few cases. In the latter cases the score sheet will be a very definite help. I should have preferred the factor of living conditions to be segregated entirely from that of isolation as I indicated in my memorandum forwarded to the Department by Major Mackay. It is a little difficult to determine how well the isolation score sheet will work in B.C. as there is nothing to indicate what score is necessary to entitle a teacher to the reclassification. Apparently in B.C. the minimum score for reclassification should be set at 35 or a little higher but not over 40. If this were done I believe there would be about four or five schools which would qualify. I note that the reclassification would be the equivalent of a bonus of about $200.00 which should give the desired result.

With regard to the individual items on the sheet I think that No. 16 should be clarified. Apparently the factor being considered in this item is the number of pupils per teacher rather than the total number of pupils in the school. Although this is obvious to me some of the Agents might misinterpret the present wording.

I was very interested in the copy of "Canada and Her Neighbours" which I received the other day. In my opinion it is
a first class book, although I think there should have been more activities either suggested or given as exercises. I also noticed that there were one or two inaccuracies in the section dealing with B.C. Inaccuracies may be an over-statement but certainly the wrong impression was given, largely due I believe to the author's attempt to keep the subject matter down to a minimum.

Classification Regulations

1. Teacher, Indian School, Grade I.

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold certificates from a recognized Normal or Teachers' Training School. After 1 September, 1947, it will be the policy of the Department to employ only teachers who hold recognized teaching certificates. Any non-certificated teachers employed as of that date can be retained in the service but no further non-certificated teachers will be employed except in the event of an emergency. If this is necessary such teachers will fall into this category.

(b) Salary raises to $1060 and $1120 will be given for satisfactory service in the first three years only as shown on the salary scale.

2. Teacher, Indian School, Grade II

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold a Second Class Teacher's Certificate (or equivalent requiring High School Junior Matriculation plus teacher training at a recognized school).

(b) Salary raises for satisfactory service will be given annually for the first seven years only as shown on the salary scale.

(c) No teacher shall be eligible for the increments provided in the fourth or seventh years of service according to the scale attached hereto, unless such teacher has at some time in the preceding three year period respectively, completed one professional or academic session at a Provincial or University Summer School for teachers, or an equivalent course recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch.

3. Teacher, Indian School, Grade III

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold a First Class Teacher's Certificate (or equivalent requiring High School Senior Matriculation or First Year University) plus teacher training at a recognized school. Specialist teachers with First Class Certificates in Industrial Arts, Household Science, Agriculture or other specialist field will also be classified in this category.
(b) Salary raises for satisfactory services will be given annually for the first ten years; thereafter at the end of the 14th and 19th years of experience.

(c) No teacher shall be eligible for the increments provided in the 4th, 7th, 10th, 14th and 19th years of service according to the scale attached hereto, unless such teacher has at some time in the preceding three or five year period respectively, completed one professional or academic session at a Provincial or University Summer School for teachers, or an equivalent course recognized by the Indian Affairs Branch.

4. Teacher, Indian School, Grade IV

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold a High School Teacher's Certificate (or equivalent requiring a University degree plus teacher training). Specialized teachers with High School Certificates in Industrial Arts, Household Science, Agriculture, or other specialist field will also be classified in this category. It will be further required that 50% of such teacher's teaching time be spent in Grade IX and upwards.

(b) Same as for Teacher, Grade III.

(c) Same as for Teacher, Grade III.

DEPUTY MINISTER

Statement on Indian Day School Teachers -

As requested, please find attached a statement prepared on the improved status of Indian day school teachers for presentation by you to the Parliamentary Committee.

We have endeavoured to cover the salient points in a brief presentation.

Enclosure.

Director,

[Signature]

[Stamp]
The Indian Affairs Branch is now employing some 352 teachers in its Indian day schools which are located throughout every province and territory of Canada. In the past, these teachers were classified only as temporary civil servants and were not placed on a regular graded salary schedule.

On 1 September, 1947, there went into effect an "Indian Day School Teacher's Salary Schedule" which provided for grades of day school teachers, welfare teachers and principals. This schedule provides for regular annual salary increments, based upon qualification and satisfactory teaching experience. This schedule has done much to retain in our service the type of teacher who can render a great contribution to Indian education.

The introduction of a separate class of teachers now termed "Welfare Teachers" is a progressive advancement which, we hope, will do much to improve living conditions on certain isolated reservations. This category of teacher is paid on a twelve month basis and in addition to normal teaching duties, carries out other activities such as the formation of homemakers' clubs, the sponsoring of community recreation, the encouragement of home gardens and home improvement clubs, the improvement of living conditions and cooperates with Indian agents and nurses in matters of family allowances, drug dispensing, etc.

Early in January of this year an Order-in-Council was passed making eligible the first group of Indian day school teachers for appointment to permanent positions in the Indian Affairs Branch for the purposes of the Civil Service Superannuation Act. This means that for the first time teachers who meet the requirements are eligible for superannuation privileges such as are enjoyed by other permanent civil servants. We feel confident that this step will do a great deal towards the provision of a more permanent group of teachers in these schools and will reduce the large turnover in staff that has previously occurred every summer.

In addition to the above two improvements in status, we have also endeavoured to provide a better type of living accommodation at our day schools. The new standard type of day school building being constructed provides for a comfortable teachers' in the same building. We feel that in these isolated points, a sound and well furnished teachers' will help to attract a more satisfactory type of teacher. We are also carrying out improvements in many of the present teachers'.

To summarize, then, the achievements of the past year with regard to improved conditions for our day school teachers are three-fold:

1. The introduction of a salary schedule with regular increments as described above,

2. The first group of such teachers has been made eligible for privileges under the Civil Service Superannuation Act,

3. The provision of a better class of living accommodation for teachers.

7. GENERAL REMARKS
The following suggestions concerning teachers' salaries are submitted for the consideration of the subcommittee:

(1) The salaries of all teachers employed in day schools in the Northwest Territories should be paid by the Government. It is felt that such a practice would make for more unified control and is desirable in view of the plans now being formulated to improve the level of instruction.

(2) Government positions should be created for these teachers. The Indian Affairs Branch has recently succeeded in establishing government positions for all the teachers in the Indian schools throughout Canada. This was effected through an arrangement with the Treasury Board, and by authority of Order in Council P.C. 88/566 of 14th February, 1947, and an amendment of 26th March, 1947. The teachers in Indian schools are temporary civil servants, and may be granted permanent status at the end of two years of satisfactory service. A similar arrangement is recommended for the teachers in day schools of the Northwest Territories.

(3) These teaching positions should be excluded insofar as the manner of appointment is concerned, from the operation of the Civil Service Act. Some years ago the Indian Affairs Branch circumvented the usual Civil Service Commission procedure in filling vacancies by having the appointment of its teachers excluded from the operation of the Civil Service Act, it being considered "that it is not practicable nor in the public interest to apply in any manner whatsoever the provisions of this Act to such positions." The net result has been to speed appointment, facilitate the discharge of unsatisfactory teachers, and make for greater all-round efficiency. It is suggested that appointments to teaching positions in the schools of the Northwest Territories should also, because of the particular circumstances, be excluded from the operation of the Civil Service Act.

(4) An adequate salary schedule should be adopted, based upon professional qualifications and experience. Because of the special conditions confronting teachers in the Northwest Territories, it is held that such a salary schedule must provide for increased salaries over and above the present salary schedule in effect for day school teachers.
employed by the Indian Affairs Branch. This might be done in any three ways:

(a) Classify all day school teachers in the Northwest Territories and Yukon in a separate grade. For example, classify them as Grade 4 teachers with a salary range of from $1,500 to $2,520. This proposal was discussed with the Personnel Section of the Department, and it was found to be not feasible because it is contrary to the Civil Service principle of salary payments based upon position, qualifications and experience, rather than upon location. In other words, it is not practical to have a teacher employed in a Government day school in Alberta who is classified as a Grade 11 teacher, promoted to a Grade 4 teacher simply because she is being transferred to a school in the Northwest Territories. Moreover a teacher moving from the Territories to an Indian day school in one of the provinces would have to be downgraded.

(b) Grant a living allowance to a maximum amount of $1,200 in the case of single persons and $1,500 for married male teachers and married female teachers with dependents, the amount of the allowance to be determined in each individual case by the degree of isolation involved. The Department of Transport has solved a similar problem in the classification of radio operators by adopting an isolation rating form, together with a scale for dividing allowances into six groups. These two forms in effect with the Department of Transport are attached as Appendices A and B.

It has been decided to recommend a somewhat similar plan for the day schools operated by this Department, and a suggested isolation score sheet is attached hereto as Appendix C. An attempt has been made to make this more objective than the form used by the Department of Transport, and to provide for important factors not included in this form. It is suggested that the ratings for groups should be a matter for determination by the officials concerned.
Revise the salary schedule currently in effect with the Indian Affairs Branch. Such a revision is presented in Appendix D, wherein an attempt has been made to secure an improvement by the introduction of a salary increase such as was recently granted by the Civil Service Commission to clerks, stenographers, etc.

These salary ranges have been discussed briefly with Mr. Orr of the Civil Service Commission. He has recently been conducting a survey of all field officers in the Indian Affairs Branch, and he has had the opportunity to visit a number of day schools. Mr. Orr suggested a minimum salary of $1,500 per year for qualified Indian day school teachers.

Attached hereto as Appendix E are some comparative salary scales designed to show what is involved as between the present and recommended salary schedules, together with several comparisons of the proposed salaries for teachers as against some other Civil Service salaries.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

B. F. NEARY,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,

The attached letter is self-explanatory and I believe you are aware of the fact that we have never yet made deductions from the salaries of Indian Day School teachers from allowances in kind such as quarters, fuel, light etc.,

This has been due to the fact that we have always regarded our Indian day school teachers as the caretakers of the schools in which they were teaching. These caretaking services consist of being responsible for the general maintenance and care of the buildings. In some instances, our teachers are paid as janitors where they do the cleaning work involved in keeping the classrooms fit for use. We do not pay them for the general supervision of the building, the carrying in of fuel and the carrying out of minor repairs. It was felt that these services could well be regarded as being received in lieu of living quarters, fuel and light.

Most of our Indian day schools, particularly the one and two room types, are so designed that a teacher lives under the same roof as the classroom in which he or she works. Therefore, it is impossible to differentiate between care of the school and the care of the teacherage. I have felt that, in view of the isolated condition of many of our schools and the difficulties besetting our teachers that it would be almost impossible to hire teachers at our present rates of pay unless we continue to provide them with free house, fuel and light.
I may add that this practice of providing these amenities is consistent with that being followed by most rural school districts in Western Canada. In this regard, I attach two administrative letters covering specific examples of such a procedure.

In view of your personal knowledge of conditions in our day schools, I would appreciate an opportunity of discussing Mr. Hamlyn's letter with you.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Indian Day School Teachers.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your recent letter concerning deductions made from the salaries of these teachers for any allowances in kind, such as quarters, fuel and light, etc., that may be supplied to them.

A search of our files has revealed that a similar enquiry was made by the Treasury Board in March, 1938. At that time, Mr. R. A. Hoey, the then Superintendent of Welfare and Training, replied as follows:

"With reference to Mr. Pratt's memorandum of December 23, 1937 requesting certain information required by the Treasury Board I may say that the only employees of this Division who might be considered as receiving perquisites in addition to their salary are the teachers of Indian Day Schools.

"Owing to the impossibility of securing suitable board and accommodation close to the majority of Indian Day Schools it has been found necessary by the Department to provide, in many cases, living accommodation for the teacher. In most cases the Department has provided a building which contains a classroom and two or three small rooms for the teacher's living quarters. At a few of our Indian Day Schools separate buildings were erected several years ago to serve as teachers' living quarters. These are still being used."
"As you know P.C. 20/1936 of July 20, 1936, wholly exempted teachers of Indian day schools from the operation of the Civil Service Act."

We have always regarded our Indian day school teachers as the caretakers of the schools in which they were teaching. These caretaking services consist of duties connected with the general maintenance and care of the building. In some instances our teachers or a local Indian receives a small monthly payment for janitoring duties such as emptying toilets, scrubbing floors of classroom and toilets, washing windows, erecting storm windows, etc. We do not pay them for the general supervision of the building, the carrying of fuel, minor repairs, etc., as it was considered that these services could well be regarded as being received in lieu of living quarters, fuel and light.

Most of our Indian day schools, particularly the one and two room types, are so designed that the teacher lives under the same roof as the classroom in which he or she works. Therefore, it is impossible to differentiate between care of the school and the care of the teacherage. I have felt that, in view of the isolated condition of many of our schools and the difficulties besetting our teachers that it would be almost impossible to hire teachers at our present rates of pay unless we continue to provide them with free house, fuel and light.

I may add that this practice of providing these amenities is consistent with that being followed by most rural school districts in Western Canada.

Yours very truly,

Director.

Department of Mines and Resources

The following suggestions concerning teachers' salaries are submitted for the consideration of the subcommittee:

(1) DAY SCHOOL TEACHERS

The following comparative chart shows the qualifications of Indian day school teachers at 1 January 1949, as compared with 1 January 1948.

This table indicates the proper trend in the hiring of day school teachers. We feel the Departmental policy should be as follows:

(a) The elimination of grade I teachers from our schools.

This intention has been stated in previous salary schedules but the continuing serious shortage of teachers makes it difficult to interest and hire teachers with qualifications. Therefore, we are recommending a salary increase of $60.00 only for this category.

(b) The gradual reduction in the number of grade II teachers.

The provinces are gradually ceasing the issuance of second class teaching certificates (grade 2 teachers). Therefore, we have recommended only an increase of $120 for this category. We feel that all teachers with second class certificates should be provided with a definite incentive to work towards first class certificates. Therefore, a wider gap should be provided between the salaries of grade II and grade III teachers.

(c) The employment, wherever possible, of grade III teachers

All provincial departments of education are now emphasizing the importance of hiring only teachers with first class certificates. We must not lag behind and therefore feel that this grade of teacher should receive the following salary changes:

(i) a basic increase of $150 per annum
(ii) an increase in the annual salary increment from the present rate of $60 to $120
(iii) a "degree bonus" of $120 for teachers holding or receiving university degrees.

(2) WELFARE TEACHERS

As previously discussed in the subcommittee, the classification regulations have been changed to provide for more emphasis on professional social service qualifications.
(3) PRINCIPALS

These salaries have been increased in line with grade III teachers' salaries as all principals must hold at least first class teaching certificates.

We have attached, as appendices, comparative tables showing teachers' salaries in the two provinces in which are located the largest number of Indian schools, namely Ontario and British Columbia. Other salary information is also provided in these appendices.

We have denoted by lines in the margin the main changes recommended from the present salary schedule.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Salaries of Teachers - Indian Residential Schools

Upon receipt of Mr. Jackson's memorandum of April 5th, as minute to you by Dr. Keenleyside, I began making enquiries as to similar provincial schools operated within institutions.

As you are aware, one such example is the provincial school operated within the buildings of the Fairbridge Farm School near Duncan, B.C. The Fairbridge Farm School is operated by a Society with headquarters in England and is part of a colonization programme. Young British boys and girls are brought to the school at the age of 10 and upwards. When they graduate, they are assimilated into Canadian life much more readily than the average immigrant of older years. Similar schools are operated in Australia and I believe now, New Zealand. Realizing that Major Davey was personally acquainted with the existing system and also with some of the staff at Fairbridge, I wrote and asked him to make enquiries. Please find attached his memorandum of April 23rd.

I also had enquiries made at the School for the Blind at Brantford, Ontario.

While an exact parallel does not exist in either of these two institutions, I feel that we can reach certain definite conclusions as a result of a study of
their operation. I might best clarify the situation by answering Mr. Jackson's questions as follows:

1. The teachers will be hired by the Department and responsible to the Department for the education of these children. I feel that a senior teacher should be appointed who will be directly responsible for the education of these children and who will come under the Principal of the school for such matters as administration and discipline. In order that there will be no divided authority within the institution, the Principal will have to be responsible, subject to Departmental regulations, for the efficient functioning of the classrooms insofar as lighting, heating, etc., are concerned.

We have had no difficulties with our hospital teachers in the hospitals operated by the Indian Health Services. These teachers are directly under the Medical Superintendent of the Hospital and he instructs them as to the patients which they can teach, the hours during which they can be taught, etc. The teachers are responsible to the Department for the educational progress of the adults and children whom they are instructing.

2. The teachers will be responsible for the discipline of the school children during such times as these pupils are detailed to them for classroom instruction. They may also be allotted extra curricular activities such as Sports, Boy Scouts, Girl Guides, Dramatics, etc., but again, always subject to departmental regulations.

3. Every effort should be made to limit the amount of time spent by senior pupils outside the classroom. It will be necessary to have a survey made at each school concerned to determine which pupils, if any, should be exempt from classroom work. You will note that the Fairbridge School Farm regulations require that pupils do farm chores during class periods only to a limited extent and that daily chores are performed outside school hours. The heavy laundry work is done on Saturdays or other holidays.

4. Yes, as is done in the day schools.
5. I would suggest that we adhere to a standard day school practice of a period not to exceed thirty minutes per day for religious instruction.

6. I recommend that we pay these teachers at the same rate as allowed by our day school teachers' schedule. Any deductions for board, lodging, laundry and other perquisites can be settled between the principal and the teachers concerned. There should be no objection to teachers boarding away from the residential school if they so desired and providing they did their share of the extra curricular activities mentioned in paragraph 2 above.

It will be necessary to review the per capita rate at each school concerned and to recommend to the Minister a new and lower rate, dependent upon the proportionate salary allowed to teachers at the present time.

Bernard J. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

INTRODUCTION

MINIMUM AND MAXIMUM SALARIES OF TEACHERS AND PRINCIPALS IN 34 CANADIAN CITIES

The 1949 report on salaries of teachers and principals is comparable to Report #16, issued in May, 1948. As will be noted, the majority of salary schedules have been revised or are in process of revision this year. In a few cases (i.e., Montreal Catholic and Saskatoon) the new schedules are not yet available and last year's figures have been inserted in the tables. The date of revision should therefore be checked before any comparisons are drawn.

Tables I, II, III and IV give a break-down by population groups for elementary and secondary school levels. The intermediate level was omitted this year because so few school boards differentiate for this category.

Table V indicates the factors considered by the various school boards in determining teachers' salaries -- and salary schedules. Some ambiguity of interpretation is evident, particularly with regard to the merit system. A number of responses confused merit rating with training (degrees, specialization, etc.); a further number interpreted merit in terms of "satisfactory inspectors' reports prerequisite to annual increments." According to the latter definition, probably most schools would give an affirmative response, though only a few have done so. The most complete response is that of Victoria, with its E-A, E-B, etc. certification. Again, these letter categories are based chiefly on training (degrees and/or specialization), but do include credits "for approved work." No detail of the rating system or such "approved work" is given. Since several cities have requested further information regarding a workable merit system, it would be much appreciated if those who practice rating by superintendents and/or inspectors according to any objective scale would supply further data for subsequent analysis.

Table VI has been added to cover questions raised by a specific school board. The table, constructed on a qualitative basis, is self-explanatory.

MEMORANDUM:

SIR,

Indian Res School Teachers' Salaries.

As you are aware, our day school teachers did not receive the cost of living bonus (or increase in salary) granted to most civil servants effective October 1, 1948. Classification Regulations

I. Teacher, School, Grade I.

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold certificates from a recognized Normal or Teachers' Training School. September, 1947, it was the policy of the Department to employ only teachers who hold recognized teaching certificates. Any non-certificated teachers employed at that date can be retained in the service but no further non-certificated teachers will be employed except in the event of an emergency. If this is necessary, such teachers will fall into this category.

(b) Teachers whose service with the Department has been satisfactory may apply for a year's leave of absence without pay in order that they may attend a Normal School and obtain a Provincial Teachers Certificate.

(c) Salary scales for satisfactory service will be given annually for the first six years only as shown on the salary scale.

(d) A bonus of $60.00 per annum will be allowed to teachers in this category who have attended two summer school refresher courses since 1940.

II. Teacher, School, Grade II.

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold a Second Class Teacher's Certificate (or equivalent requiring High School Junior Matriculation plus teacher training at a recognized school).

(b) Salary scales for satisfactory service will be given annually for the first nine years only as shown on the salary scale.

(c) No teacher shall be eligible for the increments provided in the fourth or seventh years of service according to the scale attached hereto, unless such teacher has at some time in the preceding three-year period respectively, completed one professional or academic session at a Provincial or University Summer School for teachers, or an equivalent course recognized by the Department of Mines and Resources.

III. Teacher, School, Grade III.

(a) Teachers in this category will be required to hold a First Class Teacher's Certificate (or equivalent requiring High School Senior Matriculation or First Year University plus teacher training at a recognized school).

(b) Salary scales for satisfactory service will be given annually for the first ten years; thereafter at the end of the 16th and 20th years of experience.

(c) No teacher shall be eligible for the increments provided in the 6th, 11th and 16th years of service according to the scale attached hereto, unless such teacher has at some time in the preceding five-year period respectively, completed one professional or academic session at a Provincial or University Summer School for teachers, or an equivalent course recognized by the Department of Mines and Resources.
(d) A bonus of $120.00 per annum will be allowed to teachers in this category holding or receiving degrees from a recognized University.

CLASSIFICATION REGULATIONS

(a) These regulations shall be the same as for Teacher, School. Normally these Welfare Teachers will be employed in day schools situated on the more remote Indian reservations, at nursing stations and Indian hospitals, and within the Northwest Territories.

(b) Welfare Teachers may qualify for the salary increments requiring summer school courses by taking correspondence courses from provincial Departments of Education, universities, or other institutions recognized by the Department of Mines and Resources.

(c) These teachers will be employed for the full twelve-month period. They will remain on the reservation or in the community during this time, with the exception of the usual Civil Service holidays of eighteen working days per year to which they will be entitled.

(d) Welfare Teachers may be granted leave of absence for seven weeks once every three years to enable them to attend a course in social welfare, sociology, education or some related field at a Canadian or American university or school recognized by the Department of Mines and Resources.

(e) In addition to their normal teaching duties, Welfare Teachers will be called upon to lend their assistance in connection with such administrative matters as the payment of family allowances, the dispensing of medicines, the investigation of welfare cases requiring assistance, and the supervision of special problem cases.

(f) Welfare Teachers will be expected to give leadership to all local activities designed to effect improvements in community life. For this purpose they will organize recreational programs, devise measures of adult education, visit the homes, and endeavour to improve not only the living conditions but the general welfare of the people.
(g) In view of the particular nature of the duties to be performed by Welfare Teachers, the latter will be selected on the basis of personal qualifications and aptitude for the work. Professional training in the field of social welfare work will be distinct advantage, and appointees must have a good background in participation in group activities.

(h) A bonus of $120.00 per annum will be allowed to Grade 3 Welfare Teachers holding or receiving degrees in social science from a recognized university.

1949 REVISED TEACHERS' SALARY SCHEDULE

Department of Mines and Resources

As our field officials and teachers were advised in the June 1949 issue of the Bulletin, our Day School Teachers' Salary Schedule has been revised. Approval for this new scale has just been obtained, and we are pleased to forward to our teachers the details of their new salaries.

You will find in the attached pages three separate sections which will be of interest to you:

(a) The Classification Regulations
(b) The Salary Scale
(c) The Application Form for Classification on the Scale.

We are now outlining the main changes in the regulations and salary scale.

CLASSIFICATION REGULATIONS

Departmental policy in the hiring of day school teachers will be as follows:

1. The elimination of Grade I teachers from our schools.

This intention has been clearly stated in previous salary schedules. The present serious shortage of teachers alone makes it possible to hire teachers who do not hold teaching certificates granted by provincial departments of education.

Once again, we would urge all teachers holding permits and letters of authority to qualify for teaching certificates as soon as possible. We can make no guarantee whatsoever to them of continued employment unless they become qualified.

In order to help such teachers obtain certificates, please note that they may now apply for a year's leave of absence without pay in order that they may attend normal school.
2. The gradual reduction in the number of Grade II teachers.

Provincial departments of education are gradually ceasing the issuance of Second Class Teaching Certificates (Grade II teachers). Therefore, teachers holding such certificates should begin working towards their First Class Certificates. You will note that a wider gap now exists between Grade II and Grade III teachers' salaries.

3. The employment wherever possible of Grade III teachers.

All provincial departments of education are now emphasizing the importance of hiring only teachers with First Class Certificates. We do not intend to let our Indian day schools lag behind in any respect. Therefore, the salary scale for these teachers has been greatly increased in several ways.

Naturally, we employ very few Grade IV or high school teachers in our schools as "secondary education" in provincial high schools.

SALARY SCALE

The following are the main increases in salary:

1. Grade I teachers:
   (a) An increase of $60.00 per academic year.
   (b) A bonus of $60.00 per annum will be allowed to teachers who have attended two summer school refresher courses since 1940.

2. Grade II teachers:
   (a) A salary increase of $120.00 per academic year.

3. Grade III teachers:
   (a) A basic increase of $180.00 per annum.
   (b) An increase in the annual salary increment from the present rate of $60.00 up to $120.00.
   (c) A degree bonus of $120.00 for teachers holding or receiving university degrees.

4. Grade IV teachers
   (a) A basic increase of $180.00 per annum.
   (b) An increase in the annual salary increment from the present rate of $60.00 up to $120.00.
APPLICATION FOR CLASSIFICATION ON SALARY SCALE

Due to the changes in the regulations and salary scale, it will be necessary for each teacher to complete and forward to the Indian Superintendent concerned an application form covering latest qualifications. It is most important to detail the summer courses which you have attended. The following table indicates the summer school attendance requirements of the schedule:

| Grade II | 4th year | 7th year |
|----------|----------|----------|
| Grade III| 6th year | 11th year | 16th year |

No increment in these years unless summer school attended as shown in schedule.

In other words, you are "frozen" at a salary until you produce evidence of having attended the required summer schools. A Grade II teacher will not receive her third salary until she produced evidence of having attended a summer course. A Grade III teacher will not be held at the fifth year of her salary level until she satisfied the Department that she had attended the required summer school courses.

Therefore, would you please give these application forms your immediate attention. Otherwise your salary in September will be at the old rate. Teachers will receive their September salary at the old rate as it will take approximately a month to make adjustments in cheques. Please do not write to the Department if your September salary is at the old rate. You will receive adjustment during October if your application form is sent to your Indian Superintendent.

ACT NOW - fill the form at once to be sure to give details of summer courses - mail to your Indian Superintendent.

Order in Council of December 9th, 1948,
P.C. 59/5666, approved the new classes, Teacher, School,
Teacher, Welfare and Principal, School and provides that
under Section 59 of the Civil Service Act, these classes be
exempt from the operation of that Statute. In reporting
appointments to these classes, the Department of Mines and
Resources has, in certain instances, requested payment at
rates in excess of the minimum and we believe that in the
absence of specific authority, all appointments should be
effected at the minimum rate for the class.

Section 7 of the Indian Act, Chapter 98,
R.S.C. 1927, reads as follows:

"The Governor in Council may appoint

(a) an officer who shall be called the Deputy of
the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs;

(b) a deputy governor.

2. Such other officers, clerks and servants as are requisite
for the proper conduct of the business of the Department
may be appointed in the manner authorized by law.

By exemption from the manner authorized by law, i.e., the Civil
Service Act, selection of the employees is left entirely in the
hands of the Department. However, where a salary range is
established and no provision is made for appointments at rates
higher than the minimum, such appointments should, in our opinion,
be made at the minimum or authority for any higher rate secured.

Memorandum:

CHIEF TREASURY OFFICER

School Teachers' Salaries

I have been making enquiries concerning the points raised in Mr. Morgan's letter of September 9 concerning the payment of salaries to teachers in excess of the minimum. It is now my considered opinion that the main difficulty in this connection is that our submissions concerning teachers' salaries always fall into two parts:

(a) "Regulations regarding the grades of Civil Servants to be employed in the Education Division"

(b) Rates of pay for school teachers, welfare teachers and principals.

Regulations

As you will note from the attached 1949 Revision of the Salary Schedule, the Regulations clearly indicate the category into which the various applicants for teacher positions in our schools might be placed.

In these Regulations we also define the number of summer sessions which teachers must attend in order to qualify for salary increases at certain stated periods. In other words, these salary increases, unlike the usual Civil Service salary increments, are not dependent on years of service and the recommendations of the senior officials concerned but must meet the following additional requirements:

(a) submission of a satisfactory school inspector's report

(b) attendance at summer schools at certain stated intervals.
Therefore, at the end of each academic year, teachers must submit an application for an increase in salary supporting their claim as required by our Regulations concerning Inspector's reports and summer school attendance. These increases do not originate, as do most Civil Service salary increases, with the Personnel Officers of the Branch but with the teachers concerned. In most instances, where teachers can not support their claim for an increase, they do not even make such application.

The other point in the Regulations which should possibly be covered by approval from the Treasury Board is the following:

"3. Time spent by a duly certificated teacher as a teacher in the public schools in any part of the British Commonwealth, or as an Instructor in a University in any part of the British Commonwealth, shall be regarded as time spent in teaching in the school of the Department, provided that the maximum period of such teaching service so regarded shall not exceed five years. Such teachers must also have attended one professional or academic session at a Summer School Course recognized by the Department in order to qualify for the increments described above in the regulations for grades of teachers."

These Regulations are approved by the Minister in accordance with authority given him by Section 9 (4) of the Indian Act which reads as follows:

"The Superintendent General (the Minister) shall have power to make regulations prescribing a standard for the buildings, equipment, teaching, and discipline of and in all schools and for the inspection of such schools."

Three separate Ministers have now approved these Regulations and in each the clause concerning time spent by teachers in provincial schools has remained the same.
We have therefore been paying new teachers in accordance with these Regulations since the first of September 1947. Teachers entering our service from provincial schools have been started on the scale in accordance with the Regulations described above. A similar clause is contained in every provincial teachers' salary scale, and if we are to obtain good teachers for our schools, we will have to continue to bring in experienced teachers at rates higher than the minimum.

It is common sense that a teacher with eight years of experience is much more valuable in our schools than one graduated directly from Normal School. In fact, due to provincial salary regulations permitting years of credit for outside experience, these qualified teachers would not consider positions in our schools if they were to start at the same minimum rate as that given to Normal School graduates. Some of the provinces are more lenient than this Division, and provide up to ten years of credit for outside experience.

Increases in Salary Rates

When the new salary rates were approved by F.O.74/3539 of July 15, 1949, our former teachers were reclassified at the new figures.

Summary

I would welcome an opportunity of discussing this matter with Mr. Morgan or one of his officials. It would seem that our Regulations will have to be approved by the Treasury Board at the same time as the rates are being considered. These Regulations definitely describe conditions which have to be met and permit the granting of years of credit and therefore directly concern the salary rates. In other words, the salary rates are only one side of the picture, and the Regulations are the other in that they do influence the rates at which teachers are appointed and the manner in which increases are granted.
In order to rectify the present situation, it would seem to be necessary to have the following two submissions made to Treasury Board:

(a) concerning the granting of years of credit to new teachers appointed effective 1 September 1949 and since that date, and granting credit for their years of provincial experience,

(b) concerning the granting of salary increases to those of our teachers in the service before September 1, 1949, and who have met the conditions clearly described in the Regulations.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
Colonel Henry:

Teachers' Salaries:

I attach two copies of the salary schedule presently in force in the High Prairie School Division. Obviously there must be many two-thousand-dollar teachers, and the cost per pupil for that item alone is likely to exceed fifty dollars a year. As this Division also maintains bus service, the cost of pupils who may be admitted to Kinuso hereafter may be considerable. Nevertheless, school officials say it would cost more to maintain the scattered small schools with well-paid teachers.

This makes me wonder whether our salary scale should take into account the pupil-teacher ratio, or whether the Department should from time to time assign the highest-paid teachers to schools where the teaching load is heaviest. At present there is the possibility that a teacher with a high salary based on qualifications and experience may select a school with a handful of children, while some less experienced and lower-paid person has to struggle with a congested room. Some of our officials have invited my attention to this.

It has also been drawn to my attention that Welfare Teachers employed in hospitals enjoy great advantages over the nursing staff in regard to salary and duties, and that it is difficult to measure the load and the performance of the teachers. It may be that a new class of teacher—"Hospital Teacher"—is indicated.

It has also been remarked that the salaries of Social Workers (few applications for these positions have been received) compare unfavourably with the salaries paid to some of our Welfare Teachers on reserves.

C.A.F. Clark

Classification Regulations - Indian Affairs Branch Teachers

Dear Mr. Grantham:

For some time now, we have been noticing that two changes might well be made in the present classification regulations previously approved by the Minister of Mines and Resources.

These two suggested changes are as follows:

(a) When a teacher whose salary has been previously frozen attends a summer school, then such a teacher will receive a salary then equivalent to the year following the one at which she was formerly frozen.

For example, if a teacher has a First Class Certificate, eight years of experience but has never attended summer school, she would be frozen at the fifth year, namely $216.00 a teaching month. If she attends summer school, she is now entitled to jump to the ninth year on the scale or $264.00 a teaching month. I feel that such a teacher should only go up one year in salary and be placed at the sixth year or $228.00 a teaching month.

(b) That a period not exceeding two years be allowed for overseas service in the Armed Forces. I note that various School Boards are providing for such service and feel that some credit could be given on our scale.
An alternative would be to allow year for year credit for Armed Services experience but with the total credit for Provincial and Armed Services experience not to exceed seven years.

I know you will have similar suggestions for changes and would appreciate hearing from you in this regard.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
