ADVISORY PANEL ON INDIAN RESEARCH

For some time now our Departmental officials have been planning the establishment of a panel or committee which could advise them on various Indian research problems.

There is a genuine need for professional research into matters relating to Indian Education, Welfare and Social problems, etc. The establishment of such a panel could provide for a coordination of the research which has been done or is planned into various aspects of Indian life. It could also plot out in general terms the order of priority in which various studies could be undertaken.

It has been recommended that the following be represented on this panel:

1. The National Research Council, which it is felt, could be represented by yourself,

2. The Canadian Social Science Research Council which could be represented by Dr. J.E. Robbins,

3. The Indian Affairs Branch.

Naturally, this core of members could be added to by the inclusion of Dr. O.E. Ault of the Civil Service Commission, Dr. C.G. Stoddart of the Department of National Health and Welfare and Professors McIlwraith and Brown of the University of Toronto.

I would sincerely appreciate your advice on the establishment of such a panel and also your reaction to my request that you accept the duties of Chairman of this group. I feel that a fact-finding body such as this can go a long way towards alleviating the present dearth of social science research studies into the various aspects of the Indian problem.
Mr. B.F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Thanks for your letter l-l-1 (S) dated 8 JUL 49 respecting the establishment of a committee on research in the Indian Affairs Branch of your department. The draft which you attach seems to fill the bill very well. I take it that I am being afforded the unique opportunity of helping to decide how a letter to me should be worded.

If I may make a suggestion or two as to the composition of the proposed committee, one would be that you set up the committee with a definite membership for a year, specifying the persons whom you have named plus yourself and any other departmental representatives. In your present draft you merely indicate Robbins, Morton plus the Branch as the "core", adding that others (Ault, Stogdill et al) could be included also. Might it not be better to name the whole lot (with their individual consent, of course) as the committee at the outset? That would mean six people plus yourselves. Only two would be out-of-town.

I wonder whether something has to be done about McGill people? Both Hall and Laviolette have been active in the sociological field in the past, and with Brown and McLwraith we seem to be bearing down rather more heavily on Toronto. Might I suggest that you consult Robbins on this point, since he knows them all fairly well in connection with the CSSRC? It could be added that you appear to envisage no representation from the West. This criticism, however, probably can be disposed of by virtue of the known difficulties in getting people here from such a distance as B.C. No doubt if at any time any Westerner who would be useful to the Committee happens to be in the East he could be temporarily co-opted for a committee meeting.

/As
As for my own chairmanship, I am willing to take it on for a year if you and Dr. Keenlyside so wish, mainly on the grounds that the chairman might be conveniently located in Ottawa. Actually so far as Indian "lore" is concerned, McLlwraith of Toronto is perhaps the senior social science man in Canada.

Further to my telephone call the other day, I have discovered that we have a larger balance on our NRC account - to wit, some $850 - than I had first been informed. I am, therefore, writing to Turner suggesting that he put in a request for a grant for, say, $500 or 600 to the NRC Committee.

Yours sincerely,

N.W. Morton

held in the office of the Superintendent of Indian
Education, 220 Queen Street, at 9:30 a.m. on Friday,
on November 18.

MEMBERS:
Dr. H. W. Morton, (Chairman) Defense Research Board,
Dr. J. E. Robbins, Dominion Bureau of Statistics,
Dr. O. N. Ault, Civil Service Commission,
Professor T. F. McIlwraith, University of Toronto,
B. F. Neary, Indian Affairs Branch,
E. Acland, Indian Affairs Branch,
A. J. Dusset, Indian Affairs Branch,

In attendance:
Mr. R. F. Davey, Inspector of Indian Schools
for B. C.
Mr. L. Morgan, Assistant Director of Education,
Crown Colony of Hong Kong.

(1) Introductory Statements:
Dr. Morton described the meeting held last summer in
Dr. Keenleyside's office, at which the need for a group to directly
advise the Indian Affairs Branch in sociological research was thoroughly
discussed.

At this meeting it was decided to establish the panel,
whose first meeting was taking place today. Mr. Neary outlined the
feeling of the Branch for assistance in the many problems encountered
in bringing Canada's Indians into the national stream. Professor
McIlwraith expressed the willingness of the Universities to assist in
the necessary research to be undertaken.
(2) Purposes and Terms of Reference of Panel on Indian Research

There was a general discussion led by Dr. Morton, in which all members expressed their opinions as to the purpose of the panel. It was decided that the panel could best serve by helping to formulate issues or problems which were more immediate and pressing and then assist in having research begun with the initial emphasis on educational matters. Dr. Robbins spoke on the coordination which would be possible with the work being carried out by the Canadian Social Research Council. Professor Nellwright discussed the range of projects planned by the Indian Committee of the Canadian Social Research Council and the type of projects in which they were interested. Dr. Ault pointed out the need for coordination between smaller local studies and a Dominion-wide survey.

There was considerable discussion as to the difference of purpose between the Indian Committee of the Canadian Social Research Council and this panel. The general conclusion was that the Indian Committee was more concerned with a broad coverage of the various types of social problems from a scientific point of view and was not particularly concerned with the administrative problems facing the Indian Affairs Branch. The panel, however, was concerned with these problems and with providing professional research and assistance in meeting such problems. Following a review by Mr. Acland of the need for a secretary for the Panel, it was decided to have Mr. Neary carry on these duties at the present time.

(3) Outline of the Present Policies of the Education Division of the Indian Affairs Branch:

This was introduced by Mr. Neary who outlined not only the policies but also the problems confronting the Education Division. This led to expressions of opinion concerning the reserve system and Professor Nellwright spoke on the problem of assimilation.
and the need for the retention of native culture and pride of race. This was followed by an interesting interchange of ideas on assimilation with all the panel participating.

(ii) Educational Problems on which Investigation is needed.

Dr. Morton introduced this subject and stressed particularly the need for enquiring into "the educability of the Indian child". He pointed out the need for factual information concerning the effective intelligence of Indian children as compared with white children of similar social backgrounds in terms of age and grade level. If there is a gap between Indian children and white children - then to what extent do cultural and social backgrounds contribute?

(5) Ways and Means of commencing Essential Studies

Pilot Study - Caradoc Reserve, Muncey, Ontario.

It was agreed that the first project to be sponsored would be on the Caradoc Reserve and that it would be a team study with a sociologist and a psychologist both carrying out the research. Their main problem would be as previously defined and would bear directly on the effective intelligence of Indian children as compared with white children of similar social backgrounds, in terms of age and grade levels. There was considerable discussion on whether it would be possible to demonstrate that such a gap was not caused by biological differences. If the problem is not one of heredity, then what are the cultural and social differences which cause this gap? It was decided that there should be an application of Gesell techniques to both Indian and white children of age levels from 6 months and upwards.

This study would be handled by Dr. G. H. Turner, Assistant Professor of Psychology of the University of Western Ontario.
and by a graduate student under the direction of Dr. Brown of the University of Toronto.

Financing of Research Studies:

It was agreed that there were three main sources of possible revenue for these studies, namely the National Research Council, the Canadian Social Science Research Council and the Indian Affairs Branch. It was decided to provide financial support for the graduate sociology student. Dr. Turner has received a grant from the National Research Council which will make it possible for him to gather some data before the end of the present fiscal year. It was decided to continue further discussion into this general problem of ways and means of commencing essential studies to the next meeting.

The meeting was adjourned at 12:30 p.m., the members to assemble again at the call of the Chairman, probably the 19th of December, 1949.

Dr. W.W. Morton,
Chairman.

B. F. Neary,
Secretary.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Further to the June meeting of Neary, Brown Morton and Turner re the existing intellectual level of Indian children, I am pleased to report that I have recently received a grant from N.R.C. which may make it possible to gather some data before the end of the present fiscal year. (I have a graduate student who will be able to give us some time during the next few months).

I have made no detailed plans as yet but expect to see Dr. Long at O.C.H. (as well as Brown) concerning tests for which there are already existing norms based on large populations of white school children.

However I have remained as ignorant of Indian Affairs generally as I was in June and so am looking to you for some necessary background information as well as for any comments or suggestions about the project as may occur to you.

Perhaps before asking questions of you I should add that my tentative intention is to pick out one or two tests e.g. perhaps a verbal and a non-verbal test for which adequate norms are available and have these administered to as many Indian children as time, money and other circumstances will allow. I also visualize the possibility of having to supplement existing data by testing white children in rural schools.

Now for my questions and requests.

1. Would you be good enough to send along any reports or references which you would regard as either necessary or helpful e.g. results of previous surveys etc. (I have the report of the survey in the U.S. incidentally).
November 24, 1949

MEMORANDUM TO THE JURNEY MINISTER

PANEL ON INDIAN RESEARCH.

You will recall our previous discussion concerning the formation of this Panel. The planning stages have now passed and the first meeting has been held. I therefore attach, for your information and for that of the Minister, the Minutes of this first meeting and the agenda for the next.

The reaction to this first meeting was most encouraging and Professor Mollinraith wrote to the Department as follows:

"First of all, I want to say how much I enjoyed the meeting, or to be more precise, I want to say that I think the meeting was a great success and, therefore, was infinitely more pleasant than most meetings. If we can get the Munro project well started with proper cooperation - and I see no reason why we should not - then I think it will serve both as a pilot study in itself in regard to sedentary Indian groups, and will act as a model for cooperation between different bodies. I am writing Turner, and I will also write Joblin."

You will note that the first project will be started in the near future on the Caribou Reserve and that Professor Turner of the University of Western Ontario and Dr. Brown of the University of Toronto will be in charge. The National Research Council has allotted a sum of approximately $500.00 for this first project. Up to the present time, the only call on this amount has been to meet the travelling expenses of
the out of town delegates. As these meetings will be held only once every two months, it is not felt that these expenses will be excessive.

It is possible that a further sum might be required in carrying out the survey across Canada of the mental ability of Indian children as previously proposed to you. These expenses would consist mainly in the purchasing of Intelligence Tests for use by the Indian children concerned.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
I have recently administered the California Test of Mental Maturity to 70 pupils, Grades 2 and 3, at the Alberni Residential School and the Masset Day School. The results have confirmed my opinion that group intelligence tests are of little value in determining the mental ability of Indian children in British Columbia.

They have indicated however one thing very clearly, and that is the importance of the Language factor. As you are perhaps aware, the California Test has two groups of items, one in which Language is an important factor and a second group called non-Language but in which the Language factor does enter to a limited degree. There was a very great spread in the results on the Language groups as opposed to the results on the non-Language group. In some cases the difference was as much as 40 points in the I.Q. rating and the average difference in the results between the Language and non-Language group was over 15 points. In a few cases there was no significant difference and five pupils secured higher on the Language group than on the non-Language.

You will note that the two schools selected give a fairly representative selection of pupils. The people at Masset have about average contact with the white community. The results at the Day School and at the Residential School followed the same general pattern. These results show quite clearly that it is impossible to assign any arbitrary figure to compensate for the Language factor in intelligence testing with our Native people.

I understand that the Department has employed a psychologist and it is possible that he may be interested in receiving a record of these results. If so, I would be pleased to have a transcript made of them and forwarded to the Department.

Warren, W. W. *Answers to inquiries regarding Chippewas* (Minnesota archaeologist, XIII (1), Jan., 1947, pp. 5-21). The third of a series of answers to articles by an Indian on the Ojibwa (Chippewa), reprinted from the *Minnesota Pioneer* of 1849.

Weslager, C. A. *Further light on the Delaware Indians as women* (Journal of the Washington Academy of Sciences, XXXVII (9), Sept. 15, 1947, pp. 298-304). Details of the capture of the Iroquois by the Delaware following their defeat.

Arts et métiers d'outre-mer (Revue de l'Université d'Ottawa, XV (4), Oct.-Déc., 1945, 497-500). A short note on the crafts developed by the French pioneers of Quebec.

Ceintures flottantes (20th century, Ottawa, II, (4), Déc., 1944, 84, 85).

927. An interesting exposition on the history of the "string float," a woven sash so well-known in Quebec, was used by traders from Indians and others in the early part of the last century.

The house of the Mac built. (Beaver, outfit 276, Dec., 1945, 10-9). The houses built by the Hudson's Bay Company were of "posts on the ground."

Modélité dans nos méloïées populaires (Mémoires de la Société Royale du Canada, XXXVIII, Sec. I, 1944, 15-25). A thoughtful study of the form and music of French folk songs in the Province of Quebec.

Séminaire des dames à l'Amérique. (Cahiers d'art arca, 2.) Montréal: Éditions Fides, 1943. Pp. 116. BASANTI, CARLOS. El psicodálisis y la etnografía (América indígena, IV (4), Oct., 1944, 265-73). BEAUGRAND-CHAMPAIGNE, ARTHUR. Les Malécites et la médecine des anciens Iroquois: (Les Cahiers des dix, no. 9, Montréal, 1944, 227-42). A general and discursive description of Iroquois diseases and their treatment.

La Poterie iroquoise (Les Cahiers des dix, no. 8, Montréal, 1943, 267-84). A non-technical description of Iroquois pottery and its manufacture, culled largely from some of the older sources.
BERLIN, HEINRICH. *El indigena frente al estado* (América indígena, IV (4), Oct., 1944, 275-80). A plea for governmental protection and for co-operation with Indians in current problems of cultural adjustment.

BIRD, JUNIUS B. *Archaeology of the Hopetale area, Labrador* (Anthropological papers of the American Museum of Natural History, XXXIX (2), 1945, 119-86). Eskimo material from the vicinity of Hopetale indicates an occupancy of no more than 400 years ago. The area may have been remote from those of the Dorset Eskimo culture, and not appear to be directly ancestral to the tools of the modern Labrador Eskimo. This paper embodies the results of one of the few competent archaeological investigations on the northern Atlantic coast.

BRAND, DONALD D. *The present Indian population of the Americas* (New Mexico anthropologist, VI-VII (4), Oct., Nov.-Dec., 1943 [printed, Dec., 1944] 161-70). A scholarly appraisal, based on census returns and estimates, of the size of the Indian and part-Indian population of North and South America.

BURRANE, E. A. *Burbonk among the Indians*. Caldwell, Idaho; The Caxton Printers, 1944. Pp. 232. The reminiscences of a distinguished portrait artist whose subjects have included many Indians.

BURGESS, J. ALLAN. *Property concepts of the Lac-St-Jean Montagnais* (Primitive man, XVII (1, 2), Jan.-April, 1945, 250). A description of the rather obscure systems of land tenure and personal and incorporeal property rights, among the Montagnais of Lake St. John, Quebec.

C. K. *Chief Redden Bull speaks* (The Canadian forum, XXXV (297), Oct., 1945, 158). The formation of the Indian Association of Alberta and comparable organizations indicates a growth of group consciousness on the part of Canadian Indians.

CASTETTER, EDWARD F. *The domain of ethnobiology* (American naturalist, LXXVIII (778), March-April, 1944, 158-70). A summary of the history and scope of ethnobiology, a field of study which straddles the disciplines of biology and anthropology, with particular reference to the place of animals in the cultural life of primitive peoples.

CHARLTON, J. L. *English River hermit* (Beaver, outfit 276, Sept., 1945, 28-9). A brief description of an Indian who has lived alone in northern Ontario for some twenty-five years, having practically no contact either with his fellows or with the white man.

COBB, W. MONTAGUE. *Bibliography in physical anthropology: July 1, 1943 through June 30, 1944* (American journal of physical anthropology (II) fold series, vol. XXXI (4), Dec., 1944, 381-421). A comprehensive, well-arranged bibliography of physical anthropology.

COLLIER, JOHN. *Conjuring among the Kiowa* (Primitive man, XVII (3, 4), July-Oct., 1944, 45-9). A brief description of a type of conjuring among the Kiowa with comparative data from other tribes of the northern Plains.

COLLIER, JOHN. *Collier's commentary on Miss Sazi, communication* (America indígena, V (3), Julio, 1945, 255). A final note on some points of view advanced by Miss Sazi and the author.

COLLIER, JOHN. *Race and racism* (America indígena, V (3), Julio, 1945, 241-6). A thoughtful commentary on the question of whether or not claims of rights for Indians, as Indians, especially in Alaska, are likely to promote an attitude of racism towards Indians.

UNITED STATES INDIAN administration as a laboratory of ethnic relations (Social research, XII (3), Sept., 1945, 265-303). A brilliant summary of United States government policy in regard to Indians, showing the results of well formulated policy, and the crippling effects of stagnation and intolerance.
Collins, H. B., Clarke, A. H., and Walker, E. H. *The Aleutian Islands: Their people and natural history.* (Smithsonian Institution, war background studies, 21.) Cooper, John M. *The shaking tent rite among Plains and Forest Algonquians* (Primitive man, XVII (3-4), July-Oct., 1944, 60-84). Tête-de-Boule Cree (International journal of American linguistics, XI (1), Jan., 1945, 36-44). Linguistic analysis proves that the language of the Tête-de-Boule of the upper St. Maurice River, Quebec, belongs to the Cree group of the Algonkian languages.

Crowell, Samuel P. *Rites of the aborigines* (Northwest Ohio quarterly, XVI (3-4), 1944, 147-50).

Davenport, C. B. *The dietaries of primitive peoples* (American anthropologist, XLVII (1), Jan.-March, 1945, 60-82). A scholarly study of the extreme diversity of food habits among selected primitive peoples; the Eskimo are among the groups included.

Davidson, John F. *Ojibwa songs* (Journal of American folklore, LVIII (230), Oct.-Dec., 1945, 303-5). The music and texts of a number of Ojibwa songs from Manitoulin Island and the north shore of Lake Huron, an area largely overlooked in Ojibwa studies.

Dawson, Robert. *Brief survey, VI. The new North-West* (C.J.E.P.S., XI (4), Nov., 1945, 578-600). Deloria, Ella. *Speaking of Indians,* New York: Friendship Press, 1944. Pp. xii, 185. A sympathetic and able study, by an Indian, of Indian problems of today. Though written with reference to the American scene, the examples involved are as pertinent to Canada as to the United States. After a general introduction, the author uses specific illustrations from the Dakota of the northern Plains, showing the demoralizing and lethargy-producing effects of reservation life in the breakdown of traditional family life. The social customs of the old Dakota, based on generosity rather than bargaining, and the responsibility for relatives, have been limiting factors on individual success in a western competitive society. The war has given an opportunity for service to young men and women, an opportunity eagerly grasped, but it opens up problems of economic adjustment. The author pays high tribute to the work of Christian missionaries.

Densmore, Frances. *The origins of a Sioux song* (American anthropologist, XLVII (1), Jan.-March, 1945, 176-8). Dodger, Ernest S. *Notes from Six Nations on the hunting and trapping of wild turkeys and passenger pigeons* (Journal of the Washington Academy of Sciences, XXXV (11), Nov. 15, 1945, 342-3). Only the discovery of bones from archaeological deposits can prove the contemporaneousness of man and extinct animals.

Hamilton, A. H. Music of the North American Indians (Etude, LXIII, July, 1945, 376 seq.).

A detailed study of kinship terminology among the northern Blackfoot, with a comparison and analysis of the theoretical considerations involved.
