Extracts from the Cadillac papers show the French used beer, brandy, and other trade goods in the early eighteenth century to win favor with the Indians of the Great Lakes region, and prevent them from being led to the English traders. This an interesting description of trading practices and ethics of the period.

HERMANNSSON, HALLDÓR. *The Vinland sagas*. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press, 1944. Pp. xiv, 78. A critical edition of the sagas, with commentary and notes.

HEWETT, J. N. B. and FENTON, WILLIAM N. *Some mnemonic pictographs relating to the Iroquois condolence ceremonies* (Proceedings of the Philosophical Society of Sciences, XXXV (10), Oct. 15, 1945, 301-16). A description of mnemonic marks made and used by an Iroquois Indian in connexion with one of the elaborate Iroquois rituals on the Grand River Reservation. The drawings were essentially an aide memoire, partly symbolic in character.

HIBBEN, FRANK C. *We found the home of the first Americans* (Saturday evening post, CCXVII (41), April 7, 1945, 11, 35, 37). A popular, but authoritative, account of archaeological discoveries in a stratified cave in the Sandia mountains of New Mexico, giving evidence of human occupancy some 10,000 years before the date of Folkstone man, previously considered the oldest New World type. This means that America was inhabited about 25,000 years ago.

HINZ, JOHN. *Grammar and vocabulary of the Eskimo language as spoken by the Kuskokwim and Lower Yukon Eskimos* (Alaska Bethel Church, Society for Propagating the Gospel of the Morning Church, 1945). Pp. viii, 116. An analysis of one of the dialects of Alaskan Eskimo, valuable both for comparative data and as a study of a specific language. This is particularly valuable in view of the little linguistic material that has been available from this area.

HONIGMANN, JOHN I. *Northern and southern Athapaskan eschatology* (American anthropologist, XLVII (3), July-Sept., 1945, 407-9). A brief tabular comparison of certain aspects of Navaho and Sarsi (Alberta) beliefs concerning ghosts and witchcraft.

— *On the Alaska highway* (The Dalhousie review, XXIII (4), Jan., 1944, 400-8). A thoughtful article on changing conditions among the Athabascan-speaking tribes of the Yukon, changes accelerated by the building of the Alaska Highway.

— and IRMA. *Drinking in an Indian-White community* (Quarterly journal of studies, V (4), March, 1945, 575-619). A comprehensive study of drinking habits, motivation, social attitudes, and psychological aspects among both whites and Athabascan-speaking Indians in a small settlement on the Alaska Highway.

HOWELLS, WILLIAM. *Mankind so far* (American Museum of Natural History science series, 5.) Garden City, New York: Doubleday, Doran and Company, 1945. Pp. xii, 319. A lucid, witty, and well-written description of the development of mankind, stressing the biological change and evolution from earliest times to the various "races" of today. His chapter on the American Indians is a particularly useful summary of their origin and diversity in type.

*The origins of American Indian race types.* (In the Maya and their neighbours, New York, D. Appleton-Century Company, 1940, 8-9.) An analysis of the basic factors underlying the racial affinities of the American Indian.
Institute opens hall of man and his culture (Cranbrook Institute of Science news letter, XV (3), Nov., 1945, 26-32). A description of a new gallery at the Cranbrook Institute of Science with photographs of outstanding Indian specimens, some of them from Canada.

Jaeger, Elsworth. Nature adorned the Indian tepee (Nature magazine, XXXVIII (10), Dec., 1945, 545-6). A note on the use of animal and star designs, and their significance, in the painted decoration of the tipi of the Indians of the Plains.

Joblin, E. E. M. Social conditions among the Indians of Ontario at the Eastern Regional Conference of the Fellowship of Indian Workers, Thomas Indian School, Iroquois, N.Y., Oct. 20-22, 1944 [Addresses], 11-17). A general description of social and economic conditions among the Indians of Southern Ontario today.

Jury, Wilfrid. Fairfield on the Thames. (Bulletin of the museums, no. 3, University of Western Ontario, London: University of Western Ontario, 1945. Pp. 35. In 1792 Major Maseres visited the west coast of India followed by Mr. Fairfield on the Thames, establishing a village which was destroyed in the War of 1812. This historic site has been excavated in a thorough, scientific manner by the author and his associates. This report on the work is a credit to the University of Western Ontario as well as to Mr. Jury.

Have you any Indian relics? (Ontario library review and Canadian periodicals index, XXVIII (4), Nov., 1944, 388-92). A plea for the acceptance and adequate display of Indian material as a normal part of library activities.

Kennedy, G. A. The last battle (Alberta folklore quarterly, I (2), June, 1946, 57-60). A description, reprinted from the Lethbridge News of April 30, 1890, of a fight between the Blackfoot and the Cree in 1870, said to have been the last battle between Indian tribes in Canada.

Kietham, Edward L. Igloo tales. (Alaska series, I.) Washington: United States Indian Service, Education Division, 1944. Pp. 122. (90c.) This is a delightful collection of stories written by Mr. Keitham with the aid of his Eskimo school children in Alaska. They are recorded in simple, readable form and illustrated with imagination in Eskimo style, by an Eskimo artist. This volume is brought out in conformity with the policy of the United States Indian Service in describing aspects of native life as part of the government's educational system.

Kihn, Wm. Lawrence. Totem-pole builders (National geographic magazine, LXXXVII (1), Jan., 1945, 33-48). A series of attractive paintings of the west coast Indians and their activities. Painted to illustrate customs which have passed away, such as whaling from dug-out canoes, the artist shows accuracy and care, as well as imagination and artistic skill, in his depictions.

Kroeber, A. L. Anthropological research in Ibero-America and Anglo-America (Congress of Americanists, LIVII (1), 1942, 81-91). In Canada and the United States the Indian population is officially classified as a cultural minority, whereas it is a dominant element in all the countries south of the Rio Grande. Corresponding to this basic fact, anthropological investigation in the north has dealt largely with survivals, or with decaying cultures, necessitating techniques unnecessary in Middle and South American work.

Lacourciere, Luc. Les Etudes de folklore francais au Canada (Culture, VI (1), mars, 1945, 6-9). Reference made recently, there is now considerable activity in the field of folklore in Quebec; significant of this interest is the establishment of a Chair of Folklore at Laval University.

Laviolette, Gontran. The Sioux Indians in Canada. Regina: Marian Press, 1944. Pp. iv, 138. Reviewed in C.H.R., XXVI (2), June, 1945, 203-4.

Leechman, Douglas. Igloo and igluh (Beaver, outfit 275, March, 1945, 36-39). A popular, well-illustrated description of the various types of house used by the Eskimo.
Leechman, Douglas. *The savages of James Bay* (Beaver, outfit 276, June, 1945, 14-7). A brief, illustrated description of the Cree Indians of James Bay.

Lefebvre, Jean-Jacques. *Deux Descriptions ethnographiques des Canadiens* (B.R.H., I, (1), 2), janv.-fév. 1945, 75). In 1830 there appeared in the *Larousse du XXe siècle* a revised edition of the first of these compositions of the Canadian people. Presumably as a result of a protest, the note was revised in the 1834 edition.

Linquist, G. E. E. *The Indians in American life*. New York: Friendship Press, 1944. Pp. xi, 180. The author shows how the Canadian and United States are facing economic and social problems in a changing world. The author describes many of their legal advantages and disadvantages in both countries, showing the extent to which these depend on their history and on the history of white-Indian contact. Similar chapters discuss economic conditions, education, and, rather more extensively, the contribution of Christianity to Indian life. A chapter on the culture areas of North America, as a background for understanding the varied problems of the American Indians, is contributed by Dr. Erna Gunther.

Lopatin, Ivan A. *Social life and religion of the Indians in Kitimat, British Columbia*. (University of Southern California social science series, 26.) Los Angeles: University of Southern California. 1945. Pp. 118, 18 illus., 1 map. To be reviewed later.

Lowie, Robert H. *American contributions to anthropology* (Science, C (2,598), Oct. 13, 1944, 321-7). A scholarly summary and appraisal of the contributions of American anthropologists to the science throughout the world.

Lyford, Carrie A. *The crafts of the Ojibwa*. (Indian handcrafts, 6.) Washington: United States Office of Indian Affairs, Education Division. 1945. Pp. 916, (6c.) This is one of the series of pamphlets issued by the United States Office of Indian Affairs describing adequately, but in simple language, the crafts of a particular area. Houses for preparing, the making of hides and arrows, canoes, drums, snow-shoes, and baskets, the preparation of skin and tanning, various types of weaving, and bead-work are among the subjects included. There is a particularly good chapter on the making of designs. This volume is prepared primarily for use in Indian schools, but the gathering together of the material from diverse sources makes it a valuable volume to the anthropologist and, conversely, shows the value of ethnological data in the classroom. The processes are beautifully illustrated largely from data collected in Wisconsin and Minnesota, whereas the Ojibwa are a tribe of western Ontario woodlands as well as of adjacent states south of the American border. This volume serves as a convenient and authoritative handbook for Canada as well as the United States.

Iroquois crafts. (Indian handcrafts, 6.) Washington: United States Office of Indian Affairs, Education Division. 1945. Pp. 97, (5c.) This is one of a series of volumes prepared for use in Federal Indian schools utilizing illustrations and descriptions of Indian crafts for the education of Indian children. The author describes post-Columbian Iroquois houses, foods, clothing, ritual objects, and games as well as the earlier use of bone, clay, wood, and bark. There is a particularly good chapter on art, well illustrated with designs.

MacLeod, Margaret Anne, Nutt, Grace Lee, and Wilson, Clifford. *Peter Rindfleischer Red River artist* (River book 270, etc., 1946, 30c.) A symposium on the life and work of Peter Rindfleischer, who came to the Red River settlement in 1821. His drawings are the first accurate depictions of Indian life in what is now Manitoba.

McGill, H. W. *Indian Affairs Branch* (in Canada, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Report of the Department of Mines and Resources, Report of Soldier Settlement of Canada for the fiscal year ended March 31, 1945, 146-p. Ottawa: King's Printer, 1945). An improvement in the economic conditions of the Indians of Canada is reflected in the annual government report on Indian affairs. The customary details of population, occupation, income, and health are ably reported.
RECENT PUBLICATIONS RELATING TO CANADA

McGILL UNIVERSITY MUSEUMS. Indians of Canada. Montreal: McGill University Museums, 1945. 1 sheet. A brief leaflet showing the location of the principal Indian tribes of Canada and significant elements of their culture.

MANGELSDORF, P. C., and REEVES, R. G. The origin of maize. Present status of the problem (American anthropologist, XLVII (2), April-June, 1945, 285-48). A further contribution to the vexed problem of the origin of maize.

MANNING, T. H. and E.W. The preparation of skins and clothing in the eastern Canadian Arctic (The polar record, XXVIII, July, 1944, 156-69). A thorough and practical description of the preparation of skins and the manufacture of clothing, with patterns included, among the Eskimo of the eastern Arctic.

MARSH, D. B. Atamoya (Beaver, outfit 276, Sept., 1945, 44-5). Photographs and notes on the gathering and preparation of ground cranberry leaves, which are smoked by the Eskimo.

MARTINEZ DEL RIO, PAUL. The antiquity of maize cultivation in America (Congreso Internacional de Americanistas, XXVI (3), 1942, 92-5). Botanists believe that the cultivation of maize must have been begun at an earlier period than is usually allowed by archaeologists; the author points out that certain practices in planting and seed selection may have accelerated the biological modifications which would harm the botanical and archaeological dating.

MELANCON, CLAUDE. La Mythologie des Bella-Coola (Revue de l'Université d'Ottawa, XV (2), avril-juin, 1945, 180-97). A somewhat philosophical discussion of Bella Coola (British Columbia) mythology, as recorded by Boas many years ago, in which the author points out resemblances in style, scope, and content to the classical legends of Greece and Rome.

MIDDLETON, S. H. The story of the Blood Indians (Alberta folklore quarterly, 1 (3), Sept., 1945, 85-8). A popular and non-scientific description of the Blood Indians of Alberta.

MOORE, ANDREW. Arctic survey. II. Survey of education in the Mackenzie district (C.I.E.P.S., XI (1), Feb., 1945, 61-82). A careful study of educational facilities in the Mackenzie valley, with specific long-term suggestions for their improvement. Indian and white problems are both considered.

NADEAU, GABRIEL. Indian scalping technique in different tribes (Ciba symposia, V (10), Jan., 1944, 1,677-81). An analysis and description of various methods of scalping, complete and partial, practised in different areas of North America.

NICHOLSON, GEORGE. Ungava Bay (Canadian churchman, LXXII (2-0), Jan. 11-March 1, 1945). A series of descriptions of missionary activities.

NORCROSS, E. BLANCHE. The Cowichan sweater (Beaver, outfit 276, Dec., 1945, 18-19). Utilizing black sheep's wool, the Cowichan Indians of Vancouver Island have developed a distinctive type of knitted sweater which is proving a valuable economic asset to the small community.

PARKER, ARTHUR C. The Six Nations look at wardship (Eastern Regional Conference of the Fellowship of Indian Workers, Thomas Indian School, Iroquois, N.Y., Oct. 20-22, 1944 [Addresses], 24-8). A thoughtful commentary on the advantages, disadvantages, and effects of wardship among the Iroquois of New York State.

PAUL, FRANCES. Spruce root basketry of the Alaska Tingit. (Indian handcrafts, 8.) Washington: United States Indian Service, Education Division, 1944. Pp. 80. (30c.) This is a rare book, and will be highly desirable. Tingit spruce root basketry, a skilled craft that has almost disappeared. Full details are given of the selection, collection, and preparation of materials; of the shapes, uses, and reputed origins of different types of baskets and baskery hats; of the weaves; and of the designs and their name. This is one of the excellent hand-books prepared primarily
for use in United States Indian schools, but it is a volume which warrants wider recognition.

POLLARD, LANCASTER. *A Pacific Northwest bibliography* (Pacific Northwest quarterly, XXXVI (2), April, 1945, 133-42). A historical bibliography of the North-West containing a section on anthropology.

QUIMBY, GEORGE L. JR. *Aleutian Islanders.* (Chicago Natural History Museum, anthropology leaflet, 35.) Chicago: Chicago Natural History Museum, 1944. Pp. 48. An attractive and well-illustrated account of the Aleuts, a specialized group of Eskimos whose culture declined rapidly as a result of European contact and about whom little information has been available in accessible form.

Periods of prehistoric art in the Aleutian Islands (American antiquity, XI (2), Oct., 1945). Artifacts from a rich site at Dutch Harbor, Alaska, indicate at least two styles of Aleut art; the earlier resembles the Desert culture of the eastern Arctic, providing further evidence of the latter's probable Bering Strait, or even Siberian, origin.

RANSOM, JAY ELLIS. *Aleut religious beliefs: Veniaminov's account* (Journal of American folklore, LVIII (230), Oct.-Dec., 1945, 346-9). A description of Aleut religious beliefs translated from a Russian treatise by Veniaminov which was published in 1840.

RAVENHILL, ALICE. *A corner stone of Canadian culture: An outline of the arts and crafts of the Indian tribes of British Columbia.* (Occasional papers of the British Columbia Provincial Museum, 5.) Victoria: King's Printer, 1944. Pp. vi, 104 (multigraphed). Reviewed in C.H.R., XXVI (2), June, 1945, 203.

RAY, VERN F. *The contury behavior pattern in American Indian ceremonialism* (Southwestern journal of anthropology, 1 (1), spring, 1945, 75-113). In this scholarly study of the distribution and probable origin of various types of clowning, buffoonery, and peculiar behaviour practised in the rituals of various Indian groups, the author notes the occurrence of one form among Algonkian tribes of Ontario.

REEVES, R. G. *Chromosome knobs in relation to the origin of maize* (Genetics, XXXIX (2), March, 1944, 141-7). A genetic study of the types of chromosome found in maize supports the thesis that the plant was first cultivated in South America.

RITCHIE, WILLIAM A. *Ritchie to Johnson* (American anthropologist, XLVII (2), April-June, 1945, 325-6). A critical and spirited rebuttal of points brought out in a review by Ritchie of a book by Ritchie (cited in this bibliography, C.H.R., XXVI (1), 98); the author's comments raise questions of methodology in the archaeology of north-eastern America.

REITZENHAUSER, ROBERT. *The acquisition of surnames by the Chippewa Indians* (American anthropologist, XLVII (1), Jan.-March, 1945, 175-7). European surnames were obtained by the Ojibwa of Wisconsin in a variety of ways.

The *ceremonial distribution of sickness by the Wisconsin Chippewa* (American anthropologist, XLVII (2), April-June, 1945, 320-2). Sympathetic magic has recently been practised publicly by the Ojibwa of Wisconsin as a means of counteracting malaria among American troops in the south Pacific.

*Totemic injuries among the Wisconsin Chippewa* (American anthropologist, XLVII (2), April-June, 1945, 322-4). A description of methods employed by the Ojibwa of Wisconsin to punish, or shame, those who had insulted a clan totem, with comparative notes on similar practices among the Ojibwa of Ontario.

RIVERS-ANDERSON, C. *Eskimos and Red Indians, some of whom are in the armed forces sent over by Canada* (Man, XLV (19-36), March-April, 1945, 47). A note on the population figures and administration of Eskimo and Indians in Canada.
RECENT PUBLICATIONS RELATING TO CANADA

ROBERTS, FRANK H. The new world paleo-Indian (Annual report of the Smithsonian Institution for 1944, 403-38). Washington, Smithsonian Institution, 1945. A slight but revealing reprint of an important article on early types of man in the New World which appeared originally in Acts Americana and was noted in this bibliography, C.H.R., March, 1945, p. 99.

ROBINSON, J. LEWIS. Conquest of the northwest passage by R.C.M.P. Schooner St. Roch (Canadian geographical journal, XXX (2), Feb., 1945, 52-74). A well illustrated and interesting description of the voyage of the St. Roch from Vancouver to Halifax in 1940-42, the first crossing of the Northwest Passage had been covered from west to east. Photographs and comments on the Eskimo are included.

ROBINSON, PIERCY T. Some of Cartier's place-names 1535-1536 (C.H.R., XXVI (4), Dec., 1945, 401-5). A study of the etymology and meaning of a number of Indian place-names recorded by Cartier in the vicinity of Quebec.

ROE, F. G. White buffalo (Transactions of the Royal Society of Canada, XXXVIII, sect. II, 1944, 155-76). Albino buffaloes are known to have occurred rarely on the western plains. The skins of these white animals were highly valued by different tribes.

ROJAS, ALFONSO VILLA. La civilización y el Indio (América indígena, V (1), Enero, 1945, 67-72). Cultural adjustments are constantly taking place among the Indians of the Americas and direct leadership by governments, and by science, is desirable.

SALZ, BEATE. Some considerations on Mr. Collier's article (América indígena, V (3), Julio, 1945, 247-54). A comment on the question of Indian rights and racism, raised in an article by John Collier, cited on p. 96.

SHAPIRO, HARRY L. There's no place like home (Natural history, LVII (1), Jan., 1945, 24-38). An attractive and informative article on native houses, including descriptions of types used in various parts of Canada.

SHEA, BERNARD J. Some methodological considerations for a comparative study of slavery (American anthropologist, XLVII (3), July-Sept., 1945, 357-62). In this scholarly study of the practice of slavery, the author analyses its role among the coastal Indians of British Columbia.

SPEC, FRANK G. Abenaki text (International journal of American linguistics, XI (1), Jan., 1945, 45-6). A short text, with translation, recorded from a St. Francis Abenaki Indian.

The Iroquois—a study in cultural evolution. (Cranbrook Institute of Science, bulletin 23.) Bloomfield Hills, Michigan: Cranbrook Press, 1945. Fp. 94. An authoritative and well written description of the Iroquois, covering both their social organization as deduced from a study of sources. The illustrations from the Cranbrook Institute of Science are well chosen. This volume and Iroquois crafts by Lyford (cited above), give a very satisfactory picture of Iroquois life.

The Iroquois—the historical versus the ethnological view (Cranbrook Institute of Science news letter, XV (3), Nov., 1945, 58-6). The common belief that the Iroquois were brutal warriors whose whole life was spent in attacks on peaceful neighbors is not supported by the evidence. It is widely circulated, but gives a distorted picture of their culture and their role in history.

and DODGE, ERNEST S. Amphibian and reptile lore of the Six Nations Cayuga (Journal of American folklore, LVIII (230), Oct.-Dec., 1945, 306-9). A note on the knowledge of amphibians and reptiles possessed by the Cayuga of the Grand River, Ontario.

STEPHENSON, EVELYN. Within the circle. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons, 1944. Included in this general volume on the Arctic are various facts concerning the Eskimo.
THE CANADIAN HISTORICAL REVIEW

STEWART, JULIAN H. *The changing American Indian* (The science of man in the world crisis, Linton, Ralph, Ed., New York, Columbia University Press, 1945, 282-305.) An appraisal of current Indian problems, including cultural change, government and racial attitudes, population growth, and economic conditions.

STIRLING, MATTHEW W. *Indians of our north Pacific coast* (National geographic magazine, LXXXVII (1), Jan., 1948, pp. 46-60). A highly authoritative but popularly written description of the Indians of the north-west coast.

STRONG, W.M. DUNCAN. *The occurrence and wider implications of a "bear cult" on the Columbia River suggested by carvings in wood, bone and stone* (American anthropologist, XLVII (2), April-June, 1945, 244-61). Little known carvings and sculpture from the Columbia valley show resemblances to art forms of the Indians of British Columbia, and may perhaps be associated with a Ghost Cult.

TAYLOR, GRIFFITH. *Arctic survey. III. A Mackenzie domesday: 1944* (C.J.E.P.S., XI (2), Oct., 1947, 185-203). Among other facts placed on record in this survey of the patterns of settlement in the Mackenzie valley are observations on where and in what style of houses Indian and Eskimo families are living.

THALBITZER, WILLIAM. *Is Eskimo a primitive language?* (Actes du quatrième congrès international de linguistes, Copenhagen, 1938, 354-62). The Eskimo language comprises a distinctive stock, to which Aleut is related; in no sense of the word can it be described as "simple."

UNDERHILL, RUTH. *Indians of the Pacific northwest.* (Indian life and customs, 5.) Washington: Educational Division of the United States Office of Indian Affairs. 1949. Pp. 228. This is one of the most stimulating and attractive books that I have read for a long time, and it is one that I shall recommend to my students with enthusiasm. It belongs to a series prepared by the United States Indian Service primarily for use in schools, but it is so well written and so full of simple, informative, and accurate descriptions of Indians and their life in different parts of the United States. Miss Underhill's theme is the Indians of Oregon and Washington, but she points out that they are a part of the whole Northwest coast area. In fact, she might mention that all the aborigines is characteristic of British Columbian coastal tribes. The author is to be congratulated on giving adequate description without unnecessary details, on preserving, yet not indulging in undue linearities, the tales and legends, quoting, for example, in handsome terms from a canoe with a shell-tipped harpoon; in showing the skill necessary in native craftsmanship; in stressing the dependence of the Indians on supernaturalism; and, perhaps most of all, in preserving the dignity of the Indians from the rich hunting and fishing life of a century ago to the reservation existence of today, again, with understanding and sympathy, but without false sentiment. Miss Underhill's style is simple and direct, holding the reader's attention throughout. The illustrations (which include, by the way, things of the Paul Kane paintings in the Royal Ontario Museum of Archaeology, Toronto) are numerous and well-chosen, and the large line drawings of fish-traps, houses, and manufactured products are better than I have seen in most ethnical publications. The page and printing are worthy of the text; briefly, this is a most satisfactory book in every respect.

United States Office of Indian Affairs, Education Division. *Indian: yesterday and today.* (Information Pamphlet, I.) Washington: Office of Indian Affairs. 1941. Pp. 74. (15c.) The basis of this volume is a series of radio broadcasts prepared by the United States Office of Indian Affairs for use in schools. The introductory chapters fulfill this purpose almost perfectly; they serve as a model of well-selected material on Indian history and background, the kind of information that every high school student should know. The later chapters deal with specific American problems of economics and administration.

VICKERS, CLARK. *Archaeology in the Rock and Pelican Lake area of south-central Manitoba.* (American antiquity, XI (2), Oct., 1945, 88-94). Excavation of a number of sites indicates a series of different cultures. Little archaeological work has been done...
in this region and it is to be hoped that more extensive excavations can be accomplished.

VICKERS, C. A., Archaeology in the Rock and Pelican Lake area of southern Manitoba (Papers read before the Historical and Scientific Society of Manitoba, 1944-45, Winnipeg, 1945, 14-24). A presentation of the same material.

VOEGELIN, C. F., Relative chronology of North American linguistic types (American anthropologist, XLVII (2), April-June, 1945, 232-4). An appraisal of the possibilities and difficulties involved in the attempt to determine the relative age.

and HARRIS, Z. S., Index to the Franz Boas collection of materials for American linguistics. Supplement to Language, XXI (3), July-Sept., 1945. (Language monograph, 22.) Baltimore: Maryland Linguistic Society of America. Pp. 48.

In 1927 the late Professor Franz Boas became chairman of a committee of the American Council of Learned Societies to sponsor the study of American Indian languages and to publish the results of investigations in this field. Between 1927 and 1936 some 100 manuscripts were submitted and worked over. Many manuscripts were published and many more were submitted to Professor Boas who, as a pioneer in American linguistics already was the custodian of other manuscripts in all stages of preparation. The written field notes constitute a comparative study. These manuscripts have been donated to the library of the American Philosophical Society where they have been catalogued and are available to students. The present paper is a valuable record of this collection; each item is described according to tribe, author, size, and relevant facts as to content.

WALKER, EDWIN F., America's Indian background (Michigan, XIX (1, 3, 4), Jan., May, July, 1945, 113, 89-90, 119-20). A non-technical description of the Indians of America and the varying forms of native culture in the New World.

World crops derived from the Indians. (Southwest Museum leaflets, 17.) Los Angeles, 1943. Pp. 16.

WALLACE, PAUL A. W., Conrad Weiser. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 1945. Pp. 648. To be reviewed later.

WHERRITT, G. J., Arctic Survey. I. Survey of health conditions and medical and hospital services in the North West Territories (C.J.E.P.S., XI (1), Feb., 1945, 49-60). A thoughtful appraisal of medical services in the Mackenzie valley, with special reference to Indians and Eskimo.

WISSLER, CLARA, Corn and early American civilization (Natural history, LIV (2), Feb., 1944, 14-46). An interesting and well illustrated description of the probable origin of corn, with a brilliant comparison of the resemblances and differences between the essential traits of Old and New World civilizations, especially in the field of agriculture.

WORMINGTON, H. M., Ancient man in North America. (Colorado Museum of Natural History, popular series, 4.) Denver: Colorado Museum of Natural History, 1944. Pp. 89. A popular, illustrated description of the discoveries of early man in America.
ANNUAL LIST OF PUBLICATIONS ON ETHNOLOGY, ANTHROPOLOGY, AND ARCHAEOLOGY

BY

T. F. McILWRAITH

Reprinted from
The Canadian Historical Review
March, 1945
XII. ETHNOLOGY, ANTHROPOLOGY, AND ARCHAEOLOGY

(Contributed annually since 1925 by Professor T. F. McIlwraith.)

ACKERBERG, ERWIN H., 'White Indians' (Bulletin of the history of medicine, XV (1), Jan., 1944, 15-36). A study of the life histories of eight white children abducted by Indians during the seventeenth and nineteenth centuries. In each case the child, growing up as an Indian, became completely and satisfactorily adjusted to Indian life and refused to return home.

The administration of Indian affairs (Boletin indigenista, IV (2), June, 1944, 107-15). A useful summary of Canadian government administration in regard to Indian affairs.

ALLEN, HOPE EMILY. An Osweida tale (Journal of American folklore, LVII (228), Oct.-Dec., 1944, 280-1). An Iroquois folk-tale.

ARKLE, PERCY W. A study of the Naskapi in Labrador (Oral health, XXXIII (4), April, 1943, 203-6). A semi-popular summary of the results of the examination of some 4,000 teeth among two bands of Naskapi Indians in Labrador.

BARBEAU, MARCEL. Ce manque pas une enchante (Mémoires de la Société Géographique Canadienne-Française, I (1), Jan., 1944, 1-17). An interesting study of diet in French Canada, particularly in the eighteenth century, showing the influence of Indian and English foods upon the French menu.

French Canadian trade goods (Beaver, outfit 274, Sept., 1944, 14-19). Following the union of the Hudson's Bay Company and the North West Company in 1821, extensive use was made of trade goods manufactured in Montreal, instead of relying exclusively on imports from England.

French Canadian folk-songs (Musical quarterly, XXIX (1), Jan., 1943, 122-37).

From gold threads to porcupine quills (Antiques [Boston], Jan., 1944, 24-6).

How the raven stole the sun (Transactions of the Royal Society of Canada, XXXVII, sec. 2, May, 1944, 59-69). One of the feats of Raven, a culture hero of the Haida, was his theft of the sun. Incidents of this myth have been shown on totem-poles and in argillite carvings, many of them of outstanding artistic excellency.

Mountain cloud. Caldwell Idaho: The Camel Priests; Toronto: Macmillan Company of Canada, 1944. (80 pp.) This novel is worthy of inclusion in a bibliography for its accurate descriptions of Indian life in the Liard River area.

Sea otter skins of the seas (Beaver, outfit 276, Dec., 1944, 20-3). Sea otter skins were used extensively by the coastal Indians of British Columbia, and their great value in the Chinese market led the Russians, and later the English, to the profitable hunting grounds of the North Pacific. The animal was almost exterminated, the Indians were forced into use of other skins, but the sea otter played an important part in the opening of China to foreign trade.

Totemism, a modern growth in the North Pacific (Journal of American folklore, XVII (1), March, 1944, 51-8). A study of the history of North-west Coast totemic art, much of which is of modern origin and strongly influenced by Russian contacts in the eighteenth century.

Tobacco for the fur trade (Beaver, outfit 274, March, 1944, 86-9). Tobacco was a valuable article of trade from the time of the early posts; most of it was imported from Brazil and later from Virginia.

Tobacco for the fur trade (The lighter, Department of Agriculture, Ottawa [unpublished], XIV (2), May, 1944, 13-15). A reprint of the article in the Beaver cited above.
BARNETT, H. G. *Underground houses on the British Columbian coast* (American antiquity, IX (3), Jan., 1944, 265-70). Evidence of the existence of subterranean houses among the coastal Indians of southern British Columbia raises interesting problems of the distribution and spread of this type of habitation.

BARRANTES, EMILIO. *Conceptos fundamentales sobre la educación del Indio* (America indigena, IV (1), Jan., 1944, 48-54). A thoughtful study of Indian education, a problem having many similarities in all American countries with any considerable native population.

BELCOEUR, translated by J. A. BURGESSON. *Buffalo hunt* (Beaver, outfit 276, Dec., 1944, 13-17). A vivid account of bison hunting on the Plains in 1845, including details of the method of butchering and preparing the meat; Father Belcourt's description was written as a letter to a friend and published in Quebec in 1847.

BLESTING, FRED K., Jr. *A glossary of a Minnesota Ojibway dialect* (Minnesota archaeologist [unnumbered], X (1), Jan., 1944, 3-66). A lengthy list of Ojibwa words in a dialect spoken in Minnesota.

BURGESS, J. ALLAN. *The woman and the child among the Lac-St.-Jean Montagnais* (Primitive man, XVII (1, 2), Jan. and April, 1944, 1-18). An intimate description of the position of women and the training of children among the Montagnais of the Lac St. John area. This is a valuable account based on long first-hand knowledge of the people concerned.

CAMERON, W. BLEASDELL. *Gian McKay in the west* (Beaver, outfit 275, Sept., 1944, 3-7). This account of the services of the McKay family to the Hudson's Bay Company contains a description of the Indian uprising at Battleford in 1885.

CAMPBELL, GEORGE MUNROE. *Campbell's original Indian dictionary of the Ojibway or Chippewa language.* Minneapolis: Argus Publishing Co. 1940. Pp. 80. A dictionary written by an Ojibwa, containing miscellaneous facts as well as linguistic material.

COBB, W. MONTAGUE. *Bibliography in physical anthropology: July 1, 1943 through June 30, 1944* (American journal of physical anthropology, new series II (4), Dec., 1944, 381-413). A comprehensive bibliography, with special reference to the Indians of America.

COLBERT, MILDRED. *Kultos, Chinook type.* Boston: D. C. Heath and Co. 1942. Pp. 228, illustrations. A well-written and interesting book for children describing Northwest Coast Indian life and legends.

DELOREY, ELLA CARE. *Dakota treatment of murderers* (Proceedings of the American Philosophical Society, LXXXVIII (5), Nov. 7, 1944, 868-71). A study of Dakota (Sioux) practice respecting the punishment of murderers which varied according to whether the offender was, or was not, a member of the victim's family.

DENNY, SIR CECIL. *Blackfoot magic* (Beaver, outfit 275, Sept., 1944, 14-15). Incidents of Blackfoot shamanistic practices in the seventies.

DENSMORE, FRANCES. *Music of the Indians of British Columbia* (Bureau of American Ethnology, Bulletin 136, Anthropological papers, 27, Washington, 1943, 1-99). A collection of more than eighty songs from different tribes of British Columbia, recorded with music and musical analysis, and of extensive ethnological data on objects and matters referred to in the songs. Miss Densmore has studied Indian music in the United States for many years, and her incursion into the Canadian field is welcome both in respect to the collection of rare vanishing material, and as an example of international scientific co-operation.

Traces of foreign influence in the music of the American Indians (American anthropologist, XVI (1), Jan., 1944, 106-12). Elements in American Indian music which can be traced to European sources are an objective means of tracing some aspects of the course and extent of contact.
RECENT PUBLICATIONS

Drucker, Philip. Archeological survey on the northern northwest coast, with appendix by Fisher, Edna M., Early vertebrate fauna of the British Columbia coast (Bureau of American Ethnology, Bulletin 138, Anthropological papers, Washington, 1943, 17-149). This report presents an excellent contribution to the study of the little-known archaeology of the North-west Coast. The results of excavations at various sites are given, together with an analysis of tool forms based on museum material.

Dutilly, Arthème. An inexhaustible source of linguistic knowledge (Proceedings of the American Philosophical Society, LXXXVII (5), May 5, 1944, 403-6). A summary of linguistic work, including manuscript material, recorded by missionaries among the Indians of Canada.

Edwards, Everett E. and Rasmussen, Wayne D. A bibliography on the agriculture of the American Indians (United States Department of Agriculture, Miscellaneous Publication no. 447.) Washington: Government Printing Office, Jan., 1942. Pp. 10. This is concerned mainly with ancient studies; the use by the American Indians of both cultivated and wild plants. The material is arranged: (a) On a regional basis, (b) On a tribal basis, (c) According to specific crops, (d) According to developments on reservations in the United States, and (e) The use of wild plants. One striking conclusion of the authors is that approximately four-fifths of the farm crops of the United States are plants derived from the Indians.

Ewers, John C. The Blackfoot war lodge: Its construction and use (American anthropologist, XLVI (2), April-June, 1944, 103-106). On raiding expeditions the Blackfoot and other tribes of the northern Plains used bark-covered lodges which they erected in wooded valleys or 'islands' of timber; in fact, wood was utilized more commonly than is generally recognized.

Some winter games of Blackfoot Indian children (Masterkey, XVIII (6), Nov., 1943, 108-110). A description of children's activities and games among the Blackfoot.

The toys of the Blackfoot. (United States Indian Service, Education Division; Indian life and customs pamphlet, no. 6.) Lawrence, Kansas: United States Indian Service, Haskell Institute. Nov., 1944. Pp. 66. A well illustrated and scholarly description of the Blackfoot, written and presented in a traditional manner. The historical approach has been used throughout by describing the activities of the Blackfoot at different periods, concluding with life on the reservations today.

Fenton, William N. Simeon Gibson: Iroquois informant, 1865-1941 (American anthropologist, XLVI (2), April-June, 1944, 101-4). A biography of an Iroquois of the Grand River who, as interpreter, informant, and adviser to successive ethnologists, has played a significant part in the recording of details of Iroquois culture.

Food and health of Eskimos and Lapps (British medical journal, II 1943 (4310), Aug., 1943, 207). A brief note on the food habits of the Eskimo of Greenland and Labrador, compared with those of the Lapps of Lapland and Sweden.

Foster, Mrs. W. Garland. The Katsinam masks (Canadian geographical journal, XXVIII (2), Feb., 1944, 84-7). An illustrated description of masks belonging to three generations of Squamish Indians from southern British Columbia.

Friend, Emma Jane. Making birchbark transparencies (American anthropologist, XLVI (1), part 1), Jan.-March, 1944, 149-50). The use of birchbark transparencies as art stencils is well known, but the author records a game in which a child weaves a story around designs made in this way.

Giddings, J. L., Jr. Dated Eskimo ruins of an inland zone (American antiquity, X (2), Oct., 1944, 113-34). Archaeological investigations in the Kobuk River area of Alaska disclose an early, highly specialized, inland culture, having traits indicative of Indian influence.

Some climatic aspects of tree growth in Alaska (Tree-ring bulletin, IX (4), 1943, 26-32).
HEIZER, ROBERT F. *Acornite points whaling in Asia and America: An Allotopic transfer to the new world.* American Anthropology Bulletin 138, Anthropological papers no. 24, Washington, 1943, pp. 61-68. A comprehensive and scholarly study of the distribution of acornite points and whaling leads to the conclusion that the method developed in the Old World and spread to America via the Aleutian Islands, affording further evidence of contact between the two continents by that route.

Artifact transport by migratory animals and other means (American Antiquity IX (4), April, 1944, pp. 275-276). Artifacts giving instances of the transportation over long distances of projectile heads and other artifacts imbedded in the bodies of animals; whales and other marine mammals are particularly important as involuntary distributors of archaeological specimens.

HERNÁNDEZ DE ALBA, GREGORIO. *La indigena como objeto americano* (America indigena IV (3), July, 1944, pp. 5-15). Widespread cultural resemblances in pre-Columbian Mexico among the Indians of America point to a basic unity, and suggest the desirability of a similar approach to their problems of today.

HEWITT, J. N. B. [ed., by WILLIAM N. FENTON]. The requiemizing address of the Iroquois condolence council (Journal of the Washington Academy of Sciences, XXXIV (3), March 15, 1944, pp. 65-80). A scholarly and thorough description of one of the most important Iroquois rituals, prepared by the late J. N. B. Hewitt and adequately revised and amplified.

HUBBEN, FRANK C. Our search for the earliest Americans (Harper's magazine, CLXXXIX (1130), July, 1944, pp. 130-136). Archaeological discoveries in two localities in Alaska, Christina Bay and the mouth of the Yukon, have revealed Paleoindian points and masses of bones of mammoth and other extinct mammals.

HILGER, SOR M. INEZ. Ceremonia para dar nombre a un niño Indio Chippewa (America indigena, IV (3), July, 1944, pp. 237-242). A detailed description of the selection and bestowal of a name among the Ojibwa.

Chippewa funeral and mourning customs (American anthropologist, XLVI (4), Oct.-Dec., 1944, pp. 564-568). A description of an Ojibwa funeral showing a blend of Indian and modern American practices.

HILL, JASPER. The manifesto of the Indian Council Fire (Boletin indigena, IV (4), Dec., 1944, pp. 269-272). A statement of the aims of the Indian Council Fire of Canada, an organization seeking to promote fellowship and joint action among the Indians of Canada.

HOWAY, F. W. Origin of the Chinook jargon on the north west coast (Oregon historical quarterly, XLIV (1), March, 1943, pp. 27-55). A reprint of an earlier article originally published in the English Canadian Historical Quarterly (and cited C.H.R., XXVIII, May-June, 1943, pp. 102), showing that the Chinook jargon developed after the arrival of the white man as a result of contact between maritime fur traders and various coastal tribes.

HERDIEKA, ALEX. Alaska diary. Lancaster, Pa.: Jaques Cattell Press, 1943. Pp. xvi, 414, 232 illustrations. Reviewed in C.H.R., XXVIII, May-June, 1943, pp. 146-147.

Catalogue of human remains in the United States National Museum collections: New Guinea, Melanesia, the northwest coast, Alaska, and Siberia. (Proceedings of the United States National Museum, XCIV, no. 3171, 1-172.) Washington: Smithsonian Institution, 1944. Pp. vii, 1-172. This catalogue comprises detailed measurements of the crania from the Aleutian Islands, Alaska, and British Columbia in the United States National Museum, with comparable data obtained from Russian museum collections. Such examination shows greater diversity in Alaska than was previously known, including a pure Aleut population in the Aleutians similar to American Indian types, whereas the modern Aleutian Islanders resemble Siberian tribesmen.
IMBERLONI, JOSÉ. *The peopling of America* (Acta Americana, I (3), July-Sept., 1943, pp. 809-820). Contrary to generally accepted views, the author believes that there are diverse strains in the population of America, and that the Mongoloid is by no means dominant.

Indians are allies rather than subjects (Boletin indigenista, IV (1), March, 1944, pp. 19-31). A reprint of a letter to the editor of a Montreal newspaper, stressing that the Iroquois of Caughnawaga are allies of the Crown, not subjects of Canada.

JARGER, ELLSWORTH. *The way of the false face* (School arts, XLIII (3), Nov., 1943, pp. 92-93). A popular note on Indian masks and their use, particularly among the Iroquois.

JENNESS, DESMOND (ed.). *The Eskimos: Their past and future* (Queen's quarterly, L (2), summer, 1944, pp. 132-148). A scholarly summary of Eskimo history, based on the results of archaeological investigations and deductions.

JENNESS, DIAMOND. *The Carrier Indians of the Bulkley River: Their social and religious life* (Bureau of American Ethnology Bulletin 133, Anthropological papers, 25, Washington, 1944, pp. 686). A report and field description of the Heiltsuk-Sitcometne, the most westerly branch of the Carriers, living in the Bulkley River valley, an affluent of the Skeena, in northern British Columbia. This thorough study of their social and religious life, particularly important as it is in showing the modifications which have resulted from contact with coastal tribes, for example, in the importance of crests, phatries, and the potlatch system. The field work on which this report is based was carried out for the National Museum of Canada in 1924-25.

— Grammatical notes on some western Eskimo dialects. (Report of the Canadian Arctic Expedition, 1913-16; Vol. XV: Eskimo language, Part 3) Ottawa: King's Printer, 1944, pp. 1-34. This paper deals largely with the grammar of the Eskimo of the Barrow district, Alaska, with shorter studies and comments on other western Eskimo languages. The material was collected during the Canadian Arctic Expedition of 1913-16. Publication has been better than never, but a delay of nearly thirty years is not to the credit of Canada.

JOHNSTON, J. WALTER. *Adventure in Alaska: Social pioneering among the Eskimos*. Philadelphia: Dorrance and Company, 1944. Pp. 325; 71 plates. ($3.00). The Reverend T. L. Brevig, a Norwegian Lutheran clergyman, served as a missionary to the Eskimo of Point Barrow from 1894 to 1917. This volume is based on extracts from his daily journal.

JURY, WILFRID. *Old Fairfield on the Thames* (C.H.R., XXV (4), Dec., 1944, pp. 409-410). A description of an important area of historical archaeological work at Fairfield, Kent County, Ontario, where a Moravian mission was established in 1702, the first Protestant mission in Upper Canada. Excavations have definitely located the site and made clear many details of the plan of the village and its individual houses.

KELEMAN, PAL. *Medieval American art*. New York: Macmillan Company, 1943. Vol. I, pp. xiv, 414; Vol. II, 306 plates, pp. 33. This is a monumental study of native American art, covering the period from the earliest cultures to the metal and stone-working, and a variety of applied arts. The author shows the significance of American artists and craftsmen in relation to other parts of the world, finding that the Indians had their own stand of characteristics which has been proven elsewhere and, though of independent origin, can be studied in a world setting. The second volume of plates does full justice to the material. Though dealing specifically with the area between New Mexico and Peru, these volumes deserve inclusion in a Canadian Bibliography for their broad outlook on Indian art as a whole.

KIDD, KENNETH. *Pilgrimage of St. Mary*, Margaret Shute's message; VIII (3), Oct., 1944, pp. 181. Details of life at St. Marie, centre of Huron missions in the seventeenth century, can be deduced from carefully excavated objects.
Kirchhoff, Paul. *Comentario al artículo del señor Hernández de Alba* (America indígena, IV (3), July, 1944, 227-31). A careful examination of an article by Hernández de Alba, in which Mr. Kirchhoff criticizes his views of basic pre-Columbian Indian resemblances and stresses the diversity of aboriginal culture.

Kraus, Bertram S. *Acculturation, a new approach to the Iroquoian problem* (American antiquity, IX (8), Jan., 1944, 302-15). Taking as illustration the Neutrals of southwest Ontario, this author expands the value of appraising cultural change in elucidating the history of the Iroquois, indicating its importance in archaeological as well as literary studies.

Kroonan, W. M. *Bibliography in physical anthropology, January 1, 1943 to July 1, 1943* (American journal of physical anthropology, (new series) 1 (4), Dec., 1943, 487-86). A well classified and valuable bibliography.

Learmonth, L. A. *Nets under ice* (Beaver, outfit 275, Dec., 1944, 24-7). A series of photographs of net fishing as practised by the Eskimo of the Coppermine area.

Leechman, Douglas. *John Rostell and the Indians* (Queen's quarterly, LI (1), spring, 1944, 78-7). The earliest description in English of the Indians of eastern Canada appears to be in a comedy play written by Robert Aubrey in 1605. The facts were probably gleaned from fishermen who had visited the Grand Banks.

Longfellow's Hiawatha (Queen's quarterly, LI (3), autumn, 1944, 307-12). For the story of Hiawatha, Longfellow relied upon Schreiber, who wrote with many inaccuracies about the Ojibwa of the Upper Lakes, and not about the Iroquois; while the metre was taken from the Finnish epic, the Kalevala. The result is a masterpiece of imaginative verse, but of no ethnological value.

Royal Society of Canada, XXXVIII, sec. 2, May, 1944, 99-102). Two Indian skulls, one from Lytton and one from the Skeena River, show successful trephining. The technique employed was that of scraping, an ancient method.

Wigwams and traps* (Beaver, outfit 275, Dec., 1944, 28-31). A scholarly and well illustrated description of types of Indian houses used in different parts of Canada.

De Lemos, Pedro. *Indian art craft of the northwest* (School arts, XLIII (3), Nov., 1943, 90-1). A brief, illustrated note on Haida art.

Lindquist, G. E. E. *The Indian in American life*. New York: Friendship Press. 1944. Fp. xii, 180. ($1.00) To be reviewed later.

Linton, Ralph. *North American cooking pots* (American antiquity, IX (4), April, 1944, 369-80). A survey of the distribution and types of clay cooking vessels in North America leads to the conclusion that they developed independently in several areas and were not associated with military or agricultural life.

Lips, Juliette. *Tents in the wilderness: The story of a Labrador Indian boy*. Philadelphia and New York: Frederick A. Stokes Company. 1942. Fp. 297. A lively book for children, written by an anthropologist, describing life among the Naskapi of northern Quebec.

Loram, C. T. and McIlwraith, T. F. *The North American Indian today*. Toronto: University of Toronto Press. 1943. Fp. xii, 361. Reviewed in C.H.R., XXV, Sept., 1944, 327-8.

McGillivray, H. *Indian Affairs Branch* (in Canada, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Report of the Department of Mines and Resources, including Report of Soldier Settlement of Canada, for the fiscal year ended March 31, 1943, Ottawa, King's Printer, 1944, 180-89; and idem, for the fiscal year ended March 31, 1943, Ottawa, King's Printer, 1944, 180-89). These annual government reports contain more than mere statistical summaries of Indian affairs in Canada; they contain a wealth of information on the activities of the Indians, and on the work of the Indian Affairs Branch in fulfilling its obligations as trustee for the aborigines.
MANNING, T. H. *Hunting implements and methods of the present-day Eskimos of north-west Hudson Bay, Melville Peninsula, and south-west Baffin Island* (Geographical Journal, CII (1938), No. 4, 397-526). Details of the hunting and fishing implements and equipment (guns, harpoons, and nets) used today in hunting and fishing by the Eskimo of the eastern Arctic. The description is based on accurate observations made during seven years by a well-trained scientist and is, therefore, of first-rate importance.

MANNING, Max T. H. *Igloo for the night*. London: Hodder and Stoughton Ltd., 1943. Pp. 225. A fascinating description of three years in the eastern Arctic as seen by a woman, with intimate pictures of the rigors of Eskimo life. Reviewed in C.H.R., XXV, March, 1944, 59.

MARKLEY, Max C. *The Iroquois long house, a possible Norse cultural remnant* (Minnesota archaeologist [multilithed], X (2), April, 1944, 76-7). The author points out striking resemblances between Iroquois and Norse houses.

MARSH, D. B. *All this for tea* (Beaver, outfit 275, Dec., 1944, 18-19). Tea has become almost a necessity to the Eskimo of Hudson Bay, but its preparation requires hours of toil to collect enough twigs to boil a kettle.

—*Agua pura* (Beaver, outfit 275, June, 1944, 14-15). A series of excellent photographs with explanatory captions, showing how the Eskimo obtain drinking water by constant chiselling through the ice.

MARTINEZ DEL RIO, Pablo. *Los Origenes Americanos*. Second edition. Mexico, 1943. Pp. 360; 38 maps, figures. This is a thorough revision of a scholarly and objective study of American Indian origins, archaeology, linguistics, and ethnology—an important work by a distinguished Mexican scholar.

MAYER, Joseph R. *Flintlocks of the Iroquois, 1620-1687*. (Rochester Museum of Arts and Sciences, Historical Records, No. 63.) Rochester: Rochester Museum of Arts and Sciences, 1943. Pp. 50, 17 figures. This study is based on 198 fragments of gun material collected from the sites of four Seneca villages which were sacked in 1687. The author breaks new ground in the field of historical archaeology since his study indicates the manner in which guns were used by the Iroquois at that time, and also shows their origin, probably in the Netherlands.

MICHELSON, Truman. *Contributions to Algonquian linguistics* (International journal of American linguistics, X (2/3), Nov., 1939, 75-85). A comparative study of Algonkian linguistic forms.

MONTAGU, M. F. ASHLEY, and Peterson, C. Bernard. *The earliest account of the association of human artifacts with fossil mammals in North America* (Proceedings of the Royal Society of Canada, LXXXVIII (6), May 5, 1944, 10). In 1838 Albert Koch claimed to have discovered human artifacts associated with mastodon remains; though long discredited, it appears probable in the light of modern knowledge that his contention was correct.

MORANT, G. M. *Eskimo craniology* (Nature, CLI (1819), Jan., 1943, 59-60). A review of the catalogue of Eskimo skeletons in United States National Museum with observations on the measurements taken, and the conclusions that can be reached by analysis of craniofacial characteristics.

MORTON, ARTHUR S. *Nipawin, on the Saskatchewan River, and its historic sites* (Transactions of the Royal Society of Canada, XXXVIII, sec. 2, May, 1944, 117-36). The location of Nipawin and two posts of this name, and extracts from documents in the Hudson's Bay Company's archives give interesting details of Indian activities there in the early days.

MURRAY, Raymond W. *Men's unknown ancestors: The story of prehistoric man*. Milwaukee: Bruce Publishing Company, 1943. Pp. xiv, 364. An ambitious attempt to combine and correlate the archaeology of the New and Old Worlds into a single volume.
Norris-Ely, L. T. S., *Indians* (School arts, XLIII (3), April, 1944, 284-5). A brief note, with illustrations, of costumes and ornaments of the Plains Indians collected by Paul Kane a century ago.

Okanagan Society for the Revival of Indian Arts and Crafts. *Native Canadians: A plan for the rehabilitation of Indians, submitted to the Committee on Reconstruction and Re-establishment*, Ottawa. Oliver, B.C.: Okanagan Society for the Revival of Indian Arts and Crafts. This day book contains a report on the first demonstration of Indian problems in post-war adjustments; this thoughtful analysis brings out clearly difficulties experienced by the Indians today and gives specific suggestions for improvement. Historical considerations are recognized and pertinent comparisons drawn to conditions and administration in the United States.

Paalen, Wolfgang, *Totem art* (Dyn [Mexico], 4-5, Dec., 1943, 7-36). A beautifully illustrated description of North-west Coast Indian art, with text explaining its styles, functions, and probable origin.

Pollard, Lancaster, *A Pacific northwest biography*, 1943 (Pacific northwest quarterly, XXXV (2), April, 1943, 157-69). This short biography (the title is a misprint) contains a section on North-west coast archaeology and ethnology.

Rainey, Fredric, *Discovering Alaska's oldest Arctic town* (National geographic magazine, LXIXII (3), Sept., 1942, 318-36). At Ipiutak, near Point Hope in northern Alaska, has been found the remains of an Eskimo town belonging to the Old Bering Sea culture of about the time of Christ. The superb photographs illustrate the wealth of the arts and crafts of the inhabitants of this, one of the earliest, although the most complex, Eskimo culture.

Ravenhill, Alice, *A corner stone of Canadian culture: An outline of the arts and crafts of the native tribes of Canada* (British Columbia Provincial Museum, Occasional Paper No. 5). Victoria: British Columbia Provincial Museum. March, 1944. Pp. 108, 20 plates. Photo-offset. To be reviewed later.

A Resident Nurse, *Medicine dance* (Beaver, outfit 275, June, 1944, 24-5). A chatty account of an Ojibwa conjuring ritual for curing the sick.

Rickard, T. A., *The use of meteoric iron* (Journal of the Royal Anthropological Institute of Great Britain and Ireland, LXVI (1, 2), 1941, 55-66). A survey of the use of meteoric iron by natives in various parts of the world. This was the only kind of iron worked in the New World where it was of considerable importance to the Eskimo.

Ringuet, *Un Monde était leur empire*. Montréal: Les Éditions Varletéa, Dussault et Pléadeau. 1943. Pp. 350. Reviewed in C.H.R., XXV, June, 1944, 214.

Ritchie, William Augustus, *The Pre-Iroquoian occupations of New York State*, (Rochester Museum Memoir, I). Rochester: Rochester Museum of Arts and Sciences. 1944. Pp. xvii, 410, 165 plates. This exhaustive study of archaeological horizons in New York is really an archaeological history of north-eastern America.

Rivers-Anderson, C., *Pottery made by Red Indians* (Man, XLIV, Sept.-Oct., 1944, 127). A brief description of modern pottery-making among the Micmacs of Nova Scotia, a handicraft project initiated as a welfare measure by the government.

Rivet, Paul, *Les Origines de l'homme américain*. Montréal: Les Éditions de l'Arbre, Collection "France Forever". 1943. Pp. 135. A comprehensive and scholarly treatise, embodying the results of geological, anatomical, linguistic, and ethnological studies—Los orígenes del hombre americano. Mexico: Ediciones Cuadernos Americanos. 1943.
RECENT PUBLICATIONS

ROBERTS, FRANK H. M., JR. Evidence for a Paleo-Indian in the new world (Acta Americana, I (2), April-June, 1943, 171-201). A critical appraisal of the evidence concerning the antiquity of man in the New World, as well as the physical types and cultural achievements of these earliest inhabitants. It is clear that man reached America while much of the continent was still covered by Wisconsin ice sheets; that the Paleo-Indians, though contemporaneous with Pleistocene mammals, that these Paleo-Indians were a long-headed variety of the Indian type, and that their tools are to be correlated with prehistoric types of Asia rather than of Europe.

ROBINSON, J. Among the Caribou-eaters (Beaver, outfit 275, Dec., 1944, 38-41). Observations on the life and customs of the Caribou-eaters, an Athapaskan-speaking tribe of the Great Slave Lake area.

ROBINSON, J. LEWIS. Eskimo population in the Canadian eastern Arctic (Canadian geographical journal, XXXIV (3), Sept., 1944, 42-47). Estimates about 6,000 Eskimo in the eastern Arctic; the author gives the location of each group, and concludes that the total population has not changed appreciably in numbers in recent years.

ROBINSON, PERCY J. Montreal to Niagara in the seventeenth century: A philological excursion (Transactions of the Royal Society of Canada, XXXVIII, sec. 2, May, 1944, 137-53). The author gives the derivation and meaning of a number of Ontario place-names of Indian origin.

ROGERS, SPENCER L. Disease concepts in North America (American anthropologist, XLVI (4), Oct.-Dec., 1944, 559-64). An analysis of the distribution of types of disease concepts in North America.

SAUER, CARL O. A geographic sketch of early man in America (Geographical review, XXXIV (4), Oct., 1944, 529-73). An important and scholarly article which goes up from the newest and most complete reviews of the evidence for the antiquity of man in America. The aspects considered include: Pleistocene geology, the association of man with Pleistocene mammals, possible migration routes, similarities and differences in physical types, blood groups, and evidence which can be deduced from studies of archeology and of material culture.

SAVAGE, A. H. Dugald Macdonald. New York: Sheed and Ward, 1942. Pp. xvi, 231. Observations on conditions among the Indians of Hudson Bay in the nineteenth century are included in this description of pioneer missionaries.

SETON, ERNEST THOMPSON. The Arctic prairies: A canoe-journey of 3,000 miles in search of the caribou, being the account of a voyage to the region north of Aylmer Lake. (New edition.) New York: International University Press, 1943. Pp. xii, 308. A reprint of one of the best known volumes on travel in the north, with descriptions of Indians and Eskimos.

SETTLE, FRANK M. Archaeological explorations in the United States, 1930-1942 (Acta Americana, I (2), April-June, 1943, 206-20). As a result of government funds made available for relief projects, archaeological investigations in the United States have been carried out on a scale unprecedented in modern times. Scientific methods have been followed throughout, resulting in satisfactory evidence bearing on the early history of the New World, as well as on the development of native cultures.

SPECK, FRANK G. Indian art handicrafts of eastern Canada (School arts, XLIII (8), April, 1944, 266-70). A brief, but very useful summary of the art crafts of the Indians of Quebec and the Maritime Provinces, both in respect to techniques of manufacture and art motifs.

STEINSSON, VILHJALMUR. The friendly Arctic: The story of five years in polar regions. (New edition.) New York, Toronto: Macmillan Company, 1943. Pp. xxxviii, 812. A new edition of this important and controversial work, with a supplementary chapter summarizing changes in the last twenty years. Reviewed in C.H.R., XXV, March, 1944, 54.
STERLING, MATTHEW W. *Indians of our western plains* (National geographic magazine, LXXXVI (1), July, 1944, 75-83). An authoritative description of the Plains Indians, illustrated with well-selected photographs and a series of striking coloured reproductions of paintings by W. Langdon Kihn.

SULLIVAN, ALAN. *When God came to the Belchers* (Queen's quarterly, LI (1), spring, 1944, 62-68). In religious frenzy caused by a belief in the second coming of Christ, several murders were committed in 1914 by Eskimo of the Belcher Islands in Hudson Bay. This is a vivid account of one of these crimes, as gleaned from the court proceedings, with an account of the trial itself.

T., B. W. *Hudson's Bay Company trade marks* (Minnesota archaeologist [multilithed], X (3), June, 1944, 100). A brief note pointing out that few of the articles traded to the Indians by the Hudson's Bay Company bore any distinctive mark, and are accordingly difficult to recognize.

TAYLOR, ARCHER. *American Indian riddles* (Journal of American folklore, LVII, (223), Jan.-March, 1944, 1-15). A thorough, comparative study of American Indian riddles leads to the conclusion that the use of riddles, though rare, was indigenous to North America; evidence supporting this thesis comes largely from the Huron and the Pen'a.

TRANTER, G. J. *Plowing the Arctic*. London: Hodder and Stoughton. 1944. Pp. 256. The St. Roch, an eighty-ton Royal Canadian Navy Polar patrol vessel commanded by Sgt. Larsen, by sailing from Vancouver to Halifax, was the first vessel to penetrate the Arctic ice pack from west to east. This popular account of an epoch-making voyage contains descriptions of the Eskimo encountered en route, and of conditions in the Arctic today, which, although much, all too often, contrast unfavourably with those under which the Eskimo formerly lived.

VELTEN, H. V. *Three Tlingit stories* (International journal of American linguistics, X (4), Oct., 1944, 169-172). Three stories from southern Alaska carefully recorded in phonetic script with linguistic analysis.

Two southern Tlingit tales (International journal of American linguistics, X (2/3), Nov., 1939, 65-74). A detailed study of two Tlingit tales from southern Alaska, recorded in native script with full grammatical analysis.

VORGELIN, C. F. and VORGELIN, E. W. (comps.). *Map of North American Indian languages* (American Ethnological Society, publication no. 20). American Ethnological Society, in collaboration with Indiana University. New York: J. J. Augustin. 1944. 1 sheet. This is the most comprehensive map that has yet appeared, showing the distribution of American linguistic stocks, and the areas occupied by individual tribes.

WHITING, ALFRED F. *The origin of corn: An evaluation of fact and theory* (American anthropologist, XLVI (6), Oct.-Dec., 1944, 500-15). A critique of theories concerning the origin of corn, a plant of which the place of first cultivation is still uncertain.

WHYTE, WILLIAM FOOTE. *Age-grading of the Plains Indians* (Man, XLIV, May-June, 1944, 68-72). An analysis of age codes among the Plains Indians in relationship to formal societies and other markers of wealth.

WISLEER, CLARK. *The origins of the American Indian* (Natural history, LIII (7), Sept., 1944, 312-20). A beautifully illustrated summary of existing knowledge concerning the Monohoid theories of the American Indian and of the period of his entry to the New World.

held in the office of the Superintendent of
Indian Education, 220 Queen Street, at 9:30 a.m.
on Friday, November 18.

MEMBERS:
Dr. N. W. Morton, (Chairman) Defence Research Board,

Dr. O. E. Ault, Civil Service Commission,
Professor T.F. McIlwraith, University of Toronto,
B. F. Neary, Indian Affairs Branch,
E. Acland, Indian Affairs Branch,
A. J. Doucet, Indian Affairs Branch.

In attendance:
Mr. R. F. Davey, Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia.
Mr. L. Morgan, Assistant Director of Education, Crown Colony of Hong Kong.

(1) Introductory Statements:

Dr. Morton described the meeting held last summer in Dr. Keenleyside's office, at which the need for a group to directly advise the Indian Affairs Branch in social science research was thoroughly discussed.

At this meeting it was decided to establish the panel, whose first meeting was taking place today. Mr. Neary outlined the feeling of the Branch for assistance in the many problems encountered in bringing Canada's Indians into the national stream. Professor McIlwraith expressed the willingness of the Universities to assist in the necessary research to be undertaken.

(2) Purposes and Terms of reference of Panel on Indian Research

There was a general discussion led by Dr. Morton, in which all members expressed their opinions as to the purpose of the panel. It was decided that the panel could best serve by helping to formulate issues or problems which were more immediate and pressing and then assist in having research begun with the initial emphasis on educational matters. Dr. Robbins spoke on the coordination which would be possible with the work being carried out by the Canadian Social Research Council. Professor McIlwraith discussed the range of projects
planned by the Indian Committee of the Canadian Social Research Council and the type of projects in which they were interested. Dr. Ault pointed out the need for coordination between smaller local studies and a Dominion-wide survey.

There was considerable discussion as to the difference of purpose between the Indian Committee of the Canadian Social Research Council and this panel. The general conclusion was that the Indian Committee was more concerned with a broad coverage of the various types of social problems from a scientific point of view and was not particularly concerned with the administrative problems facing the Indian Affairs Branch. The panel, however, was concerned with these problems and with providing professional research and assistance in meeting such problems. Following a review by Mr. Acland of the need for a secretary for the Panel, it was decided to have Mr. Neary carry on these duties at the present time.

(3) Outline of the Present Policies of the Education Division of the Indian Affairs Branch:

This was introduced by Mr. Neary who outlined not only the policies but also the problems confronting the Education Division. This led to expressions of opinion concerning the reserve system and Professor McIlwraith spoke on the problem of assimilation and the need for the retention of native culture and pride of race. This was followed by an interesting interchange of ideas on assimilation with all the panel participating.

(4) Educational Problems on which Investigation is needed.

Dr. Morton introduced this subject and stressed particularly the need for enquiring into "the educability of the Indian child". He pointed out the need for factual information concerning the effective intelligence of Indian children as compared with white children of similar social backgrounds in terms of age and grade level. If there is a gap between Indian children and white children - then to what extent do cultural and social backgrounds contribute?

(5) Ways and Means of Commencing Essential Studies

Pilot Study - Caradoc Reserve, Muncey, Ontario.

It was agreed that the first project to be sponsored would be on the Caradoc Reserve and that this would be a team study with a sociologist and a psychologist both carrying out the research. Their main problem would be as previously defined and would bear directly on the effective intelligence of Indian children as compared with white children of similar social backgrounds, in terms of age and grade levels. There was considerable discussion on whether it would be possible to demonstrate that such a gap was not caused by biological differences. If the problem is not one of heredity, then what are the cultural and social differences which cause this gap? It was decided that there should be an application of Gesell techniques to both Indian and white children of age levels from 6 months and upwards.

This study would be handled by Dr. G. H. Turner, Assistant Professor of Psychology of the University of Western Ontario and by a graduate student under the direction of Dr. Brown of the University of Toronto.
Financing of Research Studies:

It was agreed that there were three main sources of possible revenue for these studies, namely the National Research Council, the Canadian Social Science Research Council and the Indian Affairs Branch. It was decided to provide financial support for the graduate sociology student, Dr. Turner has received a grant from the National Research Council which will make it possible for him to gather some data before the end of the present fiscal year. It was decided to continue further discussion into this general problem of ways and means of commencing essential studies to the next meeting.

The meeting was adjourned at 12.30 p.m., the members to assemble again at the call of the Chairman, probably the 19th of December, 1949.

My dear Neary,

I hope the meeting on Friday was as useful to the members of your department as it was interesting to the outsiders. It occurred to me after our discussion that there was another possible solution to the main problem of discovering good personnel for those northern schools. I was wondering whether you had considered the possibility of a kind of in-service training for people with either normal school or teacher training background. As you are probably aware, the Department of Justice has been providing in-training facilities for wardens and instructors on the Penitentiary Force. It occurred to me that something of this procedure might be used for preparing good young teachers to take on this responsibility of dealing with the Eskimo bands and the Northern Indian bands. Would it not be possible to select one or more of our Canadian anthropologists, have them come to Ottawa for a month or two to draw together the materials available in the departmental files, and then to lay out a specialized training program to cover 8 or 12 weeks. Once the program were drawn up, it could be shared by one or more of the Canadian Anthropologists and the inroads on their academic time would not be too severe.

The thought came to me on the train coming back; these anthropologists would be too modest to volunteer such responsibility. However, if it becomes impossible to persuade the kind of persons who have a social science background to take the added pedagogy, the above suggestion might be a possible substitute.

If you come to Montreal in the near future, would you let us know in advance. Professor Vogt and I would very much enjoy talking over with you some features of the Caughnawaga situation.

I am returning the expense account which your secretary prepared.

With all good wishes,

Cordially,

Oswald Hall.

(2) Social Science Studies
This item on the agenda was introduced by a discussion on the procedure for the making of application for National Research Council grants. Dr. Morton outlined in some detail the steps to be taken in this connection.

(3) The Educability of the Indians of the Caradoc Reserve
Dr. Turner reviewed the initial progress of the Caradoc study and told of his discussions with Dr. Long of O.C.E. concerning the types of tests which would be used. Professor McIlwraith advised that the Indian Committee of the Canadian Social Research Council was recommending a grant for Dr. Brown's study at Caradoc and that this matter would soon be considered by the "Grants and Aids Committee" of the Council. It was expected that Dr. Brown and a graduate student would be in the field in June.
