June 6/50 - E.M.
These initial statements were followed by a discussion as to the way in which these two studies could best be closely coordinated. This was followed by considerable discussion as to the rates of payment for graduate students. Professor McIlwraith and Professor Hall outlined the difficulties encountered in interesting graduate students in research projects allowing for about $100 a month, which was regarded as a training salary. It was difficult to interest graduate students when higher salaries were available in other summer jobs.

(4) Socialization Processes Among the Iroquois

Dr. Rioux outlined this study which is being carried out by the National Museum of Canada. Members saw the questionnaire on child training which is to be sent to teachers of schools on the Six Nations Reserve. The main purpose of this questionnaire is to establish behaviour patterns among the Iroquois of the Grand River Reserve. There was some discussion concerning the integration of this study with the one being done at Caradoc. It was suggested that there be an initial trial with two or three selected teachers. This would permit decisions being made for the orientation and interpretation of the results of the questions administered by the larger group of teachers.

(5) Other Essential Social Science Studies for Future Projects

Professor McIlwraith introduced the discussion on this second item of the agenda. He advised concerning the projects under consideration by the Indian Committee of the Canadian Social Research Council. He mentioned Dr. Brown's study on the attitude to wardship of the Iroquois Indians at Grand River, and also studies at Lorette and Caughnawaga. Mention was also made of the McGill studies at Caughnawaga partially sponsored by the Dominion Bridge Company.

This led to a consideration of the other work being undertaken in the Western Provinces. It was suggested that an inventory should be made of the work now under way. There was a general discussion on this topic and it was decided that Professor McIlwraith would write to the Universities concerning other studies which might be under way. The question of public relations was raised and it was decided that there should be a press release on the work of the Panel and also an article in "Domar" (the magazine of the Department of Mines and Resources). Dr. Robbins raised the point of statistical approach and Dr. Hall suggested a possible demographic study across the Dominion. He mentioned the valuable information available from the nurses employed by the Department of National Health and Welfare. It was agreed that Indian Health Services would be asked to cooperate in such a study.

The Chairman proposed that a sub-committee composed of Dr. Robbins and Messrs. Neary and Grantham be established to report back on this statistical phase. Dr. Morton also raised the point as to how suggestions from the field staff could best be obtained. Mr. Neary pointed out that unfortunately a Regional Supervisor's conference would not be held until late in 1950 or early in 1951. He felt that a personal approach to this matter would be better than by letter.

(6) The Problem of the North American Indian

Professor McIlwraith raised the point of another conference such as was held in Toronto in 1939 under the joint sponsorship of
Yale University and the University of Toronto. Such a conference would bring together field staff, missionaries, Indians and anthropologists for a series of Panel discussions. Dr. Ault spoke in favour of such a conference and mentioned the possibility of Government sponsorship. It was agreed that such a conference should be held and could be regarded as an item for future consideration.

(7) Canadian Political Science Association

Dr. Hall spoke of the meeting of this Association in Kingston and suggested that an item on Indian problems might be included on the agenda. It was decided that action would be taken through personal channels to further inquire into this matter.

(8) Other Fields in Indian Affairs as Suggested for Research

Due to the absence of Mr. MacInnes by illness and Colonel Jones by absence in the Maritimes it was decided to defer this item on the agenda.

(9) The Inclusion of Eskimo Problems in the Scope of the Panel

Mr. Grantham introduced this item on the agenda by an outline of the problems of bringing education to the Eskimos of the Eastern Arctic and the Northwest Territories. He mentioned the schools now being operated and some of the difficulties being encountered, particularly the selection of good teachers. Dr. Robbins raised the possibility of scholarships for the training of young students for such work in the far North. He pointed out that a similar programme was being carried out by the Department of National Health and Welfare. There was a full discussion on this suggestion and it was agreed that the joint purposes of education and social research could best be served by having such trained teachers. Dr. Ault pointed out the need for further facts and research into the joint problem of education in the Northwest Territories and suggested that this whole field was one for careful study. It was decided that a sub-committee composed of Dr. Ault and Messrs. Neary and Grantham be set up to further explore the possibility of having such young students ear-marked and trained for teaching and welfare duties in the Northwest Territories. Professors Hall and Mollwraith would consider the matter from the students' point of view.

It was agreed that such students could well be tried out first in the summer schools operated by the Indian Affairs Branch in Northern Ontario and Manitoba. Dr. Ault then raised the point of the need for further research into the problem of Day school education as compared with Residential school education. It was agreed that this matter could well be the subject of another research project.

Dr. Morton pointed out the need for more information on the Indians and Eskimos generally and suggested a "programme of studies" with regard to the field under consideration.

Mr. Neary replied that such a "curriculum" was being conducted but that further information could be provided by sending copies of the Indian School Bulletin to each member of the Panel. Annual reports would also be sent to each member of the Panel.
The Chairman then summarized the main items discussed at the meeting and reviewed the sub-committees which had been set up for further reports.

It was decided that the next meeting would be held at the call of the Chairman, probably in mid-February.

Chairman.

Dear Mr. Neary:

I have been to Muncey with Mr. Penrose, my graduate assistant, where we had a profitable and pleasant preliminary discussion with Mr. Joblin. We withheld final decisions about tests until after this meeting and then placed orders. We expect to be in supply and ready to begin work when school opens in January.

There are two tests we must have and there is no difficulty about getting them. Another, which we would like to use as a supplementary instrument is printed in England and could not be obtained in less than a month. It is called "Progressive Matrices" (Penrose and Raven) and is printed from the R.M.S.R. Research Series by the University Press, Cambridge. We would like to have about 40 of these booklets (sufficient to test one whole class --- there are separate answer sheets, the booklets can be used over and over again). I have checked with the Vocational Guidance Centre and with the Provincial Dept. of Health and with the local D.V.A. Hospital without much success. I have one copy here and can probably borrow five from the local Ontario Hospital and that is all.

I know that the Army psychiatrists made some use of this test during the war and I wondered if by any chance there was a supply of them in the files of the D. G. M. S. which we might borrow or buy. A phone call to the chief Psychiatric Consultant could probably settle the matter quite quickly and I felt that he would not mind checking on this for me.

Many thanks. And compliments of the Season!

Yours sincerely,

Gordon H. Turner
Assoc. Prof. of Psychology.

P.S. 1. Thank you for letter & file.
2. Sent Wilson report on Wednesday.
3. Hope it arrives safely.
January 5, 1950.

Dr. G.H. Turner,
University of Western Ontario,
London, Ontario.

Dear Doctor Turner:

I have for answer your letter of December 30 which arrived this morning. I have been on the telephone trying to locate the tests which you require. Unfortunately none are available.

I was able to get the most information from Dr. Cathcart of the Department of Veterans Affairs who is personally acquainted with the tests and also knows Dr. Penrose quite well. He advised me that they had stopped using these tests because they were unable to get an adequate supply of them from the United Kingdom.

I would be quite happy to order a stock for you from the University Press in Cambridge but naturally this will take some time. However, I am taking the liberty of preparing a requisition for them and am asking for 50 so that we can have some for our own future use.

I regret that these tests are apparently not available but we will advise you as soon as they arrive from England.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Dept. of Indian Education.

MINUTES of a meeting of the Panel on Indian Research, held in the office of the Superintendent of Indian Education, 220 Queen Street, at 9:30 a.m. on Friday, December 16.

MEMBERS:
Dr. N.W. Morton, (Chairman) Defence Research Board,
Dr. J.E. Robbins, Dominion Bureau of Statistics,
Dr. O.E. Ault, Civil Service Commission,
Professor T.F. McIlwraith University of Toronto,
Dr. O. Hall, McGill University,
Dr. G. Turner, University of Western Ontario,
B.F. Neary, Indian Affairs Branch,
E.N. Grantham, Northwest Territories Administration,

In attendance:
Dr. L.P.M. Rioux, National Museum of Canada.

(1) Reading of Minutes:
The minutes were adopted after an amendment pointed out by Dr. Turner with regard to the pilot study on the Caradoc Reserve. Dr. Turner indicated that this study would be handled by a graduate student under his supervision.

(2) Social Science Studies
This item on the agenda was introduced by a discussion on the procedure for the making of application for National Research Council grants. Dr. Morton outlined in some detail the steps to be taken in this connection.

(3) The Educability of the Indians of the Caradoc Reserve
Dr. Turner reviewed the initial progress of the Caradoc study and told of his discussions with Dr. Long of O.C.E. concerning the types of tests which would be used. Professor McIlwraith advised that the Indian Committee of the Canadian Social Research Council was recommending a grant for Dr. Brown's study at Caradoc and that this matter would soon be considered by the "Grants and Aids Committee" of the Council. It was expected that Dr. Brown and a graduate student would be in the field in June.
These initial statements were followed by a discussion as to the way in which these two studies could best be closely coordinated. This was followed by considerable discussion as to the rates of payment for graduate students. Professor McIlwraith and Professor Hall outlined the difficulties encountered in interesting graduate students in research projects allowing for about $100 a month, which was regarded as a training salary. It was difficult to interest graduate students when higher salaries were available in other summer jobs.

(4) Socialization Processes Among the Iroquois

Dr. Rieux outlined this study which is being carried out by the National Museum of Canada. Members saw the questionnaire on child training which is to be sent to teachers of schools on the Six Nations Reserve. The main purpose of this questionnaire is to establish behaviour patterns among the Iroquois of the Grand River Reserve. There was some discussion concerning the integration of this study with the one being done at Caradoc. It was suggested that there be an initial trial with two or three selected teachers. This would permit decisions being made for the orientation and interpretation of the results of the questions administered by the larger group of teachers.

(5) Other Essential Social Science Studies for Future Projects

Professor McIlwraith introduced the discussion on this second item of the agenda. He advised concerning the projects under consideration by the Indian Committee of the Canadian Social Research Council. He mentioned Dr. Brown's study on the attitude to wardship of the Iroquois Indians at Grand River, and also studies at Lorette and Caughnawaga. Mention was also made of the McGill studies at Caughnawaga partially sponsored by the Dominion Bridge Company.

This led to a consideration of the other work being undertaken in the Western Provinces. It was suggested that an inventory should be made of the work now under way. There was a general discussion on this topic and it was decided that Professor McIlwraith would write to the Universities concerning other studies which might be under way. The question of public relations was raised and it was decided that there should be a press release on the work of the Panel and also an article in "Dome" (the magazine of the Department of Mines and Resources). Dr. Robbins raised the point of statistical approach and Dr. Hall suggested a possible demographic study across the Dominion. He mentioned the valuable information available from the nurses employed by the Department of National Health and Welfare. It was agreed that Indian Health Services would be asked to cooperate in such a study.

The Chairman proposed that a sub-committee composed of Dr. Robbins and Messrs. Neary and Greentham be established to report back on this statistical phase. Dr. Morton also raised the point as to how suggestions from the field staff could best be obtained. Mr. Neary pointed out that unfortunately a Regional Supervisor's conference would not be held until late in 1950 or early in 1951. He felt that a personal approach to this matter would be better than by letter.

(6) The Problem of the North American Indian

Professor McIlwraith raised the point of another conference such as was held in Toronto in 1939 under the joint sponsorship of
Yale University and the University of Toronto. Such a conference would bring together field staff, missionaries, Indians and anthropologists for a series of Panel discussions. Dr. Ault spoke in favour of such a conference and mentioned the possibility of Government sponsorship. It was agreed that such a conference should be held and could be regarded as an item for future consideration.

(7) Canadian Political Science Association

Dr. Hall spoke of the meeting of this Association in Kingston and suggested that an item on Indian problems might be included on the agenda. It was decided that action would be taken through personal channels to further inquire into this matter.

(8) Other Fields in Indian Affairs as Suggested for Research

Due to the absence of Mr. MacInnes by illness and Colonel Jones by absence in the Maritimes it was decided to defer this item on the agenda.

(9) The Inclusion of Eskimo Problems in the Scope of the Panel

Mr. Granthem introduced this item on the agenda by an outline of the problems of bringing education to the Eskimos of the Eastern Arctic and the Northwest Territories. He mentioned the schools now being operated and some of the difficulties being encountered, particularly the selection of good teachers. Dr. Robbins raised the possibility of scholarships for the training of young students for such work in the far North. He pointed out that a similar programme was being carried out by the Department of National Health and Welfare. There was a full discussion on this question and it was agreed that the joint problem of education and social research should best be served by having such trained teachers. Dr. Ault pointed out the need for further facts and research into the joint problem of education in the Northwest Territories and suggested that this whole field was one for careful study. It was decided that a sub-committee composed of Dr. Ault and Messrs. Neary and Granthem be set up to further explore the possibility of having such young students ear-marked and trained for teaching and welfare duties in the Northwest Territories. Professors Hall and McIlwraith would consider the matter from the students' point of view.

It was agreed that such students could well be tried out first in the summer schools operated by the Indian Affairs Branch in Northern Ontario and Manitoba. Dr. Ault then raised the point of the need for further research into the problem of Day school education as compared with Residential school education. It was agreed that this matter could well be the subject of another research project.

Dr. Morton pointed out the need for more information on the Indians and Eskimos generally and suggested a "programme of studies" with regard to the field under consideration.

Mr. Neary replied that such a "curriculum" was being conducted but that further information could be provided by sending copies of the Indian School Bulletin to each member of the Panel. Annual reports would also be sent to each member of the Panel.
The Chairman then summarized the main items discussed at the meeting and reviewed the sub-committees which had been set up for further reports.

It was decided that the next meeting would be held at the call of the Chairman, probably in mid-February.

Chairman.

Dear

Through the initiative of Colonel B. F. Neary of the Indian Affairs Branch in Ottawa, there has been set up a panel to discuss problems of Indian education in Canada. The members of this body comprised Colonel Neary and several of his associates, together with representatives from the National Research Council Committee on Applied Psychology, from the Canadian Social Science Research Council, and from the Dominion Bureau of Statistics. Its aim is to bring together a group of men with an interest in problems of Indian education - in the broad sense of the word - in the hope that from the meeting of such individuals there may develop research projects in Indian education and, in general, thought in regard to problems and projects, particularly those which directly affect the work of the Education Division of the Indian Affairs Branch. Dr. Morton of the National Research Council's Committee on Applied Psychology has acted as chairman at the two meetings of the panel, which I have attended as one of the representatives of the Social Science Research Council.

Personally I welcome the setting up of such a panel. I am not sufficiently optimistic to feel that epoch-making advances will be made, but I believe that it is likely to stimulate thinking in regard to matters of Indian education.

At the last meeting of the panel, discussion took place concerning research work actually being undertaken at the present time. Members of the panel were familiar with some of these, and I have made it my responsibility for a good many years to list every year current publications on Canadian anthropology. But it was felt that there was undoubtedly research work going on with which we were not familiar, and that it would be desirable to have a list of such activities. It was the feeling of the panel that the word "research" should not be considered too exacting. That is, we are interested in small projects, perhaps in the work of some teacher at an Indian school to develop home and school club activities, or in some project in the field of
medicine leading to measures of health education.

I was asked to compile such a list, and I am writing to ask your cooperation. Would you be good enough to jot down for me any work that is going on in your area which might be regarded as being included within these terms of reference. I am making this same request to a number of scholars in different parts of Canada, and Colonel Neary is making the same enquiries among members of the Indian Affairs Branch.

Yours sincerely,

T. F. McIlwraith,

There has recently been formed a Panel on Indian research with the express purpose of helping formulate issues or problems which are immediate and pressing in Indian social work. The initial emphasis is being placed on educational matters and coordination has been arranged with the Canadian Social Research Council. This panel will help to provide professional research and assist in meeting educational problems encountered in Indian schools. The members of the panel include the following:

Dr. N. W. Morton, Defence Research Board, as Chairman,
Dr. J. E. Robbins, of the Canadian Social Research Council,
Dr. O. H. Ault, of the Civil Service Commission,
Professor T. F. Mollwoith, of the University of Toronto,
Dr. Oswald Hall, of McGill University,
Mr. N. Grantham, of the Northwest Territories Administration,
Messrs. R. Asland, B. F. Henry, A. J. Desser of the Indian Affairs Branch.

The first study project is being undertaken by Dr. G. Turner of the University of Western Ontario and is entitled "The Educability of the Indians of the Cariboo Reserve".

This panel will also be corresponding with universities and other interested groups across Canada in an effort to find out what current research on Indian problems is being done.

It is felt that this panel can do a great deal to stimulate thinking in regard to matters of Indian education and that progress in this field can be expedited by means of psychological and other research.

(1) Reading of Minutes:
The minutes of the last meeting were adopted as read.

(2) Social Science Studies by Canadian Social Science Research Council

Professor McIlwraith introduced the section of this topic by outlining the grants in aid made by the Council for research on current Indian problems in various parts of Canada.

The main studies are as follows:

(a) Professor G. Gordon Brown (Univ. of Toronto), To conduct a study of social conditions, particularly in relationship to educational achievements, among the Indians at Muncey, Ontario.

(b) Professor G. Gordon Brown (Univ. of Toronto), To sponsor a study of reactions to wardship among the Six Nations of the Grand River, Ontario.

(c) Professor H.B. Hawthorn (U.B.C.), To study family life and adjustments on the Squamish Reservation, North Vancouver.
(d) Professor H.B. Hawthorn (U.B.C.), To study the question of Indians in the fishing industry of British Columbia.

(e) Professor M. Tremblay (Laval), To continue a study of social conditions and interactions among the descendants of the Huron Indians at Lorette.

(f) Professor F. Vogel (McGill), To continue research on social groups and attitudes among the Indians at Caughnawaga, near Montreal.

(3) Social Science Studies by Universities.

Professor McIlwraith had been in correspondence with the various universities concerning the studies underway across Canada. He outlined the work being done at the University of British Columbia, with particular reference to the work being done on the Indians in the fishing industry. Professor McIlwraith will continue his work at Caughnawaga this summer, and Professor Tremblay at Lorette. The study being done by Mr. Jones of McGill on the construction industry will be closely related to the many Indians who are being employed in that trade. Dr. Carl of the British Columbia Museum had also advised that in future a report on anthropology in British Columbia would be published annually.

Professor McIlwraith also cited "The Twenty-Sixth Annual List of Publications on Ethnology, Anthropology and Archaeology" reprinted from the Canadian Historical Review of March 1950.

A general discussion then followed in which various members of the panel expressed their views on the best method of approach to be adopted in arousing interest in the Prairie Provinces and the Maritimes where it was obvious that no studies were being undertaken. Dr. Leechman spoke of the Archaeology Society meetings in the Prairie Provinces and suggested the use of Archaeology Society meetings to develop latent interest into active participation. Professor McIlwraith mentioned the interest being taken by the Department of Planning and Development of the Province of Saskatchewan. Dr. Leechman indicated that if the interest of even one student in each university could be aroused in social anthropology, history, archaeology or education as it concerns Indians, that in time the faculty would shift its interest also. It was felt that Manitoba would probably be the easiest to approach, and that even the Hudson's Bay Company might be interested. Professor Morton pointed out the difficulty of solving this problem and felt that the personal approach through members of the faculty would be the best solution. This was generally agreed upon by Dr. Robb, Dr. Leechman, Dr. McIlwraith and Dr. Morton and they advised that they would attempt to create such an interest during the following months.

(4) In-Service Techniques

Colonel Neary began the discussion by presenting a new book entitled "They Came Here First". This book had been written by Darcy McNickle, the Chief of the Tribal Relations Branch, Indian Bureau, Washington, D.C. The author is himself an Indian and the book is highly recommended by the United States Indian Service. This led to a general discussion on the best way of presenting such material to field officials. Colonel Acland pointed out the difficulty of holding conferences which could be attended by Assistant Agents, etc. Dr. Leechman raised the possibility of a synopsis of the study being made, in the Annual Report of
the Branch or the general distribution to field superintendents. Dr. Robbins quoted the new famous extract "No Research Without Action"; "No Action Without Research". Professor McIlwraith suggested that reprints of papers be distributed to Indian superintendents, assistant agents, etc. Some of these might be dull but others would be quite readable.

All agreed to the need for the staff training of personnel and a sub-committee was established to bring in recommendations. This sub-committee would be composed of Drs. Leechman and McIlwraith and Colonel Neary. Its purpose would be to review various reports and publications, the substance of which would be of use to the field staff and to make direct recommendations to the Branch. Dr. Neary also pointed out the need for getting data before the public and their legislators. He felt that there was a need for a two-way approach with the administrator working with the researcher and presenting administrative problems for further investigation.

(5) Proposed Conference on the North American Indian

Professor McIlwraith reviewed the background of the 1939 conference and pointed out the need for another such meeting. He recommended that it be deferred until reports had been received from the research work presently being undertaken. It was decided that a further discussion on this point be raised in the fall of 1950 with the possible date of such a meeting in the fall of 1951.

(6) Canadian Political Science Association

Professor Hall was a member of the panel who had this matter under consideration.

(7) Social Studies Text

It was decided to defer discussion on this matter until a later date.

(8) Demographic Study

The sub-committee will report on this matter at a later date.

(9) Next Meeting

The date of the next meeting will be in September, probably the week of September 18 to 25.

Dear Mrs. Farmer:

Your letter of May 17th, 1950, addressed to the Honourable W. Ross Macdonald has been referred to me.

The point of view expressed in your letter reflects the keen interest you are taking in the affairs of public concern and particularly of our Indians; your action is certainly fully appreciated by ethnologists and anthropologists who have always tried to understand the cultures of the native races in Canada and to study them as objectively as possible.

The science of culture anthropology aims at understanding and explaining the behaviour of all ethnical groups of the world. To do so the anthropologist needs a full picture of what is happening in all the sectors of culture. In the last few years the emphasis has been put on early discipline in childhood; it is thought that there is a close relation between the way children are brought up and the way they will later behave as members of a group; the aim of these studies on child social adaptation is to find the roots of actual adult behaviour with a view of eradicating the sources of maladjustments. The studies of anthropologists and psychologists in the last 25 years have shown that the behaviour, which we justly consider as intimate, has a wide influence on other aspects of human behaviour and should be investigated if a full understanding of a given society is to be arrived at. The best example I can give you of the good effects of this type of enquiry is that of the Navaho Indians who have been studied in this manner by members of the Peabody Museum of Harvard. These Indians are now dealt with by administrators with a full comprehension of their point of view and will in the near future be completely integrated into the
active life of the country with their complete consent and satisfaction.

Another point of view is that to fully understand the human behaviour the anthropologist should study cultures different from his own; the native races have so far supplied the investigators with a mass of valuable data which will greatly forward the science of man. The Iroquois of Brantford have been chosen for this kind of study because of their great culture achievements and because it is thought that in understanding the way they have accomplished their cultural transition this knowledge could be used and applied to some other groups who have not achieved so much.

Even if everybody were agreed on the value of such studies there would still remain a question of trained investigators. I whole-heartedly agree with you that the ideal way would certainly be to have the inquiries made by trained anthropologists. In the case of the Navaho Indians the investigators spent years and years collecting their data. Unfortunately there are but few anthropologists in Canada and very little money available for such studies. To obviate this difficulty it was thought that the Indian teachers could be used to obtain some of the information required. Being in constant contact with the families of the Reservation they could, we thought, by observing what is done rather than by questioning the informants, fill some of the gaps in our knowledge of this particular group. We also thought that this procedure would reduce to a minimum the possibilities of friction between the informants and the investigators. It is understood that the data collected by the teachers are to be checked in the field by anthropologists and as is always the case in such studies, no names are divulged.

The responsibility of the Indian Affairs Department is limited to asking the Indian teachers to co-operate with the National Museum on a voluntary basis; if questions were felt to be too intimate the teachers could disregard them. From the answers already in I see that this has been the case in some instances.

I hope that this explanation has convinced you that we are trying to act in the best interests of the Indian and those of the country as a whole; our anthropologists want to secure as much objective information as possible on the various cultures of all the ethnical groups of Canada at a minimum cost to the Government. May I point out by way of conclusion that the museum parties which have worked in the past in the Six Nation Reserve have always been on very good terms with the Indian council and that it is the intention of our anthropologists to continue this tradition of co-operation and friendship.

Yours sincerely,

R.J. Alcock
Ottawa, May 23, 1950

Dear Dr. Morton:

In reply to your letter of May 2, I think the best way in which you could make sure that some research will be done on the problems of the Indians, is to provide research bursaries or scholarships for this purpose.

I have consulted Professor G.W. Simpson, the Head of the History Department at the University here. He tells me that a great deal of research material regarding Indians would be in the Archives at Ottawa. Masters students are proverbially poor and when they are not Science students they seldom have bursaries or scholarships. Money would have to be provided for a Saskatchewan student to carry on part of his research in Ottawa. Professor Simpson is interested in the Archaeological side of research and I think would be glad to foster work in this field so far as it relates to Indian affairs. Again a bursary would probably be required.

I have not had an opportunity to consult with Dr. Britnell Head of the Department of Economics, but my general impression would be that if a study of Economics or Sociological study of the problems of Indians were to be made, it would be undertaken only if bursaries or scholarships were available.

So far as the College of Education goes, we supervise the work of students in the Master of Education Degree in the College of Graduate Studies. We have had ten students actively engaged in work for the Master's Degree this year. I think it would be quite possible to interest some of our Masters students in the Education of the Indians, but again it would involve special expenses in travelling to Reserves and schools and living there for a while. Most of our Masters students at present are married men with family responsibilities, and they are unlikely to undertake such a project, but rather to choose one which they can carry out either in Saskatoon or from Saskatoon. I think you might try offering a few $1200
scholarships in Canada or even a few bursaries of a smaller amount and see what would come out of it. If this is at all likely, I shall keep the matter in mind so far as our students are concerned.

Sincerely yours,

S. R. Laycock,
Dean of Education.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Thank you for your letter of May 20th. You might very well wonder what has been happening down this way.

In January I made application to N.R.C. for a grant for work at the Caradoc Reserve this summer and it was favourably received. The student (who is now out there) is Douglas Penfold who did the work at Muncey last winter. It was all he could do to cover Muncey and a control population from schools in the district adjacent to the Reserve before the end of March. And with the interference and distraction of regular work and exams we haven't been able to complete the report of that work. And even last week I brought back from Windsor some data on school children there (on one of the tests we used) which we hope to incorporate in the report. The findings thus far will be available, we hope, within the next week or two and I'll certainly see that a copy goes directly to you.

Our present plans are two-fold. First, to give large numbers of the Indian children individual tests (probably the new Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children) so that some clinical assessment will be possible and likewise the opportunity to discover whether or not they differ from white children in respect to a number of more specific functions, e.g., verbal as opposed to non-verbal material, and various types of each. A second major interest is in the attitudes of children and adults to education. And this interest will be in with the work of Fleming (Dr. Brown's anthropology student) who is already on the spot.

As for Moraviantown I don't see at the moment, how we
can do very much about it. It is a lot farther away and trips there could not possibly be covered by the small items I have in the present grant. However, how would it be for Mr. Hummel to get in touch with Penfold directly (c/o Mrs. Capayo, Nuncy, Ont.) to let him know how many children they have there, when they might be available, etc. It might be very interesting to have scores from Noraviantown on the Otis and Hennon-Nelson tests we gave this winter. A supply might be shipped down with careful instructions or Penfold might manage to get there on at least one short visit.

In a word, let's establish effective contact and see what we can work out.

Did you ever receive a supply of Progressive Matrices from England? We could make use of them this summer.

Isn't the Superintendent of Indian Education due for a whirl through this territory?

All the best.

Yours sincerely,

Gordon H. Turner,
Assoc. Prof. of Psychology.

MINUTES of a meeting of the Panel on Indian Research, held in the Office of the Superintendent of Indian Education, 220 Queen Street, at 9:30 a.m. on Monday, May 1, 1950.

MEMBERS:

Dr. N.W. Morton (Chairman) Defence Research Board,
Dr. J.E. Robbins Dominion Bureau of Statistics,
Dr. O.E. Ault, Civil Service Commission,
Professor T.F. McIlwraith University of Toronto,
Dr. D. Leechman National Museum of Canada,
Colonel H.M. Jones Indian Affairs Branch,
Colonel E. Acland Indian Affairs Branch,
Colonel B.F. Neary Indian Affairs Branch,
Mr. E.N. Grantham Northwest Territories Administration,
Mr. A.J. Doucet Indian Affairs Branch,
Major C.A.F. Clark Indian Affairs Branch,

(1) Reading of Minutes:
The minutes of the last meeting were adopted as read.

(2) Social Science Studies by Canadian Social Science Research Council

Professor McIlwraith introduced the section of this topic by outlining the grants in aid made by the Council for research on current Indian problems in various parts of Canada.

The main studies are as follows:

(a) Professor G. Gordon Brown (Univ. of Toronto),
To conduct a study of social conditions, particularly in relationship to educational achievements, among the Indians at Muncey, Ontario.

(b) Professor G. Gordon Brown (Univ. of Toronto),
To sponsor a study of reactions to wardship among the Six Nations of the Grand River, Ontario.

(c) Professor H.B. Hawthorn (U.B.C.),
To study family life and adjustments on the Squamish Reservation, North Vancouver.

(d) Professor H.B. Hawthorn (U.B.C.),
To study the question of Indians in the fishing industry of British Columbia.
(e) Professor M. Tremblay (Laval),
To continue a study of social conditions
and interactions among the descendants of
the Huron Indians at Lorette

(f) Professor F. Voget (McGill),
To continue research on social groups and
attitudes among the Indians at Caughnawaga,
near Montreal

(3) Social Science Studies by Universities.

Professor McIlwraith had been in correspondence
with the various universities concerning the studies underway
across Canada. He outlined the work being done at the
University of British Columbia, with particular reference to
the work being done on the Indians in the fishing industry.
Professor Voget will continue his work at Caughnawaga this
summer, and Professor Tremblay at Lorette. The study being
done by Mr. Jones of McGill on the construction industry
will be closely related to the many Indians who are being
employed in that trade. Dr. Carl of the British Columbia
Museum had also advised that in future a report on
anthropology in British Columbia would be published annually.

Professor McIlwraith also cited "The Twenty-Sixth
Annual List of Publications on Ethnology, Anthropology and
Archaeology" reprinted from the Canadian Historical Review
of March 1950.

A general discussion then followed in which
various members of the panel expressed their views on the
best method of approach to be adopted in arousing interest
in the Prairie Provinces and the Maritimes where it was obvious
that no studies were being undertaken. Dr. Leechman spoke
of the Archaeological work being done in the Prairie Provinces
and suggested the use of Archaeology Society meetings to
develop latent interest into active participation.
Professor McIlwraith mentioned the interest being taken by
the Department of Planning and Development of the Province of
Saskatchewan. Dr. Leechman indicated that if the interest
of even one student in each university could be aroused
in social anthropology, history, archaeology or education
as it concerns Indians, that in time the faculty would shift
its interest also. It was felt that Manitoba would probably
be the easiest to approach, and that even the Hudson's Bay
Company might be interested. Doctor Morton pointed out the
difficulty of solving this problem and felt that the personal
approach through members of the faculty would be the best
solution. This was generally agreed upon by Dr. Robbins, Dr.
Leechman, Dr. McIlwraith and Dr. Morton and they advised that
they would attempt to create such an interest during the
following months.

(4) In-Service Techniques

Colonel Neary began the discussion by presenting
a new book entitled "They Came Here First". This book had
been written by Darcy McNickle, the Chief of the Tribal
Relations Branch, Indian Bureau, Washington, D.C. The author
is himself an Indian and the book is highly recommended by the
United States Indian Service. This led to a general discussion
on the best way of presenting such material to field officials.
Colonel Acland pointed out the difficulty of holding conferences
which could be attended by Assistant Agents, etc. Dr. Leechman
raised the possibility of a synopsis of the study being made,
in the annual Report of the Branch or the general distribution
to field superintendents. Dr. Robbins quoted the now famous
extract "No Research Without Action"; "No Action Without Research".
Professor McIlwraith suggested that reprints of papers be distributed to Indian superintendents, assistant agents, etc. Some of these might be dull but others would be quite readable.

All agreed to the need for the staff training of personnel and a sub-committee was established to bring in recommendations. This sub-committee would be composed of Drs. Leechman and McIlwraith and Colonel Neary. Its purpose would be to review various reports and publications, the substance of which would be of use to the field staff and to make direct recommendations to the Branch. Dr. Morton also pointed out the need for getting data before the public and their legislators. He felt that there was a need for a two-way approach with the administrator working with the researcher and presenting administrative problems for further investigation.

(5) Proposed Conference on the North American Indian

A Study of the Existing Intellectual Level of Indian Children

Report by Gordon H. Turner
Associate Professor of Psychology, University of Western Ontario.

June 1950
Introduction and Problem

This study was undertaken in the hope of throwing some light on the question "What differences in educability, if any, exist at the present time between Indian and white school children?"

The grant for this project was made in November 1949. It was understood that the aim would be a limited one, namely, to examine, before the end of March 1950, a number of Indian school children using group tests of intelligence which had been constructed and standardized on and for a white population. It should be clear then that the question of differences in native capacity between Indians and white children was not the issue. It might be useful to put the question in this way, "Judging by performance on group tests of intelligence for white children, how capable are Indian children of benefitting from standard elementary school instruction?"

It was decided to confine the study to the children of the Caradoc Reserve, Muncey, Ontario, and to white children in schools in the surrounding rural districts who would serve as controls. It was felt that it would be more satisfactory to compare Indian children with white children from the same country district than with children in Canadian cities or more unsatisfactory still, with American school children.

Thus the problem was narrowed to a comparison of Indian children of the Caradoc Reserve and white children in neighbouring schools with respect to performance on group tests of intelligence.

Population of Cases

a) Indian

Muncey, Chippewa and Oneida Indians reside on the Caradoc Reserve which is served by six schools. Table I gives the number of registrations in each of the schools and the number who were available for testing when the schools were visited. The total tested is 240.

The greater percentage tested among the whites is of course a reflection of the higher percentage attendance. Differences in attendance figures are however open to misinterpretation since many pupils are kept on the register at the Indian schools even after they have ceased to attend regularly whereas such is not the case in the provincial schools.

Test Administration

In consultation with Dr. Long, Department of Education Research, Ontario College of Education, two group tests of intelligence were selected:

The Otis Quick-Scoring Mental Ability Test, Alpha, Form A.
(Administered to Grades 1-4 using the non-verbal instructions.)

The Henmon-Nelson Test of Mental Ability, Grades 3-8.
(Administered to Grades 5-8)

Both of these are "paper and pencil" tests. Responses are made by marking Xs or crossing out items. No writing is involved. Reading is of course essential except in the case of the pictorial material designed for the younger children.

All tests were administered and scored by Douglas Penfold, the research assistant, during the first three months of 1950.

Raw scores on the Otis may be converted to I.Q.'s by two different methods one of which does, and one of which does not, involve the M.A./C.A. formula. Mr. Penfold used both methods and obtained somewhat different results, the dispersion of the distribution of I.Q.'s being greater when the M.A./C.A.
method was used.

In presenting results only I.Q.s based on the M.A./C.A. calculation will be employed. This is the method used in scoring the Henmon-Nelson and furthermore it was found that I.Q.s obtained in this manner conformed more closely to the Henmon-Nelson I.Q.s in dispersion. As a check, however, all calculations of differences between Indian and white children were repeated using the alternative scoring method of the Otis. But since these data yielded very similar results it was decided that it would not be necessary or helpful to include them in this report.

Findings

1. Distributions of Otis I.Q.s (Grades 1-4) and Henmon-Nelson I.Q.s (Grades 5-8) for Indian and white children are presented in Graphs 1 and 2 and show

   a) a clear tendency for the white children to have relatively higher quotients.

   b) a range of quotients which is approximately the same for both Indians and whites.

9. Reliability determinations were not made upon present test results. However, in June 1949, the Otis had been administered to the Indian children in Grades 1-4 by Mr. Joblin, the School Principal at Muncey. It was found that 61 of these cases were also among those tested by Mr. Penfield with the same test six months later. The product-moment coefficient of correlation between these two sets of data was calculated and found to be .62. This is a surprisingly low test-retest correlation and it strongly suggests that group test results obtained in a class room setting with these Indian children are less reliable than might reasonably be expected.
Since there had been a suggestion that there might be quite wide differences between the performance of children in different bands on the same reserve, the Oneidas were compared with those of the other two bands, on Otis I.Q.s. SUMMARY OF FINDINGS

1. On group tests of intelligence designed for use with and standardized upon groups of white children, the Indian children of the Caradoc Reserve obtained significantly lower average scores than white children attending rural schools in the same area of the province. Their scores were not, however, very much lower than those found among some groups of Grade 3 children attending city schools.

2. In round figures, 30% of the Indian children obtained I.Q.s below 80 as compared with 10% of the white children.

3. The reliability of the test scores obtained by the Indian children would seem to be too low to be regarded as satisfactory.

4. Such evidence as is available does not support the contention that there are significant differences in capacity among the children of the Indian Bands at Muncey.

5. As a group the Indian children appear to start school at a slightly more advanced age than the white children in the control group and to maintain this age differential throughout their elementary schooling.

6. The difference in test performance between the Indian and white children becomes much more marked among those over 12 years of age.
DISCUSSION OF FINDINGS

While there is no reason to believe that the scores obtained by the white controls are not reasonable valid reflections of their abilities, such is not the case with respect to the Indian children. The question of reliability might well be pursued further but the low test-retest correlation at least serves as a warning that all may not be well. More than that however, there is a serious doubt that the Indian children take the tests on equal terms with the whites in respect to strength of motivation. While no systematic observations were made in this connection it appears to be the general impression, and it is certainly quite possible, that the Indian children do not receive from their parents as much encouragement to do well in school work and may in many cases be discouraged in the attitude that schooling is an unnecessary discipline imposed from without which has to be endured until a certain age.

Thus we know how well the Indian children did but we cannot be at all confident that it was the very best that they could do, with their present background and experience.

Apart from the matter of general attitude the Indian children are undoubtedly at a disadvantage because of other deficiencies in background. One obvious factor which might be expected to have considerable effect on test performance is that of familiarity with English. In all probability another language is spoken in the home at least for part of the time. And even in cases in which English predominates it is highly questionable if it would compare favourably with the English used in the homes of the white children in vocabulary, grammar or any other respect. And of course any differences in home background that would limit general knowledge of academic skill might be expected to reduce test scores.

However, in attempting to assess the educability of Indian children in terms of performance on standard tests it is an interesting question whether or not one should make any allowances for poor motivation. It might be argued very cogently that in so far as it is culturally determined it should stand alongside the other background factors that may put Indian children at a disadvantage. Thus attention would be directed solely to the present degree of disparity between Indian and white children as judged by white standards. The reasons for such disparities would of course occupy the centre of the stage when consideration is being given to the problem of narrowing the gaps.

CONCLUSION

As judged by performance on group tests of intelligence for English-speaking children, most of the Indian children of the Caradoc Reserve are at the present time as capable of deriving benefit from elementary school instruction as the white children attending rural schools in the same area of the province. However, they are on the whole less well equipped. Moreover, whereas about ten percent of the white children may be regarded as too limited in present ability to derive average benefits, the corresponding percentage for the Indians is approximately thirty. To infer from these findings that there is any necessary or permanent difference in educability would of course be quite unjustified.

Dear Mr. Brown:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of November 14, in which you advise that representations have been made to you by two or three women from Brantford in connection with a questionnaire which had been circulated among Indian women on the Six Nations Indian Reserve.

This questionnaire was undertaken as part of a scientific study on socialization processes among the Iroquois sponsored by a Panel on Indian research, at a meeting held in December 1949, under the Chairmanship of the Director of the Operational Research Group of the Defence Research Board, on which this Branch was represented.

The project was carried out by the Anthropological Division of the National Museum of Canada and arrangements were made by agreement with this Branch to have the questionnaires distributed through the Indian school teachers on the Six Nations Reserve.

When this arrangement was made I was not aware of the actual details and nature of the questionnaire. When it was brought to my attention in June last, as a result of representations made by Mrs. R. A. Farmer, Secretary of the Brantford Local Council of Women, through the Honourable W. Ross Macdonald, I must say that I was disturbed by the nature of the questions which were of an extremely delicate and personal character and which, in my opinion, could not serve any useful or desirable purpose. Accordingly, action was taken to disassociate this Branch from the activity of distributing the questionnaires and to that end instructions were given to the Indian Superintendent, Col. Randle.
As far as this Branch is concerned the incident, which I consider to have been regrettable, is closed and care will be taken to see that it is not repeated.

The Indian Superintendent is being instructed to call upon Mrs. Florence M. Raynor and explain the position, in the circumstances, to her.

The matter has also been discussed again with officials of the National Museum concerned, who have given assurance that any questions of the kind objected to will be carefully avoided in any further research work undertaken.

THE EDUCABILITY OF INDIANS OF THE GARADOC RESERVE

PROGRESS REPORT

by

Gordon H. Turner

Associate Professor of Psychology

The University of Western Ontario

January, 1951
1. The last report on this project was submitted in June 1950 and dealt with a comparison of Indian and white children on group tests of intelligence.

2. The project was continued with two main aims in mind:
   (a) to gather more detailed data on the performance of Indian children (on intelligence tests designed for whites) by the administration of individual tests containing performance as well as verbal sections and
   (b) to obtain as much information as possible concerning cultural factors which might influence progress in school or psychological test performance.

3. In pursuance of these objects Mr. Penfold spent the summer months in residence at Muncey along with Mr. Fleming, student of anthropology working under Dr. Brown.

4. The original intention and hope had been to complete a program of individual testing during the summer but this was found to be impossible for two reasons:
   (a) once the schools closed testing had to take place in the homes and in the great majority of cases the conditions were quite unsuitable and
   (b) many families left for the tobacco fields and elsewhere.
Thus testing not completed in June or early July had to be put off until the fall.

5. It was possible, however, to make an extensive compilation of medical records and school records of attendance and achievement and to complete the onerous task of checking age records which were in many cases either incomplete or uncertain and frequently required diligent investigation of parents or other relatives.
Furthermore, information concerning the attitudes and opinion of
Indians (especially those of parents about education) was sought (and subsequently recorded) on all possible occasions. Penfold appears to have gained a great measure of acceptance and has been able to gather a wealth of information which, along with Fleming's findings, should be invaluable aids to the interpretation of results.

6. The program of testing includes the following

(a) the administration of the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children to all Indian children in the age groups 7, 10, and 14.

(b) the administration of the Progressive Matrices (1947) to all Indian school children up to and including the age of 12 and to several groups of white controls.

7. Penfold has been visiting Muncey once or twice a week since early fall and will now require only about four full working days (three weeks at most) to complete the gathering of the data.

8. Since Penfold is basing his M.A. thesis on this work and has a May 1st deadline to meet, a complete report is assured by that date.

(1) Reading of Minutes:
The Minutes of the last meeting were adopted as prepared.

(2) Chairman's introductory remarks:
Dr. Morton reviewed, for members of the panel attending for the
first time, its purposes and stressed that it was in the nature of an informal
discussion group of University and Government officials to deal with various
problems in Indian Affairs.

He touched on the departure from the panel of the Secretary, due
to his resignation from the Indian Affairs Branch.

Dr. Morton then tabled the progress report of Dr. G.H. Turner of
the University of Western Ontario, dealing with the Educability of the Indians
of the Caradoc Reserve. He stressed that this was an initial report only;
with the compilation of other data, and when the results of further research were available, a final report would be made.

(3) Social Science Studies by Canadian Social Science Research Council:

Professor McIlwraith introduced this section by outlining the grants in aid made by the Council for research on current Indian problems in various parts of Canada.

(a) Professor Gordon Brown (University of Toronto) in conjunction with Dr. Turner, to conduct a study of social conditions, particularly in relation to educational achievements, among the Indians at Munroey, Ontario.

(b) Mrs. Martha Hewitt (now Mrs. Randlo) on a study of reactions to wardship among the Six Nations Indians of the Grand River, Ontario.

(c) Professor H.B. Hawthorn (U.B.C.) a study of family life and adjustments on the Squamish Reserve, North Vancouver, B.C.

(d) A study of economic and social conditions among Indians in the fishing industry of British Columbia.

(e) Professor F. Vogel, the continuation of research on social groups and attitudes among the Indians at Caughnawaga, P.Q.

(f) Professor M. Trombley (Laval), the continuation of a study of social conditions and interactions among the descendants of the Huron Indians at Lorette.

Professor McIlwraith pointed out the need for research into Indian problems. He also stressed the need for the training of, and the arousing of interest in, social science research workers. He then dealt with the other projects now under consideration for grants by the Research Council. One was a study of Indian adjustments in the agricultural areas of southern Ontario (from Kettle Point to Tyendinaga). Professor McIlwraith pointed out that there was little work being done among the Prairie Indians, and mentioned in passing the publication of a recent book by Mr. and Mrs. Hankins entitled "Tribe under Trust" (being a study of the Blackfoot Indians of Southern Alberta.

Professor Hall also mentioned the work being done by a West Coast Indian, Percy Gladstone, under the supervision of Dr. Hawthorne.

Colonel McCary then reviewed the need, as he saw it, for the continuation of the panel. He stressed the use already being made by the Education Division, of the researches at Caughnawaga and at Squamish. He also mentioned the interest of the field officials and the teachers in reports of such research.

Dr. Loehman then pointed out how abstract field work among the Indians can give them a moral stimulus and self-confidence. He mentioned his experiences in recording an important and valuable block of culture among the Indians of Northern British Columbia and the Yukon.

(4) Reports on Research

Dr. Morton led a discussion into the various ways and means of bringing the reports of such research to the attention of all field officials. Professor McIlwraith volunteered the use of one or two graduate students from
the University of Toronto in making abstracts of articles which had previously been decided upon as being of sufficient importance to warrant their distribution. He mentioned, as an example, a recent study in Mexico. This had been carried out by a group of 40 researchers working under a UNESCO grant, and being a fact-finding study plus In-service training of the Mexican officials concerned. It was one of the most comprehensive educational surveys which he had ever read. It had recently appeared in an obscure Mexican journal in four articles totalling 160 pages. It would be most valuable if summarized and distributed to our field officials. Dr. Leechman then pointed out the need for the distribution of all such reports.

Colonel Fortier then asked to say a few words as he had to leave the meeting for another one. He expressed his appreciation for the work of the panel, both on his own behalf and on behalf of the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration. He pointed out that since the formation of this new Department just a year ago, the emphasis was clearly being placed upon bringing of Indians into citizenship. He also pointed out that every effort must be made to get the whites to know and understand the Indians. The Prime Minister had already clearly stated government policy in this regard at the time of the formation of the new Department. An Information Section was not in the process of being formed and they were looking for a senior man to head it. He must be one who could understand the great mosaic of Canadian citizenship and appreciate ethnic problems of these various groups. He offered the services of this Division to publish the reports mentioned and to assist in their circulation. He agreed entirely that research work was important but it was also most essential to have abstracts made of their reports and distributed to field officials for their future information and guidance. (Colonel Fortier then left the meeting).

Major Clark then raised a query concerning what had happened to the study made among the James Bay Indians. Professor Mollwraith answered at some length outlining this sociological study which had concentrated particularly on food and diet. The late Dr. Tisdall and Dr. Brown had headed this study. A sub-committee of Professor Mollwraith, Dr. Leechman and Major Clark was to investigate this problem further and bring in another report.

Dr. Morton then led a discussion into the need for further study among the Indians of the Prairie Provinces. He had contacted certain of the western universities and had received a letter from Dr. Laycock of the University of Saskatchewan. He felt that there was potential interest there but there was a need for financial assistance and also for trained field workers.

Professor Mollwraith had also contacted Dr. Britnell of the University of Saskatchewan and Dr. Long of the University of Alberta.

Dr. Leechman mentioned that he had had an opportunity of discussing the formation of the panel with Professor Hawthorn who felt that it was a move which would have far-reaching benefits.

Professor Hull mentioned the development of the Department of Sociology at the University of Manitoba and felt that this would make for further research in that province.

Dr. Morton then pointed out that the colleges of education of the various universities needed to be contacted so that their interest could be stimulated into research in the field of Indian education. Colonel Neary in reply pointed out that this was one of the things which he hoped that the Regional Indian School Inspectors would be able to do.

Professor Hall then raised the possibility of funds from the Department. There followed a general discussion on this matter and it was decided that it would be raised again in the presence of the Deputy Minister.
Proposed Conference on the North American Indian.

Professor McIlwraith recommended that this conference be delayed until 1952. He based his recommendations upon two points:

(a) the disturbed international situation,
(b) by 1952 many of the research projects now under way will be completed and reports ready for consideration.

Colonel Acland then delivered a message from the Director and he also suggested that the conference be postponed until the new Indian Act was passed, possibly at the next session of Parliament. By 1952 the Department would know also the reaction to the new Act.

Mr. Doucet agreed with this proposal and also pointed out the favourable reaction of field officials to the work of the panel. He appealed to the panel to continue its work and to add its impetus to the improvement in general of Indian education.

Demographic Study

Dr. Robbins will examine all statistical information received at the Education Division and will make recommendations as to other statistics which should be made available for this study.

Appointment of new Chairman

Dr. Morton reviewed the general situation and pointed out that a new Chairman and Secretary would be required. After considerable discussion, Professor McIlwraith was selected by unanimous vote.

Appointment of new Secretary

Major C.A.F. Clark was unanimously selected to replace Colonel Neary.

Future of the Panel

Colonel Acland led the discussion by raising the following points:

(a) the exact terms of reference used by Dr. Keenleyside in his letter concerning the panel,
(b) the possibility of the National Museum playing a greater part in its activities. He felt that there was a definite need of drawing to the attention of the new Deputy Minister, the exact terms of reference of the panel.

This led to a general discussion with Dr. Morton, Professor McIlwraith and Dr. Robbins participating. It was agreed that letters would have to be sent to General Young, the Deputy Minister of the Department of Resources and Development concerning the participation of Dr. Leechman of the National Museum. It was also decided that a letter should be sent to Colonel Fortier concerning the terms of reference of the panel.

The suggestion that Dr. Brown of the University of Toronto be a future member of the panel was deferred until the next meeting.

Next Meeting

This will be at the call of the Chair. It will likely be in May when Dr. Hawthorn of the U.B.C. will be in Eastern Canada, attending a conference. The panel was anxious that he attend the next meeting.

Dr. N. W. Morton,
Chairman.

B. F. Neary,
Secretary.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Life has been very complicated of late and I find that I have neither acknowledged your letter of June 9th., nor reported our findings of last winter. This will take care of the former and the latter is the very next major item on the agenda.

The Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children, which Penfold is using now at Murray is an individual test along the style of the Revised Stanford-Binet Scale. One box of materials plus a few record blanks and small manual costs $22.00 (Vocational Guidance Centre, 205 Avenue Rd., Toronto). A record blank would not be very revealing and I haven't an extra manual so am not enclosing anything for you. The VGC would be glad to send you a manual and other information about the test, I'm sure.

We are using an individual test, now that we have a little more time, for various reasons: clinical observations may be made of the performance of each child, test results will be more reliable and valid because there is a real chance to control and assess motivation, and performance will be much more adequately sampled on both verbal and non-verbal materials. In general we hope to discover a great deal more about the children and the particular strengths and weaknesses which may characterize them in relation to a broad white population.

Sorry to have missed you during your recent visit.

Sincerely,

Gordon H. Turner,

Dear Major MacKay:

I have been looking forward to the chance of dropping in and calling on you in Ottawa, but I have been up very seldom during the last few years, and it has always seemed necessary to take an early train home. Ten days ago when a meeting was called of Neary's panel on problems of research connected with Indian education, I again hoped that the meeting would break up in time for me to slip over to see you. However, we all talked at such length that it was well after twelve o'clock on Saturday before the meeting broke up.

As you may remember, Morton has acted as chairman of the panel since its formation. Reasonably enough, he asked to be relieved, partly in the belief that a rotation of chairmen was desirable. Much to my surprise and against my advice, the panel asked me to take over the chairmanship. As I am so keenly interested in the matters that have been discussed at the meetings, I felt that it would be ungracious for me to decline. More than ever, I shall regret the resignation of Neary. He always impressed me as an extremely able man.

I do not suppose you know how grateful I was for a message which you sent via Acland, urging that no attempt be made to hold an Indian conference in the immediate future. I had thrown the suggestion out rather casually a year ago and was somewhat surprised at the enthusiasm with which the idea was received, but I felt that this was not the opportune time, and yet I hated to seem to be postponing it. So your message was, to say the least of it, a great relief.

Acland made another very helpful suggestion, namely, that it would be well to put down the terms of reference under which the panel has been operating. As the incoming chairman, I feel the need for this very strongly, as I am not at all familiar with some of the background and I would like to be clear on a number of points. When I prepare this statement, if I may, I shall send you a copy and ask you to see whether it agrees with your understanding.
May I ask you about quite another point? Dr. Brown heard yesterday that there was an opening for an Indian agent at or near Moose Factory. Assuming that this information is correct, I wonder if it would be feasible for Kerr to apply for such a position. He was one of the two men who worked under Dr. Brown's direction, actually doing his investigations at Rupert's House. Kerr is a big, lumbering ex-serviceman who has taken his Master's degree in Anthropology. He is not a first class student, but we felt that he was worthy of the Master's degree. On the other hand his interests are in practical problems and I think it is fair to say that he has shown himself capable of living in the North with enthusiasm and interest. I do not know what the specific qualifications for such a position are, but it might be that Kerr's experience, plus his Master's degree, plus his war service, might make him eligible. Brown and I would recommend him within the limits of the statements that I have just made. He is a plodding, honest soul who will never set the world on fire, but who will do a conscientious job.

With best regards,

Yours sincerely,

T. F. McIlwraith

To: The Superintendents of Indian Residential Schools in Ontario.

From: Sophie R. Boyd, Executive Secretary, School of Social Work, University of Toronto.

May I take this very informal way of extending to you or members of your staff an invitation on behalf of the Director of this School, Dr. Harry H. Cassidy, to take part in a workshop on Institutional Care of Children and Young People which is to be held under the sponsorship of this School on March 7th, 8th, and 9th next. I am enclosing a programme of the sessions so that you can see the sort of thing we plan to do.

For the past three years we have held workshops of this sort at the School on the request of the Division of Youth and Child Welfare of the Provincial Department of Public Welfare. The purpose of the workshop is to bring together staff members of Institutions in Ontario for discussion of matters of common interest and concern and to attempt, with the help of qualified leaders, to bring us all to a better understanding of children and their needs and of how we can best meet these in our work and institutions. In our discussions we deal with such definite questions as how to arrange an interesting programme for children in an Institution, how to deal with problems of discipline, how to prepare the child for leaving the Institution and returning to his own home, etc.

In addition to the actual knowledge gained through these joint discussions I think we have all benefitted by getting to know each other better since so often staff members in Institutions work in rather isolated places where they have not much opportunity to talk to other people who are working in similar situations elsewhere.

The group of persons who have come together now for three years in these workshops are beginning to organize themselves into a group of institutional workers so that they, themselves, will probably be initiating planning for these workshops in the future. It occurred to this group that there are many other Institutions caring for children in Ontario who might be equally interested in joining the group for discussion such as I have outlined. They mentioned in particular Indian Residential Schools, Homes for Handicapped Children, and Reform Schools. On their suggestion, therefore, we are writing now to these various residential schools and Institutions to extend a very warm welcome to the present workshop.

If you can manage to send one or more staff members, would you fill out and mail to us, the attached application forms with a fee of $4.00 made payable to University of Toronto.
