At a meeting on January 27, 1961, of the group commonly called "The Advisory Panel on Indian Research," it was pointed out that there was some ambiguity regarding the terms of reference under which the group was operating. I was asked to prepare a memorandum on this point. As the incoming chairman, I was very glad to do so, particularly in view of the fact that I was uncertain myself of the status of the group.

In preparing this memorandum, I have gone through File No. 150-144 of the Department of Citizenship and Immigration, Indian Affairs Branch, entitled "Panel on Indian Research." This memorandum is based on material in that file, supplemented with my recollections of discussions that took place at different meetings.

Preliminary and informal discussions about the possibility of forming a panel on research problems must have taken place in June or July, 1960. Correspondence took place between Colonel Neary and Dr. Morton with regard to the scope and composition of such a panel. The outcome of these discussions was a series of letters from the Deputy Minister of Mines and Resources, H. L. Keenleyside, to the National Research Council, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics, the Canadian Social Research Council, the Department of National Health and Welfare, the Civil Service Commission, and the Indian Affairs Branch asking the co-operation of different groups and individuals in the project.
I think it is pertinent to quote one of these letters.

H. W. Morton, Esq., Ph.D.,
Director of Operational Research,
Defense Research Board,
Department of National Defence,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Doctor Morton:

For some time now our Departmental officials have been planning the establishment of a panel or committee which could advise them on various Indian research problems.

There is a genuine need for professional research into matters relating to Indian Education, Welfare and Social problems, etc. The establishment of such a panel could provide for a coordination of the research which has been done or is planned into various aspects of Indian life. It could also plot out in general terms the order of priority in which various studies could be undertaken.

It has been recommended that the following be represented on this panel:

1. The National Research Council, represented by yourself.
2. The Dominion Bureau of Statistics, represented by Dr. J. E. Robbins.
3. The Canadian Social Research Council, represented by Professors McIlwraith and Oswald Hall.
4. Department of National Health and Welfare, represented by Dr. Stegall, Chief of the Mental Health Division.
5. Civil Service Commission, represented by Dr. O. E. Ault.
6. The Indian Affairs Branch.

I would sincerely appreciate your advice on the establishment of such a panel and also your reaction to my request that you accept the duties of Chairman of this group. It is my feeling that a fact-finding body such as this can do a great deal towards alleviating the present dearth of social science research studies into the various aspects of the Indian problem.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd.) H. L. Keenleyside
Deputy Minister."

All these invitations appear to have been accepted, although the absence of written confirmation indicates that in some cases
this was done by telephone.

Two points seem worthy of mention at this point:

(a) Dr. Keenleyside uses the term "represented" in regard to individuals belonging to the National Research Council, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics, the Canadian Social Science Research Council, the Department of Health and Welfare and the Civil Service Commission. I think it is fair to say that none of the individuals from these organizations have thought of themselves as representing any official opinion of these various bodies. Members of the Panel have provided information or ideas, as individuals, but in no case have gone to their respective organizations to ask for authority or for concurrence in any statement.

(b) Dr. Keenleyside speaks of the group as "a panel or committee which could advise on various Indian research problems." He also speaks of research into matters relating to "Indian education, welfare and social problems, etc."

On August 8th, 1949, Major MacKay, writing to the Deputy Minister speaks of the group as "a Panel on Indian Research." There is a further memorandum, unsigned, from the Director which I think should be cited at this point.

"Panel on Indian Research

"As requested by you, I have had further information provided by the Superintendent of Education concerning the establishment of the above panel. The object of this panel is to provide for professional research into matters primarily relating to Indian Education. The establishment of this panel would provide for coordination of the research which has been done or is planned into various aspects of this educational field."
"One of the most urgent needs is for a survey of the mental ability of Indian pupils across Canada. This can only be done by careful selection of a suitable intelligence test and by administering such a test in a scientific manner.

"We have in Ottawa in the persons of Dr. Morton, Dr. Ault, Dr. Robbins and Mr. Stegill, leading men in the field of educational, psychological research and it is felt that their professional advice and assistance would do a great deal to help in having these tests carried out in a manner which will ensure the validity of the results obtained.

"Director."

Following these preliminary arrangements, the first meeting of the Panel was held on November 15th, 1949, with seven members and two guests in attendance. There was considerable discussion concerning the function and responsibility of the Panel, which was summarized in the minutes as follows:

"Purposes and Terms of Reference of Panel on Indian Research

"There was a general discussion led by Dr. Morton, in which all members expressed their opinions as to the purpose of the panel. It was decided that the panel could best serve by helping to formulate issues or problems which were more immediate and pressing and then assist in having research begun with the initial emphasis on educational matters.

Dr. Robbins spoke on the coordination which would be possible with the work being carried out by the Canadian Social Research Council. Professor McIlwraith discussed the range of projects planned by the Indian Committee of the Canadian Social Research Council and the type of projects in which they were interested. Dr. Ault pointed out the need for coordination between smaller local studies and a Dominion-wide survey."
"There was considerable discussion as to the difference of purpose between the Indian Committee of the Canadian Social Research Council and this panel. The general conclusion was that the Indian Committee was more concerned with a broad coverage of the various types of social problems from a scientific point of view and was not particularly concerned with the administrative problems facing the Indian Affairs Branch. The panel, however, was concerned with these problems and with providing professional research and assistance in meeting such problems. Following a review by Mr. Island of the need for a secretary for the Panel, it was decided to have Mr. Neary carry on these duties for the present time."

Discussion followed on a pilot study at the Caradoc Reserve, Muncey, Ontario, to be conducted by psychologists and anthropologists from the University of Western Ontario and the University of Toronto, operating on grants from the National Research Council's Committee on Applied Psychology and the Canadian Social Science Research Council.

The next meeting of the Panel was held on December 19th, 1941, with eight members and one guest in attendance. Dr. Turner of the University of Western Ontario reviewed the initial stages of work that had been done at Caradoc and Dr. Ricoux outlined a study on which he is engaged for the National Museum among the Six Nations. Discussion took place on the inclusion of Eskimo problems within the field of interest of the Panel.

The next meeting was held on May 1st, 1950, Professor
McIlwraith outlined the work that is being undertaken on Indian research through grants from the Social Science Research Council and discussed various other studies being undertaken by different bodies. It was recognized that there is an almost endless amount of research work needed, some of it of a direct administrative nature, other types of a more theoretical nature. It was agreed that contacts should be made with universities, particularly on the Prairies, where research appeared to be lagging. It was also agreed that reports of research, either in whole or in summarized form, should be made available to field officers of the Indian Affairs Branch. Dr. Leechman, Col. Henry and Professor McIlwraith agreed to look into this matter.

The next meeting of the Panel was held on January 27th, 1951, sixteen members being present. Professor McIlwraith reported on work carried out during the summer with the aid of grants from the Social Science Research Council. Dr. Merton raised the question of the necessity to see that the reports on research reached the hands of those who might find them of value, and Colonel Fortier expressed similar views and offered any assistance possible. Leechman, Henry and McIlwraith offered regrets at their tardiness in preparing synopses of articles which should be circulated to officials of the Indian Affairs Branch, and were requested to endeavour to carry out the wishes of the Panel as expressed in its meeting on May 1st, 1950.

To the regret of all members, Dr. Merton felt that it was necessary for him to retire as chairman and Professor McIlwraith
was elected in his place. Due to the imminent retirement from the Service of Colonel Neary, it was also necessary to nominate a new secretary, Major C. A. F. Clark.

---

The above may be thought of as a summary of the work of the Panel up to the present time, April, 1951. It may be appropriate to include a number of personal comments concerning what seem to me lines of appropriate future development. These can be summarized as follows:

1. **Membership.** The functions of the Panel would seem to be fulfilled by a small membership. Many of those actively concerned in Indian problems are located in Ottawa, where attendance at Panel meetings can be arranged easily. Outside members lend considerable support, but it is not reasonable to think of them being drawn from an area further afield than London in the west and Quebec in the east. The University of Western Ontario, the University of Toronto, McGill University, Université de Montréal and Université Laval have staff members keenly interested in these problems and representatives from these institutions might be drawn in from time to time. Professor Valardeau of Laval would be particularly useful, if available.

2. The expenses of the Panel, which have been carried by the Indian Affairs Branch, have been limited to defraying the travelling expenses for out-of-town members attending meetings. It is not anticipated that these expenses will increase
appreciably. However, it would seem desirable to set a definite amount for this. The sum of $1,000 annually is suggested.

3. The primary function of the Panel is, and should be, a clearing-house for information on research, especially in the field of the adjustment of the Indians to changing conditions. This objective would seem to be consistent with the original terms of reference setting up the Panel as dealing with Indian research.

4. While the Panel can and should give advice on research projects and their suitability, it should not itself take responsibility for conducting or supervising research, a function for which it is not constituted.

5. The Panel should include aid in the dissemination of the results of research as one of its main objectives.

6. The Panel, comprising as it does individual members with knowledge in various fields, will be available to discuss matters brought up at meetings by members. These might include such matters as changes in curricula, in administrative fields, in welfare, or in other aspects of activities pertaining to the Indians. Such discussions would fulfil one of the basic reasons for the Panel, viz., its availability as a consultative group.

MEMORANDUM TO E.A.

Reference your memorandum of June 11, 1951, concerning the Panel on Indian Research.

It would appear that the activities of the Panel to date have been centered around Indian education but if the Panel is to continue my feeling is that the terms of reference should be broadened to include matters concerning the welfare of Indians. On page 8 of Professor Hollerith's summary, suggestions 3, 4 and 5 state the case very clearly.

In the administration of Indian Affairs we are dealing with human beings and our concern is the adjustment of the Indians to changing conditions. This Panel could be of great value to the Welfare Service in the following respects:

1. It would provide an opportunity at regular intervals to discuss with experts in related fields problems of basic policy governing specific welfare undertakings. For example, had this panel been in existence, it might have been a logical place for discussion of some of the many problems inherent in the proposal to consolidate reserves in Nova Scotia.

2. In many places in Canada a recurring welfare problem concerns Indians who are no longer able to live through traditional pursuits of hunting and trapping and must accommodate themselves to a sedentary settled way of life. It is anticipated that this panel could be of great assistance in this regard as might encourage research in a typical area from which valuable lessons and guidance for the administration could be gleaned. I have in mind a case that is presently concerning our administration and that is the Weymontachie Band of the Abitibi Agency.
3. In a general way the opinions and conclusions deriving from pure research in sociological and anthropological fields would, it is considered, provide valuable leads in the whole field of welfare.

4. It would provide information as to the results of research studies undertaken by universities and other bodies which are so often filed in university libraries and never come to the attention of officials working in the field.

It would seem that this panel would be of particular value at the present time in view of the fact that the Branch is embarking upon the administration of a new act which will inevitably bring in its wake a number of unfamiliar problems.

ACCULTURATION OF THE BRITISH COLUMBIA KOOTENAY
A Venture in Ethno-History

SUMMARY

No study of acculturation in the Central Plateau Region of British Columbia has apparently ever been made. It is imperative that such a study be undertaken if any record of the process is to be preserved, for urban-industrial pressures in the Fraser Delta Region, immediately to the west of the Plateau, seem to threaten penetration of the latter area with the result that its essentially rural character will be altered. If this occurs, Indians who live in the Central Plateau Region will be forced to adjust to new patterns within the Eurocanadian society, and old adjustments will be irretrievably lost.

The present study centers about the Kootenay, smallest of five Indian groups living in the Central Plateau Region. The Kootenay are in a reserve area at Cranbrook in the extreme southeastern corner of the province, and are thus farthest removed from the source of postulated change. In spite of variations in climate and terrain within the Plateau Region, pre-contact cultures of the five groups appear to have been similar in most respects. The adjustment of the Kootenay to Eurocanadian culture seems to have been representative for the region, and may thus be described with the belief that it reflects the general picture in the Plateau.

The investigator proposes to spend a year with these people, entering as a participant (though without attempting to disguise the reason for his presence) and gradually assuming the role of observer. He will study the present life of the group and will attempt to describe the nature of their adjustments to the larger culture. If possible, he will attempt to discover, also, the processes by which these adjustments have been achieved. His ultimate aim is to set down an ethno-history of the Kootenay, a project which will involve not only descriptions of present adjustments and those of the immediate past, but a survey of more remote periods as well. For this purpose ethnological data that have been secured by other students during the last fifty years will be summarized.

The study entails expenditures amounting to $4,800.00. This sum may, however, be cut approximately in half if the program were to be divided into two periods of six months each, and expenses prorated for these periods.

The Kootenay are in a reserve area at Cranbrook in the extreme southeastern corner of the province, and are thus farthest removed from the source of postulated change. In spite of variations in climate and terrain within the Plateau Region, pre-contact cultures of the five groups appear to have been similar in most respects. The adjustment of the Kootenay to Eurocanadian culture seems to have been representative for the region, and may thus be described with the belief that it reflects the general picture in the Plateau.

The investigator proposes to spend a year with these people, entering as a participant (though without attempting to disguise the reason for his presence) and gradually assuming the role of observer. He will study the present life of the group and will attempt to describe the nature of their adjustments to the larger culture. If possible, he will attempt to discover, also, the processes by which these adjustments have been achieved. His ultimate aim is to set down an ethno-history of the Kootenay, a project which will involve not only descriptions of present adjustments and those of the immediate past, but a survey of more remote periods as well. For this purpose ethnological data that have been secured by other students during the last fifty years will be summarized.

The study entails expenditures amounting to $4,800.00. This sum may, however, be cut approximately in half if the program were to be divided into two periods of six months each, and expenses prorated for these periods.

Hon. Sir,

On behalf of the Missionary Society of the Methodist Church I beg leave to apply for your sanction to the erection of an Industrial Institute for Indians at Hazelton as shown on the accompanying map attached hereto.

To have 320 acres adjoining the Reserve secured for this purpose nearly two years ago. Re Indian Institute at Hazelton, B.C.

Permit me to ask your favorable consideration to a matter referred to in my communication of July 28th, and also in conversation when I was last in Ottawa, namely, the great importance of an Industrial Institute for the Indians on the Upper Skeena and contiguous country, to be located at or near Hazelton. Mr. Pedley,

As long ago as the 20th of August, 1896, Rev. Dr. Sutherland, General Secretary of the Methodist Missionary Society, advocated the establishment of an industrial school at Hagwilget on the Upper Skeena with accommodation for 50 pupils and stating that for many years this Society had been most anxious to get this work into operation. They had secured a half section of land from the British Columbia Government for this purpose and were anxious for a Government grant with which to commence the work. Nothing was done at that time and the application was renewed in December of 1905 by Dr. Sutherland and Dr. Whittington.

At that time it was not recognized that the Methodists had any special claim for a school under their auspices in this locality. The Anglican Bishop protested against the establishment of an industrial school by the Methodists there, claiming that this point had been for twenty-five years a Church of England mission and that if the Government contemplated an industrial school there his church should be accorded the privilege of carrying it on.
In 1906 Dr. Horace Wrinch, Medical Superintendent of the Hazelton Hospital, urged on the Department the necessity for establishing an industrial school on the land acquired by the Methodists and Dr. Whittington also wrote the Department in reference to his former application for this school. It was decided that the question would have to stand. Although the matter has been brought up several times since by Dr. Whittington and Mr. Sloan, the member for the district, no further action has been taken. Mr. Agent Loring and Mr. Vowell, Indian superintendent for British Columbia, as far back as 1906 both endorsed the project to establish a school near Hazelton. Since then conditions have materially changed and there is plenty of work available for the Indians and it is doubtful whether there is much need for an industrial school. In any event we would have to settle under whose auspices the school would be conducted, should it be established.

MEMORANDUM -

Mrs. Pedley:

I have considered the proposition to establish a Non-Denominational Industrial School at or near New Hazelton. I presume this school would be intended to meet the needs of the Indians of the Babine Agency. That is pupils might be drafted from all parts of the Agency into the school.

The school population according to our last return consists of 185 boys and 194 girls; 109 of these are Roman Catholics and the rest Protestants. The Roman Catholics belong to the Eastern part of the Agency at Hagwilget Village, Moricetown, Fort Babine and Old Fort Babine; the Indians of the rest of the district are divided between the Anglicans and Methodists, and there are at Glen Vowell and Andimaul establishments of the Salvation Army. In the Non-Denominational School we could only deal with the Protestant pupils; the Roman Catholics would require a separate school for their own people, but even so we find that there are 270 Protestant children of school age.

Some years ago we took up the question of establishing a Hospital for tubercular Indians at Hazelton. Dr. Wrinch was

We received a plan for the hospital which would accommodate 17 patients, the cost of which was in the neighbourhood of $15,000.00. I think if we would foster and promote the interest of the present day schools by paying adequate salaries to competent teachers and advance the work of the Hazelton hospital, giving them a large annex for tubercular patients, the interest of the communities would be better served. The moment we admit the pupils to the schools the question of tuberculosis arises and as our whole system of residential schools is open to criticism, I think it would be better to leave the Indians of the Skeena River free and endeavour to mitigate the scourge of tuberculosis and to give the children education in the day schools which we could improve with the expenditure of very much less money than would be required to establish and operate a Non-Denominational Industrial School.

My dear Mr. Scott:

A further word on the Hazelton proposition. When I was out there last Winter Dr. Wrinch was anxious to have a grant for building a laundry on his present hospital site. We took a trip over to Mission Point property which consists of 320 acres belonging to the Methodist Church; and I suggested to him the advisability of considering selling out our present plant, which I believe could be done, for a sanatorium, and building an entirely new plant for hospital purposes nearer the station; and a large Industrial School could be put up on the same property. Just before the war we were considering the question of building an Industrial school on this property, and the Mission Board of our Church was quite agreeable to deeding ten acres, or whatever land was necessary for the buildings. I do not anticipate any change in this policy.

At the Conference of Indian workers in connection with the Methodist Church, in British Columbia, it was unanimously decided that the school be built at Hazelton, before the construction of one at Fort Simpson. Sir:

A complaint has reached the Department regarding the inconvenience caused the teachers in the Babine Agency, owing to the delay in the receipt of their quarterly salary cheques.

It is considered that the greater part of the delay may be occasioned by the system adopted in your office, viz.: the holding of the returns each quarter until they have been received from all the schools in the agency and forwarding them to the Department at the same time. The teacher who forwards his return promptly at the end of the quarter is handicapped by its being held until those from the other teachers - some of whom may be very dilatory in forwarding them - are received by you.

In future, therefore, I have to request that, as soon as a teacher's quarterly return reaches your office, you will certify and forward it to the Department, so that payment can be made.

There is no delay in this Department after returns are received; we endeavour to have salary cheques forwarded not later than 24 hours after the receipt of the returns. It would be advisable for you to instruct all the teachers to prepare their returns promptly upon the expiry of each quarter and forward them to you.

Owing to the long distance which mail has to travel between the Department and your office, I am sure that you will cooperate in every way you can to overcome the delay in having the teachers receive their salary cheques, and thus saving them all the inconvenience possible.

Dear Scott,

For a considerable time the matter of an Industrial School for the Northern district of our Province has been under consideration. I am writing not in an official capacity but as a member of the United Church stationed at Hazelton B.C.

I would advocate the erection of such a school at Hazelton B.C. for the following reasons:

1. Hazelton B.C. has already the site of ample proportions. The land can be filled and it also contains the best grain and vegetables necessary for such an institution. Giving training and employment to the boys and girls in modern lines such as agriculture, horticulture etc.

2. The climatic conditions are more favorable to the health of the Indians as they are subject to tuberculosis ailments when living on the coast. The climate here is cold and dry and favorable to good health.

3. It is the center of our Indian life work whereas Port Simpson is over-crowded and away off and it is also a coast city with boggy land.

4. Hazelton is on the line of the C.N.R. and the expenses of securing supplies would be much less than at Port Simpson. It is evident that this was the settled policy of the Church to build Somed be pleased to join me in thus giving the above arguments consideration when the time comes for consideration and action.

Sir,

I have the honor to report that when on my way to Hazelton on March 23rd, I saw Mr. B. Rankin, (teacher of the Andimaul School), for just a moment, at the station. He enquired if I intended to visit his school, and I replied in the affirmative.

On the morning of March 28, I reached Andimaul and was informed that Mr. Rankin had gone to Prince Rupert. I saw Mrs. Rankin (an Indian woman), and wrote a note to the teacher saying I was sorry not to find him home, and asking him to send me a report on the school to Prince Rupert. I asked Mrs. Rankin if I could see the school room. After some considerable trouble she found a key that would unlock the door of a small house. I could easily see that the room had not been used for months, and I could not find a register. As I passed through the village I met several Indians separately, who declared there had not been school since May, 1913. At Kitwangak a well-known Indian, Daniel Wells, from Andimaul, told me he had lived at Kitwangak all winter so that his daughter could attend school, because there was no school at Andimaul. Then at Kitmegukla I found two girls from Andimaul attending school there, as there was no school in their own village.

When I reached Prince Rupert I found a report and letter from Mr. Rankin awaiting me, in which he stated that he had taught school right along, with an average attendance of ten, and adding that he was doing good work. I immediately wrote him asking for an explanation, and telling him that the Indians claimed there had been no school all winter and part of last summer. I received a
reply which absolutely contradicts the report he sent me to Rupert. He states that Ensign Hardy, former teacher, taught and reported for the June quarter of 1913, but that that officer only taught the month of April and arrived in Vancouver on May 24th. Mr. Rankin did not teach during the month of June, but sent in the quarterly report, was paid, and did not give Ensign Hardy any part of the money.

The school was not opened during the September quarter. He states the summer holidays were the reason for July and August, but he did not have school in September. For December quarter there was an epidemic of measles in the village and Dr. Wrinch ordered that the school was not to be opened for October and November. He did not teach school in December, but had it open a few nights preparing for Christmas.

I do not think he will send in any report for the March quarter now, although Mrs. Rankin told me it would be sent in in a few days, for he is aware that it is known that he has not taught during the quarter.

He has a store in the village which he attends to himself, also a sawmill. During the year he built a house for himself in the village. His attention has been given to these matters and not to the school.

Knowing the language of the Andimaul people I did not find it difficult to get the facts.

I respectfully recommend that the matter of a new teacher for this school be taken up by the Department with Major Green, head of the Salvation Army for B.C., residing on Hastings Street, Vancouver.

I have the honor to remain

Your obedient servant

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of Departmental letter, dated the 15th ultimo, stating that the Department were in receipt of a communication from Mr. Inspector Green who recently visited Andimaul, and had stated that he had found Mr. Rankin absent, and from enquiries made from the Indians believed that there had been no school all winter, and for a portion of last summer. Inter alia, is it remarked that Mr. Rankin had been paid for the time the school was supposed to have been taught by him in the June quarter, paid full for September quarter, although he had not held any school during the month of September, and also in full for December quarter; and that in the last mentioned he had stated that the school were closed by order of the Doctor for October and November owing to measles, but no reason had been given as to why school was not in operation during December. Also is it stated that in view of the facts it were desirable, and for me to inform Mr. Rankin that his services will not be required after the 30th June, and enquiring of me to know whether I had any knowledge of the fact that this school was not in operation during the periods above referred to.

In context to the aforementioned, and in chronological order, as far as the facts are known to me, I beg to state that Mr. Rankin did teach school during the month of June, last.

The measles broke out sometime about the 1st of September following, and again must refer to having left here on the 15th of that month on a leave of absence, and did not return till the 6th of November. The certificate of Dr. Wrinch to have his school closed

The Secretary,

closed for October and November was in my possession, which subsequently was handed to Mr. Inspector Green during a call at my office.

The measles were still in evidence till about the middle of December, and knew that Mr. Rankin taught school for the remainder of that month. Since I do not keep copies of teachers' vouchers, in so far as remarks thereupon are concerned, if I remember aright, I made mention thereupon, consecutively, recommending the pay in full, when not by any default of the teacher the whole or the requisite number of days were wanting.

Thereafter denominational affairs cropped up. Then, certain factions having broken faith with Mr. Rankin by not contributing to the saw-mill at Andimaul. The party having broken faith with Mr. Rankin, heaped insult upon injury upon him by procuring another mill by buying the little mill of Mr. Price's of Kitwanga, and this aggravated the situation.

This latter move stirred up a still more antagonism to Mr. Rankin, and he could not get sufficient attendance to justify his teaching. I tried to smoothen matters; abiding my time, believed that this feeling would subside, but no.

I prevailed upon Mrs. John Sharp and Miss "Captain" Agnes Law, of Glen Vowell, to try and effect a settlement in so far as denominational differences were concerned. They repaired to Andimaul on the 25th of March, last. Since then, Mr. Rankin has written me that he had to relinquish the teaching of the school. By Miss "Captain" Agnes Law I am informed that she had written to her organization applying for another teacher.

By Mr. Inspector Green's statement, I can plainly infer that his information was somewhat ex parte of the rival faction. In the instance of the kind, Indians are only too prone to throw
the first stone regardless of one's sacrifices and services.

Regarding Mr. Rankin, I can state that he was always untiringly active in the interests of the Indians of Andimaul, in general, ever meek and patient to a fault.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

While Mr. Lyon, the Inspector here, has been highly obliged and very interested in the education and general welfare of our tribe, he has had his feet firmly set on the subject, having also deep interest in the Indians.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Nov. 22d, 1912

Sir:

In reference to Old Kitsegukla school, as per my report of June 6th, your File No.414299/1, I discussed this question with Dr. Raley, Supt. of the Methodist Mission, and it seems that some years ago, arrangements were made with the Methodist Church whereby they would form a new Church at NEW Kitsegukla, and the Indians - at that time - consented to move from Old Kitsegukla. Seemingly this did not take place or transpire, and on my visit in June, I found quite a large number of children, of school age - probably between the ages of six and fifteen. Some of the Indians discussed the question of having a school-house, but there is no question but what they desire to remain in Old Kitsegukla, and it would seem to me that it is an absolute necessity to provide a school for the education of their children.

As this Village is under the jurisdiction of the Methodist Church, the question might be taken up by the Department with the Executive of the Church.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

INSPECTOR OF INDIAN AGENCIES.

February 15, 1915.

J.D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Sir:

The Indians of this Village met me today on my way down the river. There were nine men at the meeting, each the head of a family. They reported to me that there were 12 families in the Village and 27 children of school age.

During the Conference these facts came out. Some years ago the Indians of this Village decided to leave. A number of them went East to what is now known as New Kitzeguala—a distance of six miles. Here they were allotted land, each having a number of feet of river frontage. They built fairly good frame houses, and moved onto the land. A school was opened, a missionary was sent by the Methodist Church. The land is of excellent quality and it was hoped that the Indians would settle down and till the soil.

A number of families about the same time moved six miles West. Here the Salvation Army undertook to teach and evangelise these. The Indians built homes and settled, seeming contented for a while. This Village is known as Andimaul. There is a school in operation poorly attended.

Now there is a movement for these people to go back to the Old Village—the home of their fathers. Here they told me they were going to build
to build a model Village, with good wide streets. They intended to live in this village and cultivate their land six miles away. No cattle, pigs or sheep would be allowed in the Village.

Until these people settle down, and decide where they will dwell it is impossible to do much for them. They will likely apply for a school, and till you know all the facts of the case their story is very plausible.

I would respectfully recommend that no school be established at Old Kitzegucla this year. There has been no school at this point for some years.

I remain, Sir,

Your obt. servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C.

Inspector's Report on the Meanskinisht Indian School.

Nov. 12th, 1906.

GENERAL REMARKS.

The Indians requested me to attend a Council, where I heard their speeches. They desire the Government to aid them with their day School. The Indians say that they will build a good new School-house themselves, if the Department will assist them with a teacher.

I would respectfully recommend that the usual grant given to Day Schools, be granted to assist this School.

This village has a Bye-law requiring all children of school age to attend School.

A. R. Green.
Meanskinisht, B.C.
Upper Skeena,
Oct 29th/06.

R.E. Loring, Esq.
Indian Agent

Dear Sir:

Ever since we settled here some eighteen years ago we have been interested in school for the children of the Indian Settlers.

The parents of these children first passed a Village Rule binding themselves and any who might join this village to send their children regularly to school.

Then they built and equipped a school house. My daughters in succession taught this school with assistance at times from myself and one or other of my sons.

Two of my daughters are now married and the other two absent from home, so that the question of carrying on school has become a difficulty and I would wish with your sanction to apply to the Indian Department for a grant towards the salary of a teacher to be supplemented by a fund to be raised by the parents to enable us to obtain the services of a competent teacher, as we wish to introduce a higher grade of teaching than has hitherto been possible.

We have twenty-two children of school age belonging to this village at present. A few days before school would have closed for the summer holidays the school house was burned down. This year we will have to use rented quarters but before next Autumn, please God, we hope to have a good and suitable school house erected.

If the Department will kindly give us a grant towards the salary of a teacher we expect, and are prepared to carry on the school in accordance with their requirements.

Will you kindly bring this petition before the heads of the Department,

And Oblige,

Yours Sincerely,

[Signature]

January 17th, 1913.

The Secretary

Department of Indian Affairs

Ottawa,

Sir:

Will you kindly permit me to bring under your notice, and ask your approval of, a plan which I would like to adopt at this Mission.

My reason for bringing forward this matter at the present time is the lax attendance of so many of the scholars, especially the growing boys, at the indian day schools amongst these Indians. This is so marked, more especially in the Autumn and Spring, that any bona fide efforts to keep these children at school may well arrest the attention of the Department. Any plan proposed must partake of the nature of an experiment, but if solid reasons can be given for the likelihood of its succeeding, surely it is worth while to give it a chance.

An experience of over forty years among the indians on the Nass and Skeena rivers shews me that while they have advanced much in many ways in some things they are essentially different from the whites. These differences are most marked in those qualities which they have inherited from their fathers, and which are the result of a certain mode of living for generations. Thus the nomadic character of their forefathers lives shews itself in these their descendents by a restlessness at times which seems almost irresistible. Now for them to remain shut up in school for hours while suffering from this becomes in some of
them intolerable and consequently they stay away from school whenever they possibly can. To enact rules and regulations to restrain them at these times would, under present circumstances, prove both difficult and expensive; as it would be impossible, with the present lack of parental control, to carry out these rules unless a number of officers were appointed for the purpose; moreover compulsion, in the half-tutored mind, always feels like tyranny, so that a spirit of opposition would be excited which would more than counterbalance any good done.

Another cause affecting the attendance of the growing boys is the high wages they can obtain working among the whites. This proves a strong temptation not only to the boys but also to the parents, many of whom can ill afford to lose this assistance.

The present is a critical time for these Indians. The new transcontinental railway is opening up these valleys, and the inroad of the whites adds a further difficulty; while the opportunities and facilities for utilizing the land, and disposing of the produce are vastly increased, and if taken advantage of by the Indians will enable them to gain a nice living. If, on the contrary, they are permitted to drift much, if not all of the permanent benefit anticipated from the efforts of the Department for their uplifting and education will be lost. The matter is worth the very best and closest consideration of the Department so that they formulate a definite policy for dealing with them at this crisis.

Meanwhile I would like to ask for permission and approval
to the following plan. Something of an experiment it must be; but, as it would necessarily have to be begun on a small scale, should anything unfortunately arise to hinder its being carried out no harm would be done; while should it succeed it might prove the forerunner of larger efforts which might bring untold good. We are very favourably situated at this village for the experiment. The land around the village is rich. There is a station on the G.T.P.R. on the bank of the Skeena just opposite the village. We are only five hours run from the new city of Prince Rupert; and the climate permits the growth of most of the vegetables and fruits.

To remove some of the causes which hinder the regular attendance of some of the pupils at this Indian Day School I would propose that during the months of April, May, June, September, and October the older children, both boys and girls, who attend school, might be employed at outdoor work one half of each day and receive wages for their work.

The work proposed is the clearing and cultivating of a portion of their own land here at their village, though just at starting it may be necessary, until the heavy timber is removed from a suitable piece of their land to use a piece already cleared outside their land. Their time while they are engaged in this work to count the same as if they were present in the school, and the work done by them to be subject to the inspection of the School Inspector. As regards the wages to be paid them, I am prepared to pay these; trusting to be reimbursed
later on from the proceeds of their labours.

The advantages to the children would be— (a) A certain amount of book learning acquired in the half days in school. (b) The opportunity to work off in remunerative work the restless spirit which seizes them. (c) Their being retained at their own village instead of straggling off here and there away from their homes among the whites exposed to all kinds of temptation. (d) An incentive to them to start gardens of their own and to use the knowledge they have gained directly for themselves. (e) Individual interest and responsibility encouraged. (f) Enough earned to meet their needs. (g) No extra expense to the Department.

Such, in brief, is an outline of the plan proposed. That obstacles to the working of it will arise and have to be met is to be expected, especially when the still unsettled state of the Indian lands question is considered, for this seems to act as a blight on all their best interests at the present time.

It may seem like presumption on my part to bring this matter before you, but to attempt to work such a plan without the sanction and approval of the Department would lay me open to the charge of trying to draw away the children from school.

I have the honour to be Sir

Your obedient servant

Ottawa, February 12th, 1913.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st instant, enclosing a communication from the Rev. Mr. Tomlinson in reference to the gardening operations at Meanskinight, Skeena River, B.C. In reply, I beg to say, that the Department thoroughly approves having a garden conducted at every Indian School where it is practicable, and will agree to the suggestion of the teacher, that during the months of April, May, June, September and October, the older children present might be employed in outdoor work. The question of remuneration must be left with the teacher, as the Department cannot take any responsibility for this. Help to a reasonable extent in the way of tools and seeds will be given, if you will submit a list with an estimate of the cost.

It is hoped that this proposed scheme will result in a better attendance of the larger children, which is the object Mr. Tomlinson has in view.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

R. E. Lessing, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hazelton, B.C.
MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Pedley,

Mr. Inspector Green in his report on the Meanskinish School states that the children are doing very well under the charge of Mr. Tomlinson, the present teacher. He is devoting his whole time to the uplifting of the Indians in the village and meeting with a large measure of success. The attendance is improving and Mr. Green recommends that Mr. Tomlinson's salary be increased to $500.00 per year. He is now paid $400.00. The school has been in charge of the Tomlinson family for the last four years and as this is all he receives from all sources I think he would be fully entitled to an increase. He is an old man, but has excellent qualifications, being a B.A. of Queen's College, Dublin. Mr. Green says that in spite of his age he is an excellent teacher and a very active man.

[Signature]

Mr. Agent Loring reports that Miss Z. Richardson, formerly nurse and deaconess on the Kislipiax Reserve, has been appointed by the Rev. J. H. Spencer, the present superintendent of Methodist Mission work in that district, as teacher of the Meanskinisht School in the Babine agency.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter No.301630/1 regarding a school teacher at Meanshinisht allow me to thank you for your courtesy in consulting me but this is a case in which I have nothing to say.

Rev. Robert Tomlinson, the founder, of Meanshinisht was a clergyman of the Church of England though of late years he carried on his work in a more or less independent manner. After his death last winter his son Richard formally handed over the Mission to the Methodist Church.

There is no Indian Reserve at Meanshinisht. The Indian village stands on the Tomlinson Estate. Rev. Robert Tomlinson drew up a lease to the village Council under certain strict conditions. I doubt whether this lease was ever registered or whether it would hold in law. The consequence is that while I used to visit Mr. Tomlinson as a friend I always felt that the village was his private property. He was a man of strong opinions of his own and it was best that he should work in his own way. Richard, the son, was left by the will in charge of this estate. What the future of this Indian village on private property will be is difficult to say. I thought that the Indian Agent, Mr. Loring, understood the peculiar situation. I am now not in any way connected with the Mission of Meanshinisht. Again thanking you for your courtesy.

Yours faithfully,

F. H. Du Vernet

Rev. Sir,

I beg to draw attention to your letters of the 29th December and 14th January, in regard to the case of Miss Z. Richardson; and in reply I beg to say that it would seem that a misunderstanding has arisen with regard to the rate of remuneration allowed for her services. In December 1914 the Department confirmed her appointment at a salary of $600.00 a year as teacher of the Neamakinisht Indian Day School. It seems that Miss Richardson, who is a nurse as well as a teacher, performed duties outside the school room on behalf of the Indians. Reports with regard to her work of a nursing or field matron character have been received from time to time by the Department. (The last one submitted was for the month of November 1914). The salary of $600.00 arranged for covered all work done. In your letter of the 14th January you stated that she has been paid at the rate of $720.00 since the 1st October last. There is no record in the Department's books of payment having been made at the last mentioned rate. If you can produce evidence of such payment, I shall be glad to receive it. There is on file (No. 84343) a letter from you of the 19th October 1915, with which you submitted a list of the schools under the control of the Methodist Church "west of the Lakes" and the salaries which you agreed to pay to the teachers for the year which commenced on the 1st July 1915. In that letter you stated that the list was practically the same as the one for the previous

Rev. T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Methodist Indian Schools and Hospitals in Canada,
Brandon, Man.
previous year. The Department approves of the list without having observed that you provided for a payment of $600.00 instead of $600.00 at Neanskinish, and the Department has continued to pay at the rate of $600.00. It would seem that you now wish the Department to sanction a total payment of $960.00 at Neanskinish, $300.00 of which amount you propose to pay Miss Richardson for nursing and field matron services, and $600.00 to another person appointed by the Methodist Missionary Society as teacher of the Neanskinish Indian Day School, which work Miss Richardson proposes to relinquish.

I may add that while the Department is not adverse to dividing the work, if it is considered too arduous for one person, the question of salary has still to be considered. The Department is not prepared to increase the total outlay to $960.00, and unless very good reason is forthcoming, it will not be advanced to $800.00, as the advance was agreed to under a misunderstanding.

Your obedient servant,

Miss Richardson who was teaching at Miniskinshet, left and has gone to the States. Mrs. A. L. Fakley has been appointed to take the school.

The Department of Indian Affairs

Gentlemen,

We the undersigned beg that you will kindly consider the following request:

The time has come that we must have a better schoolhouse here at our village of Minnitakiht.

The building that is being used at present (and has been used ever since our schoolhouse was burned) is an old log building built more than 20 years ago at the other end of the village from where the Teacher lives, up on a hill.

Our plan is now to build a frame building much nearer the Teacher's residence.

We have hitherto had no assistance from the Department except a part of the School teacher's salary.

Unless we have been misinformed, we understand that the Department is always willing to help in the matter of building schools.

The cost of the building that we hope to put up will be about Five Hundred dollars and we humbly ask that you will grant us this money, which would enable us build a comfortable schoolhouse and we will hold ourselves responsible to see that the work is carefully done, and will be ready at any time to show receipts for the money.

Awaiting your reply,

We remain your humble servants,

The Secretary,

Sir,-

I have the honour to state that for over a year past, I have been importuned by the Missionary and Teacher of Meanskimish, Middle Skeena, B.C., to apply to the Department that an allowance be given to that village for the erection and equipment of an Indian school house there, and beg to enclose herewith the estimates and plan thereof.

In reporting thereupon, I deem it expedient to say that the ground whereupon the school is intended to be built is not on a reserve, but is owned by the Missionary of that village, the Revd. R. Tomlinson.

The children of school age of that village number 16, possibly 17, with more soon likely to join. The school is under Miss A. L. Tomlinson, an efficient and diligent Teacher, and is making a steady and well sustained progress.

The material requisite for the building, is intended to be supplied by the Mission saw mill. The charge for freight would prove nominal since it merely requires rafting across the Skeena.

The total cost of material and labour will amount to the sum of $759.98. At present school is being taught here in a house improvised for that purpose, and not at all suited. In regard to the advisability of the village being favoured with the aforesaid amount, I can fully give it my recommendation.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

In reference to your letter, dated the 6th of March last, regarding the erection of a schoolhouse for the Menniskinist Indians, and informing me that it were not possible for the Department to build that school for not being on a reserve, and requesting a report upon the location of these Indians, I have the honour to state the following:

About twenty-four years ago, Revd. R. Tomlinson, an Anglican clergyman, started a mission on 320 acres of land, which he took up as a pre-emption in his own name. It is situate on the left bank of the Skeena, and about fourteen miles below of Kitwanga.

Thereafter, Mr. Tomlinson had Indians of Kitwanga, Kitwankool and Kitegoola to settle on a small portion thereupon, giving allotments to them of about 200 feet each adult male, in an alignment near the bank of the Skeena. They built houses thereupon, and have been having the use of the land ever since. Upon the establishment of this Agency, I drew the attention of the Indians to the fact, that under any event they were staying on the said allotments merely on sufferance. As it is, there are 53 Indians all told at the present there domiciled. These I counted yearly in the order to the villages to which they really belong.

The teaching of school here did not form a settled feature till a Teacher's grant became provided, and has, since then, been very successful.

I have the honour to be Sir,

Your obedient servant,

R E Loring Esq.
Indian Agent
Hazelton

Dear Sir;

In answer to your letter of the 19th of August let me first thank you for your kind consideration of our request for a grant to build a school house here at our Mission at Meanskinisht.

I had an opportunity to speak to Rev R. Tomlinson about letting the Department have the site where we wish to build the schoolhouse, and we came to the conclusion that it would be better if we would build the school ourselves than go to the expense of altering the lease so that the Department could be given any part of the land.

Let me explain

A certain portion of Lot 7, Group 1, Cassiar District, was leased some years ago to the Meanskinisht Village Council, for Nine Hundred and Ninety Nine years, there are many conditions connected with this lease, one of the conditions was that they were not in any way let a full blooded White Man get possession of any part of the land that was leased to them. This condition of clause will prevent them from selling the land to the Department of cause the matter could be altered to meet the case, but it would cause more trouble than it would be to build the school house ourselves and as we have the building nearly finished we will be able to go ahead.

Thanking you again

I Remain

Yours Truly

Tomlinson, the late teacher of the Meanskinisht Indian Day School, which only lately came to hand, wherewith application is made, in connection therewith, that a bathroom be erected there.

In this respect, the school premises being on privately owned ground, I should think that it follow in this not being any more effective than the building of the school house itself, in respect to my letter of December '11.

Regarding the mention of a bath tub, would establish a precedent that soon become too general of demand. In my opinion, since every family is possessed of a large wash-tub, such should be considered quite sufficient for the use of children.

In adverting to the suggestion of an encyclopedia to be supplied this school, in order, to afford the pupils mere simple answer to simple questions, I would respectfully advocate a matter, which recommends itself to my mind in an advertisement of a book sent to my address, of which I beg to enclose the same, and may prove highly advantageous to schools in general, and must, no doubt, be cheap of price, but which to examine as its merits, I, myself, have had not as yet the opportunity.

Department of Indian Affairs,

Gentlemen:

I have supplied as teacher for the Meanskinisht school for the last six months, and would like to make two suggestions as to how the work amongst the children could be better accomplished.

The first suggestion is that a bathroom be put in connection with the school house and it be compulsory that every child take a bath at least once a week.

In the village there are no bath tubs and all the water has to be brought from the river which is at its lowest in the winter time, many of the children wash very little more than their face and hands.

The second suggestion is that an encyclopedia be supplied to the school, as I have found that the children have asked questions that I have been unable to answer and there are no books to refer to for information required. Questions as,

How long is the river Amazon.
How many miles long is the Suez canal.
What kind of tree or bush do pineapples grow on.

Hoping that these suggestions may meet with your approval.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.
Hazelten, B.C.

Dear Sir,

For the past five or more years the Indian department have had the free use of the building that they are using for a school house at Meanskiniant.

The said building was built by myself at my own expense and cost a little over five hundred dollars, hither to I have not asked any rent, or have the expenses of expenses been born by the department.

As you will no doubt remember I ask that the Department buy the building out right some years ago but they refused because we could not sell them the land on which the building stood. I was in hopes that the difficulty about the land under the building could be got over, but this will be impossible at least for some years and therefore I request the department pay me a sufficient rent for the building until such time as a more satisfactory arrangement can be used.

In my judgement I should think the rent should keep the building in repair pay insurance and pay interested on money invested.

The sum of five dollars per month would cover this except in extreme cases such as another coat of paint or in a few years re shingling.

I beg that you will give this matter your best consideration and advise me as soon as possible, as if you are not in a position to press the matter, the Secretary of the Methodist Missions will take the matter up in Eastern Canada, but it seem to me that I would rather hear from you before I say anything to him.

Let the rent start to count from January 1916 as we need repairs right away.

Thanking you for your past assistance.

Sir,

In reply to your letter dated the 5th instant having reference to the furniture of the school formerly conducted at Meanskinishet. Ottawa, June 9th, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, relative to the disposal of the furniture of the Indian day school formerly conducted at Meanskinlaht.

In reply I beg to say it is noted that the number of Indians now residing at this point is so small that there will be no need for the reopening of this school. In order to do away with the payment of the rental of the building for storage purposes for the school furnishings, you may arrange to have the same distributed among the other schools in your Agency where required. Sir;

I have the honor to report that on visiting the Comox Band I found that some of them had again began to fence in their land and had done considerable work in clearing. I was asked for assistance in the way of seed but I explained to them that as they had often before been supplied with seed which they had neglected, I could not apply to the department for help until I was certain that they were in earnest.

At the request of the chief and Missionary Frank, a native of Comox, was sworn in as constable (on trial) as personally I agree with the Government Agent in the opinion that they are not to be relied on, as a rule, but I hope Frank may prove the exception to the rule, and as all the Provincial Police are removed to Union, some seven miles away it would seem fit that some one should have authority to arrest parties bringing liquor to the village.

In this Band there are 31 male adults

A.W. Vowell Esq.
Indian Superintendent
Victoria
19 female, 10 children, there were 12 deaths and no births during the last year, there are however constantly a number of Euclataw Indians visiting and residing here.

On the second day of my visit to this village I seized a Japanese boat and committed to jail the two owners for supplying liquor to the Indians since then the Missionary, Miss H. Barnes, reports that there has been no more drinking. The Chief's statement that there is large quantities of liquor being sold to the Comox Indians is simply nonsense as they have no money to buy with, or articles to trade. They are however, making an effort to turn over a new leaf, and Miss Barnes and her friends are doing all they can to assist them in advancement.

A room is rented for a school which is well attended and I should be very glad if the Department could assist either in erecting a schoolhouse in the village or in granting something in aid of the school as at present carried on.

Your advice to them last year as to the necessity of attending to their lands combined with the actual want of employment has certainly made them make a start in this direction.

I have the honor to be

Sir,

We, the Kirk Session and congregation of Comox, B.C., in connection with the Presbyterian Church of Canada, beg to say that for some time past we have been doing missionary and educational work among the Indians of this district. There are two tribes numbering in all about ninety persons. Nothing has been done for them for the past twenty years, so that they are virtually pagan. They have land but it is uncultivated. They still live in the large open houses. They subsist by fishing, hunting &c. but often they are on the verge of starvation, since we began work among them we have had about an average of 30 at the day school and about 50 at church or Sabbath. They are very anxious to have the services continued, and seem determined to do well in the future.

We therefore humbly petition the government this year for the grant of $600 per annum to hire a payment of salary of teacher and missionary who will work among them.

The Secretary:-

Re Comox Day School.

Although this school was carried on for some years by Miss Barnes, under the auspices of the Women's Christian Temperance Union of Comox, it was only in January 1900 that the Department made a grant for the payment of the teacher's salary. Returns have been regularly received since that date up to the 30th September last, which show an enrollment of 9, 15 and 4 for each quarter respectively. Two hundred dollars was voted for the erection of a school building, but as a dispute as to the control of the building seems to have arisen between the Presbyterian Church and the Indians and others interested in the work, the building was not put up and the vote lapsed. Although this Church is designated in the Estimates as belonging to the Presbyterian denomination, Rev. Dr Warden, General Agent and Treasurer of Church Schemes, declined to accept the Cheque in payment of the teacher's salary, stating that the school is not under the supervision of the Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church but is, he believes, carried on under the individual Presbyterian congregation of Comox in some way or other, but not directly under the care of his denomination. In August last Mr Supt. Vowell informed the Department that
that the Secretary of the Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church took exception to a grant being made to this school, and that in view of the stand taken by the authorities of that Church, he had instructed Mr Agent Robertson to proceed to Comox at the earliest possible date and report what school work is being done there, and what steps, if any are advisable to take in regard to the construction of a school building as well as the appointment of a teacher.

Would it not be well to ask Mr Vowell for this report before dropping the item from the estimates?

MEMORANDUM

In August 1896 the W.C.T.U. of Comox asked for a grant for an Indian schoolhouse at that place. In support of their application, they stated that one of their members, who was accustomed to teach, would willingly take charge of the school without salary. In September of that year Mr McInnes, M.P., wrote the Department recommending this application. The Department's reply was that it had no funds available and that it was not willing to increase the number of day schools in British Columbia then.

The next we hear of this school is in May 1897 when our Agent reported that a room had been rented for a school and that it would be well if the Department could assist in erecting a schoolhouse or grant something towards assisting the work. In the same month another petition was forwarded from the Moderator and other officials of the Kirk Session of Comox for a grant for the building and provision for the salary of a teacher. Mr S.W. Crawford signed this petition as Clerk of the Session along with Mr Duncan, Secretary of the Board of Management and Rev. Mr Tait, Moderator. The school then in existence was in charge of Miss Barnes, who gave her services gratuitously.

The first application was for assistance to a non-sectarian school which was to be conducted without any remuneration for the teacher. The second
was from the Presbyterian congregation of Comox who wanted provision for the teacher's salary. Miss Barnes who had started the school applied for $300.00 in October 1897 to assist in putting up a building. The Department was inclined to favor Miss Barnes' application which hung fire until 1899, when $200.00 was placed in the estimates for a building and $300 for the salary of a teacher.

The Protestant settlers at Comox had collected about $35.00 for this building and they forwarded an agreement through Mr Crawford by which they wished to bind the Department to allow the Presbyterian Church of Canada to have the use of the schoolhouse when built (and not required for school purposes) for the instruction of Indians in Christian morality. Mr Crawford began teaching in January 1900 and in a letter from our Acting Agent he was stated to be the representative at Comox of the Presbyterian Missionary Society in Canada. The Department did not feel disposed to give the guarantee asked for, but said that it had no objection to the building being used for this purpose when not otherwise required. In August 1900 the Secretary of the Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church returned a cheque which had been sent on account of the salary of Mr Crawford, stating that they had no connection with the school at that place. The Department thereupon issued instructions to obtain a report on the work being done in this school and before it was received the Presbyterian church authorities asked to have that the grant to the Comox Indians be not made use
In order to give effect to the wishes of the Church, our Superintendent was written to on the 29th January 1901 and informed that at the request of the authorities of the Presbyterian Church, the Department had decided to discontinue the grant to this school after the 30th June, 1901 and that therefore it would be unnecessary for the Agent to visit it, as before directed. The Indian Supt. acknowledged this letter on the following 4th February and stated that he had advised the Agent to the above effect.

The above are the facts of the case. Now the Department has all along maintained that Mr Crawford was only acknowledged in the first place as the nominee of the Presbyterian Church and when they repudiated him, it immediately decided to discontinue the grant, and our Superintendent notified the Agent of the district accordingly. The school was closed in fact immediately after the instructions were issued and without waiting until the 30th June.

Mr Crawford claims to have opened a school on October 1892 and asks the Department to pay him a quarter's salary for teaching 56 days out of 66. The inference is that Mr Crawford knew that the school was to have been closed in June, but he closed it himself in January and re-opened it on his own responsibility and without authority in October.

The correspondence left by you in this matter is returned herewith.

Honorable Sir:

There has been for the last four years and is now in evidence, a constant agitation among the Indians at Quamichan and adjacent reserves, Cowichan Agency, B. C. No sooner has one agitation exhausted its novelty than another is brought on the taps. These prove so many occasions to take away the attention of the Indians from their work. Instead of giving their time to useful occupations they are hurried from one meeting to another to listen to incendiary speeches.

The prime mover of these agitations is Rev. C.M. Tate, a Methodist Minister. Not being able to pervert the Catholic Indians by honorable and christian methods, he has recourse to agitations of all sorts.

To ingratiate himself with these benighted Indians he fills them with imaginary wrongs inflicted upon them by our government or by the white settlers, and all in collusion with or made a silent protection of the Catholic missionaries who laboured successfully and peaceably among them for fifty years.
His common sense might, and I think does convince him of his evil ways. Notwithstanding his better knowledge these agitations are his cherished schemes by which he ostensibly intends to frustrate the influence of the Catholic missionaries whom I instructed to discountenance such methods of low cunning by golden silence.

If similar tactics are employed among intelligent and educated people one may overlook such, and let the victims abide by their own discretion and judgment.

But to use such tactics with Indians is taking undue advantage of the low grade of their mental and social status. As a rule they can be swayed by any agitation that pleases their fancy and which holds out to them some little benefit. They blindly follow the agitator without ever considering the merits or demerits of the case.

By his incendiary speeches Rev. Mr. Tate unscrupulously undermines the authority of the local agent, the efforts of the Provincial Superintendent and the Guardianship of your Department.

In a word, such deceitful agitations can not but have and do really have a woeful bearing on the moral, religious, peaceful and industrious condition of the Indians. These unfortunate agitations not only cause the Indians' perversion from the Faith they had learned to revere, but they have an unmistakable tendency to demoralization, domestic strifes and enmity between the Indians and white...
settlers. Where before reigned faith, peace, morality and industry, there the Rev. agitator is spreading the seed of restlessness, unhappiness, discontent and recklessness.

I am not the only witness of this deplorable condition. I fear not to say your officers as well as the candid white settlers of that vicinity will corroborate my statements in every particular.

When patience in this question ceased to be a virtue, I respectfully submitted the unholy methods of Rev. Tate to his Church authorities here and at Toronto. I received plausible acknowledgements, but all without practical results.

The latest agitation which, as so many others bears the stamp of deception, is the land agitation. To the great satisfaction and exultation of Rev. Tate and his reverend Colleagues this matter was carried, as R. Smith, M. P. stated, in a form of a petition before your honorable Cabinet at Ottawa where it received a national recognition.

When about two weeks ago I learned that a commission, consisting of Senator Templeman and R. Smith, M. P. and others, was to investigate the matter on the ground, I sought an interview with these gentlemen. At this interview I stated this: Though it appears that the investigation takes place at the instigation of Rev. Tate and Colleagues, and though it will to some extent sanction their incendiary work, I submit to it in the fond hope that an end will be put to the agitation. If you find the Indians wronged I
hope you will protect their rights. But if you find the agitation unwarranted and based on religious prejudice, I expect you to say so to the Indians and report so to the Government.

Thus I have exhausted all possible means at my command to adjust the pending difficulty without the least abatement in its lamentable results.

This being the case I deemed it my duty to place the matter in your hands for a speedy adjustment.

Hoping this long letter will not prove an intrusion,

I am,

Honorable Sir,

Yours truly,

Archbishop of Vancouver Island.
Ottawa, 30th Dec., 1903.

Memorandum:

With reference to the letter of the Archbishop of Vancouver Island, it may be said that there has been a good deal of friction during the past eight or nine years since the Rev. Mr. Tate took up his residence in the Cowichan Agency, both between the Missionary and the Indian Agent, as well as between Mr. Tate and the Roman Catholic authorities.

Mr. Tate made several complaints against the late Indian Agent, Mr. Lomas. One of these, made in October, 1895, related to the Potlach or Give Away Dance, held by the Indians, and which Mr. Tate stated was encouraged by the Agent. This charge was investigated by Superintendent Vowell, who reported that he considered the Agent had gone as far as it was prudent for him to go in preventing the dances from being held.

Mr. Tate also charged the Agent with drunkenness. Mr. Vowell was instructed to hold an investigation under oath, but this was not done owing to the death
death of the Agent.

Mr. Tate also took an important part in the complaints made last year on behalf of the Cowichan Indians regarding the quantity of land set apart for them, the damage done to their reserve by the saw-logs of a lumber company cutting away their river front, and as to their fishing rights. (These are the matters referred to on page 3 of the Archbishop's letter and which he states received national recognition.)

Reports received regarding these matters would appear to indicate that the Indians have very little cause for complaint in regard thereto. A final decision has not, however, been given as yet as to whether a commission shall be appointed as requested to investigate the alleged grievances.

The Roman Catholic Church authorities have several times complained of the interference of Mr. Tate in their work in the Cowichan district. Their missionaries have contended that they have occupied that field for about forty years previous to Mr. Tate's coming amongst them. They point to the advancement made by the Indians owing to their efforts, as a proof of the good work done by them. The Indian Agent and the Indian Superintendent both have reported
reported that they considered that the Methodist Church had made a mistake in sending a missionary into a district already occupied, when there were so many points where no work had been done by any one.

On the other hand, the General Secretary of the Methodist Church has called attention to the statement made in the Annual Report of this Department that "a very large number of the Indians in the Cowichan Agency attend no church whatever, and are, in fact, pagans." The General Secretary also says that the information received from that region goes to show that the statement in the Report is true, and this being the case the Methodist Church "cannot with a good conscience refrain from efforts to enlighten and civilise these people on the very doubtful plea that they belong to another communion."

Both the Methodist and the Roman Catholic Churches applied for a grant for a school in the Cowichan Agency. Considerable ill-feeling appears to have been aroused in regard to this matter. The Indians having signified their desire that the school should be conducted under Roman Catholic management, the Department decided that a grant be made of $300 per annum to that Church towards the maintenance of a school at Soomenos, in the Cowichan Agency.
