Memorandum: -

With reference to the letter of the 15th inst. from the Archbishop of Vancouver Island, I beg to report that a good deal of ill-feeling has existed between the Roman Catholic authorities and the Rev. Mr. Tate since 1895, when the latter began work in the Cowichan Agency under the authority of the Methodist Church.

The Department was first made aware of this condition of affairs through correspondence which took place in regard to a grant for a school at Somenos in the Cowichan Agency. An application for a grant for a school at that place was made in June, 1895, by Mr. Tate and received favourable consideration, an item of $500.00 being placed in the Estimates for 1895-6 towards the support of the school.

A protest was at once entered by the Bishop of Vancouver Island against this grant being made to the Methodist Church on the ground that the Roman Catholic Church had been in possession of the field for nearly 40 years previous
previous to the Methodists having begun work there, and that his Church had frequently made application and been refused a grant for a school at Cowichan. The Indian Superintendent and the Indian Agent substantiated the statements made by the Bishop and stated that the Indians of Somenos were all Roman Catholics and desired that the school at that place be conducted by the Roman Catholic authorities. The Department, accordingly, notified the General Secretary of the Methodist Church by letter of 12th June, 1897, that as it was learned the school at Somenos was established in the centre of a Roman Catholic tribe, and as the Act provides that Indian Schools shall be furnished with teachers of the same denomination as the majority of the Band, the grant made to the Methodist School at Somenos could not be continued. Notwithstanding a protest made by the General Secretary of the Methodist Church, the grant was discontinued to the Methodist School, and since 1900 has been paid to a school conducted by the R. C. authorities.

Mr. Tate has, however, continued to carry on work in the Cowichan Agency, the Methodist Church authorities contending that the Indians at that place are not all Roman Catholics as is alleged, but that the majority of them are pagans. The policy of the Department is not to interfere with the work of any church on an Indian Reserve, and the Archbishop
Archbishop cannot, it is thought, have any grievance against the Department in regard to the manner it has acted towards Mr. Tate in so far as his religious work is concerned.

The particular matters to which Archbishop Orth's letter has reference are doubtless the petitions and letters forwarded to the Department by Rev. Mr. Tate in which complaints are made that the Cowichan Indians have not sufficient land in their reserve to meet their requirements, that the lumber companies run logs down the river which form jams and cut away their river front, and that their fishing rights have not been recognized.

The petitions and letter from Mr. Tate on this subjects are dated 25th June, 1900, 9th July, 1901, 9th March, 1903, and 7th April, 1903. Two of the letters from Mr. Tate are signed by him as Secretary of the B.C. Fisherman's Union. These matters were also brought to the attention of the Department by the Trades and Labor Congress, and a request was made that a commission be appointed to inquire into these grievances. The Department considered, however, that as full report had been received from its officers the appointment of a commission was unnecessary. The Hon. Mr. Templeman, who inquired into some of the matters complained of, reported also that this was not sufficient ground for the appointment of a commission as any little difficulties there may be ought to be easily adjusted.

Hon. Sir:

Enclosed please find for your valuable attention and kind consideration a rough map of Cowichan Agency and a tabular statement of the number of Indians belonging to the respective denominations engaged in the Indian work of the same Agency.

By a glance at the map you will see how our Indian missions are surrounding our Indian Boarding School on Kuper Island, and you will also notice their respective distances from the school.

In this connection I beg leave to remind your Honor that time and distance are of very little consideration to our Indians, particularly when they have a chance to travel by water. I wish also to add that experience has taught that a Boarding School can be more successfully conducted when some distance away from the Indian villages.

Now, Honorable Sir, I have learned that the Methodists have petitioned for a Boarding School to be established at Quamichan again in the midst of our Catholic Indian Missions.

The official report gives to the Methodists at Quamichan fifty Indians all told. I have been informed that this
report is incorrect. The Methodist Year Book for 1902 gives, and more accurately, three adults and sixteen children including infants. As to the sixteen children I must state that at least five were baptized by the Methodist Minister against the express wishes of their respective parents who afterwards brought them to the priest for Baptism.

The Methodists could easily send their children from Quamichan and other Indian Missions in Cowichan Agency to their Indian Boarding School at Coqualeetza for which they have a grant of eighty pupils, in an agency where there are but one hundred and fifty-nine Methodists all told.

Should the Indian Department have resolved to grant the Methodists a Boarding School in Cowichan Agency, it should be placed as you can see by the map, not at Quamichan but at Nanaimo where they claim according to the official report, 165 Indians in all.

By conferring on this matter with Hon. Templeman you will certainly obtain more information, and I have not the slightest doubt that he will see the reasonableness of my respectful suggestion, particularly with regard to the geographical feature that should come under consideration in the settlement of the proposed Methodist Boarding School for the Cowichan Agency.

It has not been the practice of Catholic missionaries to enter fields previously occupied by ministers of other denominations; for we know too well by so doing we disturb and do not build up.
This unfortunate result has been realized on Vancouver Island wherever Protestant Ministers have entered Catholic missions. Nothing disturbs the mind of the Indian more than conflict and reckless contentions between Ministers of different denominations.

But, it might be retorted, the Indians asked for Protestant Ministers. This may be true in some instances. Anyone somewhat acquainted with the character of the Indians generally, and with the pagan Indians especially, knows that such petitions are based on avaricious and sordid motives. During the last three years four Indian delegations from Protestant Missions waited on me and during the interview I was asked to send Priests to their tribes. It did not require a keen observer to discover their unholy motives. Hence they received a refusal without the least hesitation.

Today I learned that Rev. Tate, the local Methodist Minister, who has been agitating there for the last four years, is making efforts to establish at Quamichan a day school. We have a day school at Quamichan and one at Somenos, 2-1/2 miles apart, and now the Methodists are trying to conduct one in the midst of our Indians. Whether it is a real effort or but another agitation, its results will be but a source of trouble to the Department and to the Indians as well.

If Rev. Tate has secured some signatures to his petition, they have been obtained by agitations, misrepresentations
or some other misleading schemes for which he is unfavorably known by the white settlers of that locality.

Asking pardon for this long letter,

I am, with sentiments of respect,

Honorable Sir,

Your humble servant,

Archbishop of Vancouver Island.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the attached type-written copy of a letter from His Grace, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Vancouver Island, to the Minister, protesting against the establishment of a boarding school to be conducted by the Methodists at Quamichan, I beg to say that I have not yet seen any application for a Methodist school at this point, but if made by them I consider that Archbishop is quite justified in objecting to their receiving Government aid for such a school as the Methodists form a very small portion of the Indian population in the Cowichan Agency. The total number of Indians according to the census for last year in this Agency is 1934 of whom 347 are Methodists, 1465 Roman Catholics, 57 Presbyterians and the balance, 65 pagans. There are seven day schools in operation in this Agency, five of which are conducted by the Roman Catholics while the Presbyterians and Methodists each have one. There is a boarding school carried on by the Roman Catholics also at Kuper Island in this Agency. Most of the Methodists live at Nanaimo where their day school is established.

Rev. Mr Tait applied for the establishment of a boarding school directly on the opposite side of the Island, when it was decided not to grant his request as there were too many applications for boarding schools being made.

The Methodists have an Industrial...
at Coqualeetza on the Fraser, with provision for 80 pupils at $130.00, which is 30 more pupils than is allowed to any other school in the Province, while their adherents in the Fraser River Agency, in which the school is situated, only number 158 out of a total population of 2865, of whom 2582 are Roman Catholics. It would be easy for the Methodists to send a few children to Coqualeetza from the Cowichan Agency if there was any necessity for doing so.

It is quite true that the Roman Catholics have been doing missionary work among the Indians of British Columbia for about fifty years, while the Methodists are new-comers and have made very few converts. As I before pointed out, it is not the province of the Department to assist any religious body in making proselytes.

Memorandum,

Mr. Sifton,

The correspondence from Archbishop Orth of Vancouver, referred to in your memorandum of the 26th ultimo, dealing with the state of unrest among the Indians of the Cowichan Agency may be more intelligently considered under two heads, namely,

1st- That relating to schools,
2nd, That relating to lands.

1st- In 1895 Mr. Tate, Methodist Missionary applied for a grant for a school at Somenos in the Cowichan Agency. This received favourable consideration here and an item of $300.00 was placed in the Estimates of 1895-96 towards the support of the school. A protest was at once entered by the Bishop of Vancouver Island against this grant being made to the Methodist Church on the ground that the Roman Catholic Church, as Missionary, had been in the field for nearly 40 years previous to the time the Methodists commenced work and that his Church had frequently applied for but had been refused a grant for a school at Cowichan. The Indian Superintendent and the Indian Agent substantiated the statements made by the Bishop and further stated that the Indians at Somenos were all Roman Catholics and asked that the school at that place be conducted by the Roman Catholic authorities.

The Department
The Department, after full consideration of the matter, notified the General Secretary of the Methodist Church, by letter dated 18th June, 1897, that as it was learned the school at Somenos was established in the centre of a Roman Catholic tribe, and as the Act provides that Indian Schools shall be furnished with teachers of the same denomination as the majority of the band the grant made to the Methodist School at Somenos could not be continued. The General Secretary of the Methodist Church protested against the action of the Department but notwithstanding his protest the grant was discontinued to the Methodist school and since 1900 has been paid in support of one conducted by the Roman Catholic authorities.

Mr. Fate has, however, continued to carry on work in the Cowichan Agency the Methodist Church authorities contending that the Indians at that place are not all Roman Catholics, as alleged, but that the majority of them are Pagans.

The policy of the Department is not to interfere with the work of any church on an Indian Reserve and whatever may be the Archbishop's grievances they cannot be against the Department in its action regarding the Methodist Church and the school grant.

2.— It has been alleged from time to time that the Cowichan Indians have not sufficient land to meet their requirements and that the river is used by the Lumber Companies for running logs which form a jam and cut away their river front. It is claimed also that the fishing rights of the Indians have not been recognized. The Reverend Mr. Fate has evidently been the spokesman for the Indians in the matter of these complaints, as indicated by letters of the 25th June, 1900, 9th July, 1901, 9th March, 1903 and 7th April, 1903. The letters of March and April are signed by him as Secretary of the British Columbia Fisherman's Union.
The above matters were brought to the attention of the Department by the Trades and Labour Congress, by a Resolution passed at the Berlin convention on or about April 6th, 1905, with the request that a commission be appointed to enquire into these grievances. The resolution of the Trades and Labour Congress was brought to the attention of Sir William Mulock by a deputation, I understand, of this Association and subsequently submitted to this Department for report.

Following this, correspondence was had with the Hon. Mr. Templeman Superintendent Vowell and Mr. Ashdown Green, P. L. S., the substance of whose replies is that no commission was necessary, that the Indians had few if any grievances and these of a comparatively trifling nature and that they had more than sufficient land for all practical purposes. I made a report to you on the 22nd July last, which I append herewith.

The Department knows nothing of the commission consisting of Senator Templeman, Ralph Smith, M. P., and others mentioned in the latter portion of the Archbishop's letter.

It is evident that the friction existing in this locality, as indicated by the correspondence, is of a religious character or has arisen through some form of labour agitation.

The Department has given considerable attention to this case in order to ascertain what are the causes, if any, of the complaints, and has been most anxious to recognize the rights of the parties and preserve harmony. Unless Archbishop Orth is prepared to make the charges more specific it is difficult to say what further action is necessary.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

In reply to your enquiry regarding the practice of the Department in allowing different denominations to take up religious and educational work on Indian reserves, I beg to say that the Department has been in the habit of acceding to the request of any religious body for the privilege of erecting a place of worship on a reserve, if any portion of the Band belonged to the denomination making the request. See memo. from Mr Smart to the Minister, dated 23rd July, 1900 on file 194, 906, and the Minister's ruling approving of the granting of a location for a Roman Catholic church on the Whitefish Lake Indian reserve where the majority of the Indians were Protestants and objected to the Roman Catholics application. The only condition imposed by the Minister was that the Roman Catholic Church was not to be too near the other one.

The case which led up to your enquiry would appear to be similar. The Methodists wish to put up a church on a reserve where the majority of the Indians are Roman Catholics and refuse to give their consent. It seems to me that the Minister's ruling should work both ways.

Previous to the above decision of the Superintendent General, the consent of the Indians in such cases was required as you will see from an extract from a letter from the Indian Commissioner,
dated 19th March, 1890, fyle 66,444.

With regard to the establishment of a second school by another denomination, the Indian Act provides that "the Protestant or Catholic minority may likewise have a separate school with the approval of and under regulations made by the Governor in Council," but it has always been the policy of the Department to discourage the establishment of competing schools in the same Band unless the number of Indians of a different faith was sufficiently large to necessitate such a division. This practice is well understood by all denominations carrying on work among the Indians. See letter from Rev. Dr Sutherland of 13th March, 1890 on fyle 43,685.

The question still remains to be decided, however, as to how many pupils of an average attendance entitles a separate school to the Government grant. See circular 3rd Dec. 1887 on fyle 80,151, on this subject, and the replies thereto from the leading church workers at that time.

Dear Sir,

After our conversation in which you gave it as your opinion that the permission given by the Indian Department to build the Methodist Church School House at Quamichan did not authorise you to allow the Methodist Church, either to build on the church lot or to place a missionary on either the said lot or on the reserve without a further reference to the Department, I deem it best to address you directly knowing that you will forward the whole matter to the Department for its consideration.

The Rev. C. M. Tate as you will remember, disregarding your instructions and mine as to the form of application necessary to secure the consideration of the Department, began building without permission and was stopped by the Department. On my return from the North West Coast, I waited on Mr. Vowell who explained the situation to me. On behalf of the Church I at once apologised to the Department and as instructed by Mr. Vowell I at once applied in proper form. Nothing could be kinder than the manner in which Mr. Vowell placed everything necessary to the application at my disposal. This application is the one the Department acted upon and in due time July 8th, 1904. Mr. Vowell wrote me as follows:- "I have the honor to inform you that in accordance with a telegram received from the Indian Department at Ottawa it has been decided that work at the Methodist Church at Quamichan may be proceeded with."

The application which I had sent forward and which the Department at Ottawa under consideration when it sent the above permission embodied a full description of the lot with a map thereof and the request that we be allowed the use of this lot for the Methodist Church for Missionary Purposes. This application was sent in duplicate and is now in the hands of the Department so that it will not be necessary for me to do more than refer you thereto.

Under these circumstances I not unnaturally concluded that the permission granted to build the church carried with it all assent to all that was in my application. For if the Department had thought otherwise it would surely have informed me of the exceptions.

The lot of land in question is the lot that Bill Whulaisillock the owner thereof marked out in my presence and in that of a large number of Indians and said that this was the land that he wished to give to the church for church purposes. At the time I suggested that the consent of the band and of the Agent should be had. He was much displeased and wanted to know what any other Indian had to say about his land. It was impossible just then to call the band as they were in a measure gone to the salmon fishing. I cannot remember why you were not present when the land was thus marked out, but I think that you were away somewhere. In any case the lot described in the application is exactly the lot that on that occasion he marked out and gave to the church and to which a goodly number of the Indians present gave positive assent in speech. There was no dissent. As it was impossible to call the band then and as the Department knew all the circumstances of the case fully I respectfully submit that the above permission of the Department carries with it full powers privileges to the land for missionary purposes and did in the mind of the Department when it was Issued.

At the same time I admit all the force of your contention that the lot has not been marked out in your presence and that the Indian Council or Band did not in due form in your presence assign the land to us.

I would be much pleased to have the decision of the Department at the earliest possible moment. As this application covers the application made for the residence of Mr. Bignell at the Reserve, which was unauthorised by me, it may be dropped.

Thanking you for your kindness, I remain, very respectfully yours,

R. D. Hutton

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With further reference to the application made by the Rev. C. M. Tate, Methodist Missionary, Duncan, B.C., for permission for the teacher of a day school established by the Methodists on the Quamichan reserve to reside there, which was refused by official letter of November 27, last, I beg to say that additional correspondence on this subject has been received from the Indian Superintendent, covering a letter from the Rev. Dr. Whittington, Superintendent of Methodist Missions in British Columbia, and one from Mr. Agent Robertson.

Dr. Whittington claims that the permission already granted to the Methodist Missionary Society to erect a church on this reserve carried with it the Department's assent to the missionary or teacher to take up his residence there.

You may remember that there was a great deal of correspondence on the subject of the building of this church, which was objected to by the Roman Catholic Archbishop and members of the band nearly two years ago. The matter was submitted to the late Minister on a memorandum from you of July 5, 1904, and the Minister's decision was given in the following words: "After giving this matter the fullest consideration I have decided to allow the Methodists to proceed with the erection of their building. Telegraph orders accordingly and advise..."
Dr. Sutherland and Archbishop Orth of the decision.

On the strength of this authority the Methodists without permission established a day school on the reserve, and they now wish to have this school recognized by the Department and be allowed the usual day school salary grant, with leave for the teacher to take up his residence on the reserve.

In my memorandum of November 24, last, turned out herewith, I pointed out why I considered it unnecessary to allow the teacher to live on the reserve, and since that date an application has been received from the Rev. Dr. Whittington through the Agent and Superintendent for the salary grant. There is certainly no need for two schools in the neighborhood of this reserve, although the Roman Catholic school is just outside it.

The total population of the Quamichan band according to the last census is 369, 20 of whom are given as Methodists, 156 as Roman Catholics and 14 as pagans, while the school population amounts to 54. This year's census apparently shows a gain of 20 Methodists over last year, and it is for the purpose of helping on their proselytizing work that they are anxious to obtain a foothold on the reserve.

It is for the Department to decide whether the late Minister's ruling entitles them to a resident teacher and, if not, whether it considers it would be advisable to grant them this privilege.

The Department has also to deal with their application for the salary grant. The school population on this reserve is not large enough to entitle them to two schools.
but as they have one denominational school for the Roman Catholics, the Methodists consider that they are entitled to similar treatment, notwithstanding the fact that they started this school on their own responsibility, without first obtaining the consent of the Department. There is no provision made in next year's estimates for this school, and Dr. Whittington is just simply trying to force the Department's hand on the strength of the permission granted him by the late Minister for the erection of the church, which to my mind was all that was contemplated when the Minister gave his decision.

I went fully into the merits of the case in my memorandum of June 30, 1904, which was submitted to the Minister.

[Signature]

Martin Brown

Sir:

Herewith I submit my report of Inspections made during the month of January, 1912:

Upon my visit to the Quamichan Day School (Methodist) I found it closed, but upon my return on the 26th it was open. There were only three children present. The average attendance last quarter was only 5.14. This quarter there only eight boys on the roll; last quarter 12—8 boys and 4 girls. Mr. Rowden, the teacher says it is not advisable to keep this school open for longer than four months each year—November, December, January and February, as most of the Indians go away and take their children with them. This being the case I do not see any use in continuing the grant at all, as the practical results obtained by Indian children from four months education in a preparatory school amount to nothing, for they forget everything they have learned, while they are away.

Dear Sir,

Replying to yours of the 5th inst. #129635 A re Quamichan School on the Cowichan Reserve, the attendance at this School has been very small ever since I have known anything concerning it. The Kekskilah School on this Reserve is attended by children who belong to parents who have settled on the land. The present school building is to one side of the homes where the children come from, and I found on visiting that school that the girls do not attend. The reason given by the teacher is that they have to go to and from their homes through the woods and some things have happened that make it unwise to expose the girls to the temptations and difficulties, hence the parents object to the girls attending the School.

The present school building is not of very much value, and not being properly located, I would suggest that a new school be built over in the heart of the Kekskilah portion of the Reserve a little South of the Cowichan River, which could only be about half a mile from the present Cowichan school. OTTAWA 15th June 1897

Rev: Sir,

In further reference to the Indian school at Somenos which is carried on by Mrs Nicholas under the auspices of your Society, I beg to say that although this school is provided for in the Estimates, it was through an oversight in their preparation that it was allowed, as it is in the heart of a Roman Catholic tribe, which had previously had a school of their own there. The Act provides that Indian schools shall be furnished with teachers of the same denomination as the majority of the Band, but that schools for the minority may be held also. In this instance, as nearly every Indian belongs to the Roman Catholic Church, the Department should not, it is thought, contribute towards the support of a Methodist School.

The school at Skidegate, where the Indians belong to the Methodist Church is unprovided for, and it is thought that if a transfer of the grant from the Somenos to the Skidegate school could be arranged, it would be better for all parties concerned, as the Roman Catholic authorities object and reasonably, it is thought, to the Government establishing a school of another denomination in their midst.

The Department would be glad if you would give this matter your favorable consideration.

Your obedient servant,

Rev: A Sutherland D:D:
Genl: Secy:

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th ultimo, No. 129637-7, referring to the Indian school at Somonos, British Columbia, taught by Mrs Nicholas, and stating "that although this school is provided for in the estimates, it was through an oversight in their preparation that it was allowed, as it is in the heart of a Roman Catholic tribe, which had previously had a school of their own there;" also that "as nearly every Indian belongs to the Roman Catholic Church, the Department should not, it is thought, contribute toward the support of a Methodist school."

In reply to the above, I respectfully call attention of the Indian Department to the Report on Indian Affairs for the year ending June 30th, 1895, p. 360. It will be observed in that report no attempt is made to give the relative strength of the Denominations in the Cowichan Agency, where the total population is 1945, but instead of the missionary figures the following note is appended:

"The majority of the Indians have been baptised into the Roman Catholic Church; many attend Roman Catholic Missions, Wesleyan, and English Church, as they may feel inclined, but a very large number attend no church whatever, and are in fact pagans."

We have no reason for believing that any particular change has taken place in the religious condition of the Indians since the above note was written. On the contrary all the information we have received from that region goes to show that the statement...
in the Report is true, that "a very large number attend no Church whatever, and are, in fact, pagans." The old mode of living and the old heathen practices still largely prevail, and this being the case we cannot, with a good conscience, refrain from enlightening and civilizing these people on the very doubtful plea that they "belong" to another communion; and while we have a school well conducted, with a good average attendance, we feel that we are fairly entitled to the customary grant.

I am,

Sir,

Your Obedient Servant,

Dear Sir,

Pardon the liberty I take in again calling your attention to the matter in connection with the Indian School at Somence, under the auspices of the Methodist church. If we are to lose our grant because of representations made by the Agent, who is a bitter enemy to our work, then it is time that further investigation was made.

When we opened our school at Somence, there was no other school in the district, and according to the Blue Book, saying nothing about personal acquaintance with the people, the great majority of the people were pagan, which was the fact, and which is the fact today.

Now, Sir! the injustice lies not only in removing the grant but in practically telling us that we have no business in the field.

The Roman Catholics sent a priest to that point, after our work had been commenced, and he was "well fellow well met" with the Agent. We found opposition at once; and on two or three occasions, the Agent took several of the best scholars from our school, and sent them to the R.C. institution at Rupert Island.

I trust that this unrighteous proceeding will be made right, and thus relieve the crippled condition of our work.

The circumstances under which we open our work here, are the very same as at Cowchuck. The priests have been here for over 20 years, and the poor people are just as destitute as they ever were. Two-thirds of the Indians here have invited us to open a mission among them, and for that purpose we have been sent here by the Missionary Society of the Methodist Church.

No wonder that the Indians want a change, for I find that their missionary is a Sunday-school, card-playing, Sabbath-breaking priest, who holds one service on Sunday, and nothing else during the week. I am informed that he gets a grant for a day-school, but I have been here a month now, and there has been no school.

We intend prosecuting mission work among this people, and when we become established, will write the department further with regard to school matters. In the meantime, I do not want it to be understood that we are here simply to oppose the Catholic priest, but at the invitation of the Indians.

I am Sir:

Yours Very Truly,

C. M. Tate,
Methodist Missionary.

P.S. We expect to build here shortly, but must first obtain the consent of the Superintendent, so say Mr. Quillod, the local Agent. Kindly send the required permission, and oblige Yours,

C. M. Tate.

It was, however, suggested that as the school at Skidegate, where the Indians are Methodists, is unprovided for, it would be well if a transfer of the grant from the

In his reply of the 8th July last, Dr Sutherland stated that he had strong reason for believing that the Indians of Somenos do not belong to any church,—in fact that they were pagans, and therefore he thought that the Methodist Church had as good a right to conduct a school there as any other church.

Dr Sutherland was informed in reply that according to the Census of 1896 all the Indians at Somenos belong to the Roman Catholic Church. This is confirmed by the last Census received, up to the 30th June last.

Vowell forwarding copies of correspondence having reference to the re-opening of a day school at Somenos under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. Mr Vowell directed Agent Lomas to point out to the Rev. Missionary in charge, the inexpediency of his pressing his application until he can demonstrate that the majority of the Somenos Band is in favor of his action (in re-opening the school) and that there are sufficient children of school age available at Somenos to render his project

I would refer you to my letter of the 17th inst. in which I stated that a meeting of the Somenos Indians was held in my office on Saturday night last at which both Rev. Father VanGoethem and Rev. C. M. Tate were present but that as only half of the band were present I declined to take a vote on the subject of giving a site for a Methodist school house or church.

When I did this I felt sure that all present were opposed to Mr. Tate's application and

Victoria.
Mr. Tate knew this as well as I did, for when I adjourned the meeting to Monday night, Oct. 16th he made the remark that as I was calling out Indians to search for the lost man John Duncanson on Monday there would be no more present then, the result proved different as every male Indian of voting age in the village was present at the Monday night meeting. Mr. Tate did not appear at the meeting although it was a somewhat lengthy one, and Mr. Tate resides some 200 yards from this office.

He knew perfectly well of the adjourned meeting as he came to the office the next morning (Tuesday) to know the result and I showed him the press copy of resolutions which I had just posted to you, so that all the information he had when he wrote you was from me.

discussion."

He knew that he was lying (I do not like using this term but with regard to Mr. Tate it is necessary.)

You know this office building, and the long windedness of Indians. As a rule, place a matter before them let the Chief take my chair and retire to the smaller room while they discuss the subject before the meeting, when they come to a decision they ask me to return. I should not have allowed either Rev. Father VanGoethem or Mr. Tate to be with them when the matter was being discussed, but as a matter of fact I could hear every word that was said from the inner office.

The Reverend Father VanGoethem is too much of a gentleman to have ever wished to be present.

When the matter was discussed he was in my private office until the Indians recalled me to say they had decided and wished me to write their decision.

In this case
I was particularly careful not even to advise the members of the Band in either way. I felt sure that I knew the feeling of the Indians and I can assure you that every one who spoke was opposed to Mr. Tate having a school on the Somenos Reserve.

To conclude I would state that no Roman Catholic Priest was ever closeted with Somenos Indians in this office; and that I, although not in the chair during the discussion, was near enough to hear all said and wrote down the resolution in their presence at the close of the meeting and when asking if it was their unanimous vote every Indian present rose to his feet and said it was.

Sir,

OTTAWA, 13th November, 1899

The Secretary:

In reference to my memorandum of the 28th ultimo on the subject of the application of the Rev. Mr Tait of the Methodist Mission at Cowichan for a site upon which to erect a schoolhouse at Somenos, I beg to say that Mr Supt. Vowell was written to as directed by the Deputy Minister, but previous to the receipt of that letter he has forwarded copies of correspondence had with him by the late Agent Lomas and Mr Tait, on this subject; and although Mr Vowell expresses the opinion that the Indians are not likely to grant Mr Tait's application, I think it would be well to await the report of the new Agent whose attention is to be called to this matter.

In the last letter from Mr Vowell he states that the present bias of the Indians towards the Roman Catholic Church is pronounced and unmistakable and that he would therefore recommend the application of the Rev. Father Van Goethen for the grant to be paid to the school which he has now in operation.

I do not think that there is any doubt but that the majority of the Indians of the Band are Roman Catholics. The question of the rights of the Methodist
Methodist minority can be considered later on.

In this connection I beg to call your attention to an apparent oversight in the preparation of the estimates by which an item for a school at Somenos is placed among the items for Methodist schools. This is clearly a mistake as the Rev. Dr Sutherland was told two years ago that a grant for a Methodist school at that place would be discontinued.

Letter 12th June 1897.
